HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Prisons (Transfer of Prisoners Labour and Jail Industry Food Clothings and Sanitation) Rules (1988)
heading: Release of wages for work done during custody in prison
HeadNote.description: Release of wages for work done during custody in prison - Dispute as to whether convict had been paid wages as per circulars/orders applicable to her - Appellant during her actual custody viz. 3 years 10 months was assigned work in Medical Inspection room as sewadar (Assistant) for assisting doctors in OPD of jail - In view of conflicting stand taken by both parties and assertion of appellant about her signature and certain entries in ledger - Appellant permitted to make a fresh representation to visiting Judge - Further visiting Judge on receipt of said representation directed to inspect and peruse ledgers/documents with assistance of jail authority and pass an order within period of 3 months thereafter.  (Paras 9, 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Daman (Abolition of Proprietorship of Villages) Regulations (1962)
heading: Proceeding before Mamlatdar
Power of Collector
HeadNote.description:
Proceeding before Mamlatdar - Power of Collector - Collector has powers of suo-motu revision of the orders that may be passed by the Mamlatdar under the Regulation.

Even though the Collector is opponent in the proceeding before the Mamlatdar and he has to protect the interest of the State by virtue of position held by him, under Sec.12-D of the Regulation he has also powers of suo-moto revision of the orders that may be passed by the Mamlatdar under the said Regulation. The Collector has no personal interest in the matter. He or his representative has to place all the material on record, etc. before the Mamlatdar in the enquiry under the Regulation so that Mamlatdar may come to the correct conclusion as to whether certain property is agricultural land or not and whether such property is covered by the provisions of the Regulation or not. If the Collector deems it necessary, in view of the facts and circumstances of the case, he can certainly exercise suo-moto revisional powers under Sec.12-D of the Regulation. [Para 6]

heading: Verification of antecedents
HeadNote.description:
Selection for post of constables - Verification of antecedents - Screening committee finding that candidate was of a violent nature and had no respect for the law of land and he was acquitted as a result of compromise - Another candidate charged under Ss.307, 504 and 506 IPC was acquitted by giving benefit of doubt - Screening Committee refusing to take cognizance of compromise and benefit of doubt despite the fact that both candidates had not concealed these facts - Held, Screening committee cannot be faulted for declining to take cognizance of compromise and benefit of doubt.

The police force is a disciplined force. It shoulders the great responsibility of maintaining law and order and public order in the society. People repose great faith and confidence in it. It must be worthy of that confidence. A candidate wishing to join the police force must be a person of utmost rectitude. He must have impeccable character and integrity. A person having criminal antecedents will not fit in this category. Even if he is acquitted or discharged in the criminal case, that acquittal or discharge order will have to be examined to see whether he has been completely exonerated in the case because even a possibility of his taking to the life of crimes poses a threat to the discipline of the police force. The Standing Order, therefore, has entrusted the task of taking decisions in these matters to the Screening Committee. The decision of the Screening Committee must be taken as final unless it is mala fide.

Compromises or settlements have to be encouraged to bring about peaceful and amiable atmosphere in the society by according a quietus to disputes. They have to be encouraged also to reduce arrears of cases and save the litigants from the agony of pending litigation. But these considerations cannot be brought in here. In order to maintain integrity and high standard of police force, the Screening Committee may decline to take cognizance of a compromise, if it appears to it to be dubious. The Screening Committee cannot be faulted for that.

The respondents are trying to draw mileage from the fact that in their application and/or attestation form they have disclosed their involvement in a criminal case. Disclosure of these facts in the application/attestation form is an essential requirement. An aspirant is expected to state these facts honestly. Honesty and integrity are inbuilt requirements of the police force. The respondents should not, therefore, expect to score any brownie points because of this disclosure.

If it is found by the Screening Committee that the person against whom a serious case involving moral turpitude is registered is discharged on technical grounds or is acquitted of the same charge but the acquittal is not honourable, the Screening Committee would be entitled to cancel his candidature. Stricter norms need to be applied while appointing persons in a disciplinary force because public interest is involved in it.				           [Para 21,26,27,28]

HeadNote.act_name: Drivers of Motor Cars and Jeeps in Government Offices (Recruitment) Rules (1980)
heading: Promotion
HeadNote.description: Promotion - Three years experience for promotion to the post of driver - Peon used to drive in absence of driver and he was paid 20% special pay for such service - Three years were computed by adding 5 days to 14 days spread over a period of 20 years service - Held, requisite experience of three years for promotion must be taken to mean regular experience for a period of three years in continuation and not spread over 20 years and as such said peon was not entitled to promotion. (Para 5)

HeadNote.description: Release of wages for work done during custody in prison - Dispute as to whether convict had been paid wages as per circulars/orders applicable to her - Appellant during her actual custody viz. 3 years 10 months was assigned work in Medical Inspection room as sewadar (Assistant) for assisting doctors in OPD of jail - In view of conflicting stand taken by both parties and assertion of appellant about her signature and certain entries in ledger - Appellant permitted to make a fresh representation to visiting Judge - Further visiting Judge on receipt of said representation directed to inspect and peruse ledgers/documents with assistance of jail authority and pass an order within period of 3 months thereafter. heading: Registration Certificate
HeadNote.description: Registration Certificate - Issue of Certificate to respondent company not in respect of any part or a separate innovated design but in respect of the whole of ceiling fan - Ceiling fan not invention or a new design by the respondent company - Same could not have been registered - Held, Registration Certificate issued in favour of respondent company is erroneous and consequently requires to be cancelled. 1987 Vol.II English and Irish Appeal 380 - Rel. on.	(Para 6)

heading: Infringement of registered design
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of registered design - Fans manufactured by plaintiffs and defendants - Design of fans not similar - Relief cannot be granted - Pendency of petition under S.51-A does not preclude court from granting relief if necessary.

The plaintiffs and defendants manufactured ceiling and other kinds of electrical fans.  The design of fans manufactured by both were not identical nor there was any imitation.  It was held that it is only if the Court comes to the conclusion that the subsequent design is fraudulent or is obvious imitation that the Court would consider the question of granting any interim relief.  As a matter of law.  It may be stated that mere pendency of any petition under Section 51-A will not preclude the Court from examining the issue and to grant the necessary relief, if circumstances so require.  Consequently, no relief could be granted to the plaintiff.  [Para 4]

heading: Other remedy open
HeadNote.description: Other remedy open - Allegation that there is infringement of design by defendant - Statutory remedy provided under S.51A - It does not preclude High Court from granting interim relief if case requires. (Para 6)

heading: Pensionary benefits
Resignation and retirement
HeadNote.description: Pensionary benefits - Resignation and retirement - Both stand on different footing - So far as "resignation" is concerned, it is a voluntary act of an employee to say good-bye to the employer on his own volition - So far as "retirement" is concerned, it is a natural consequence where an employee on reaching a particular age automatically retires - Resignation letter cannot be treated as an application for voluntary retirement. (2004)4 SCC 412 and (2004)9 SCC 461 - Ref. to.	(Paras 6, 9)

heading: Certificate of Diplomatic Immunity
HeadNote.description: Certificate of Diplomatic Immunity - Issuance of, at the stage of revision - Held, it would be unsafe to rely on the certificate issued at revisional stage without giving parties an opportunity to lead evidence on validity or otherwise of such certificate. (Para 17)

heading: Certificate of Diplomatic Immunity
HeadNote.description: Certificate of Diplomatic Immunity - Held, presumption raised by such certificate is rebuttable and not absolute - Whether a particular activity of Diplomatic Agent is immuned from legal proceedings or not is a matter to be decided on facts and evidence brought in each case. (Para 18)

heading: Diplomatic Immunity from legal proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Diplomatic Immunity from legal proceedings - Exception in case of commercial activity - No general rule to ascertain whether a particular activity of Diplomatic Agent is commercial or not - Answer depends on facts of each case - Hence it is desirable that parties be given liberty to produce their respective evidence on the point - Reliance on certificate issued u/s.9 for that purpose, is not desirable. 

No general rule or proposition of law can be laid down as to what would be commercial activity as contemplated by Article 31 of Diplomatic Relations (Vienna Convertion) Act.1972. This aspect will certainly depend on the facts of each case. In a given case, for the purpose of benefit of the persons employed in an Embassy or Consulate (Foreign Mission), some portion of the premises may be permitted to be used by outsider and such outsider may be paying certain rent/licence fee/compensation to the Foreign Mission. In such situation, the activity of permitting such outsider to use the premises would qualify to be an incidental activity in aid of and for the benefit of the principal activity of the Foreign Mission. In such a situation, the agent of the Foreign Mission will certainly enjoy the immunity. However, there may be another case where an outsider may have been inducted for monetary consideration by permitting such outsider to use the premises of the Foreign Mission for conducting an activity completely unconnected with the Sovereign functions of a Foreign Nation. In such a situation, no immunity would be available and such a case will be governed by Sub-Article C of Article 31(1) of the Schedule to the 1972 Act. It is therefore unsafe to lay down any straight jacket formula for arriving at a conclusion that any activity of a Foreign Mission invariably enjoys immunity.  [Para 19]

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Appointment of administrator
Power as to
HeadNote.description:
Supersession of committee of management of Cooperative Bank - Appointment of administrator - Power as to - Scope.

In conformity with the requirements of Section 2(gg) of the DICGC Act, 1961, Section 110A of the MCS Act provides for certain special provisions applicable to cooperative banks. Section 2(gg) of the DICGC Act, 1961 has to be read with Section 110A of the MCS Act. The said Section 2(gg)(iii) clearly provides that the eligible co-operative bank, if so required by the Reserve Bank of India in the public interest or for preventing the affairs of the bank being conducted in a manner detrimental to the interest of the depositors or for securing the proper management of the bank, an order shall be made for supersession of the Committee or Committee of Management or other Managing body of the bank and the appointing of administrator for a specified period. In case of insured co-operative banks under the DICGC Act, 1961, the order for winding up, reconstruction, supersession of the Committee cannot be made by the Registrar of Cooperative Societies under the MCS Act without sanction or requisition of the Reserve Bank of India. The Reserve Bank of India has powers under the provisions of MCS Act in respect of winding up, reconstruction, supersession of the Management Committee or Board of Directors of such insured cooperative bank. The said provision also has to be read with Section 56 of the Banking Regulation Act. In view of the said provisions under Section 110A of the MCS Act starting with a non-obstante clause, the said provisions overrides the other provisions of the Act. (Para 98)

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Guaranteeing of credit facilities and indemnifying credit institutions
HeadNote.description:
Guaranteeing of credit facilities and indemnifying credit institutions - Held, in a contract of indemnity, the indemnity holder is not bound to sue the indemnifier - The indemnity holder may sue only the debtor or only the indemnifier or both - In law, there is nothing that prevents an agreement or arrangement between an indemnity holder and the indemnifier as to the manner or circumstances in and conditions on which the contract of indemnity may be enforced.

In a contract of indemnity the indemnity holder is not bound to sue the indemnifier. The indemnity holder may sue only the debtor or only the indemnifier or both. In law there is nothing that prevents an agreement or arrangement between an indemnity holder and the indemnifier as to the manner or circumstances in and the conditions on which the contract of indemnity may be enforced. In particular there is nothing which anything prohibits an arrangement whereby the indemnifier pays the amount due under the contract of indemnity subject to the condition or on an understanding between the indemnity holder and the indemnifier that the indemnity holder will continue to pursue its remedies against the debtor and in the event of it recovering the amounts from the debtor it would refund the same to the indemnity holder.  [Para 9]

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Bank in liquidation
HeadNote.description: Bank in liquidation - Insurance Corporation repaying depositors to the extent of Rupees one lakh each - Insurance Corporation thereafter can claim surplus amount with Official Liquidator after making provision for expenses of liquidation proceedings and for declaration of dividend - Held, High Court erred in directing Official Liquidator to pay surplus amount to depositors instead of paying the same to the Corporation.  (Paras 28, 29, 30, 31)

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Is not arbitrary
HeadNote.description: Constitutional validity of second proviso - Plea that proviso completely cuts down main provisions contained in S.16(1) - However, perusal of proviso shows that it does not wipe out liability provided u/s.16(1) on part of DICGC - But it only restricts such liability upto Rs.1,00,000/- - It only thus qualifies or excepts certain provisions from main enactment - Is not arbitrary - Particularly when said proviso makes legislative intent clear that liability of DICGC was to extend upto the limit to be prescribed in proviso and not any further.  (Para 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Constitutionality of provisions
HeadNote.description: Constitutionality of provisions - Challenge based on ground that provisions of Ss.19, 21 of Act 1961 and those of Ss.10, 43 of 1949 Act grant priority to DICGC in matter of recovery of amount from assets of insured Bank, it had paid to depositors of said bank - However, DICGC is concerned with entire banking system in country - If priority not given to DICGC that would result in virtual collapse in functioning of DICGC and also possibly have deleterious effect on banking system in country - That would be against legislative intent - Provisions in issue held, neither arbitrary nor unconstitutional. (Para 27)

HeadNote.act_name: Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation Act (1961)
heading: Interpretation of provisions
Mischief Rule
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of provisions - Mischief Rule - Applicability - Provisions u/Ss.16, 17, 19 in issue do not admit, of any ambiguity - Those are very clear provisions indicating nature and extent of liability of Corporation to pay insurance indemnity to depositors - Provisions also clearly provide meaning and scope of terminology "depositors" - No interpretation either by resort to verbal semantics or by invitation to refer to legislative intent by pressing Mischief Rule, permissible. 

In instant case petitioners are credit societies registered under Maharashtra co-operative Societies Act, 1960. They had questioned interpretation adopted by Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation (DICGC) in relation to provisions contained in Ss.16(1), 19, 21(2)(a) and (b) of the Act and proviso to sub-sec.10C of S.43A of Act 1949.

Aforesaid provisions deal with liability of DICGC in respect of insured deposits, manner of payment by corporation in case of winding up of insured banks.

Court opined that provisions in issue do not admit of any ambiguity. The DICGC, in terms of Section 16(1) of the said Act, is no doubt liable to pay 'every depositor of that bank an amount equal to the amount due to him in respect of his deposit' in that bank when order of liquidation or winding up of such bank is made. The second proviso to Section 16(1) of the said Act, however, limits the liability in that the 'total amount' payable by DICGC 'to any one depositor in respect of his deposit in that bank in the same capacity and in the same right' upto Rs.1,00,000/-. This means that if the deposits held by a depositor in the insured bank as on the date of winding up or liquidation is less than or upto Rs.1,00,000/-, then such depositor is entitled to avail insurance indemnity upto the entire extent of his deposit. However, if the deposits held exceed Rs.1,00,000/- in the same capacity and in the same right, then the insurance indemnity shall extend upto Rs.1,00,000/- only. Petitioners took plea that correct interpretation would require the DICGC to treat each of the numerous small investors /depositors who have invested / deposited amounts with the Petitioner Societies as 'one unit each'. Thereby, the DICGC would be bound to indemnify each such small investor / depositor to extent of Rs.1,00,000/- each.

However, such interpretation would be inconsistent with objective of the Act. The phraseology employed in the second proviso like 'any one depositor', 'in respect of his deposit' and 'in the same capacity and in the same right' clarifies the position that the DICGC is no way concerned with the investors or depositors who may have invested or deposited with the Petitioners. The Petitioners, are no doubt depositors with the insured bank, which in the present case is the Respondent No. 6. Therefore, in view of the liquidation of Respondent No. 6 bank, the DICGC is liable to offer insurance indemnity to the Petitioners to the extent of Rs.1,00,000/-. There is no further obligation towards depositors / investors who may have made deposits / investments with the Petitioners. In the light of the clear provisions, it is futile to suggest any other interpretation either by resort to verbal semantics or by invitation to refer to the legislative intent and on the said basis press the mischief rule of interpretation Mere circumstances that premium is levied upon entire body of deposits, or that some hardship may occasion in individual cases, are not strictly speaking relevant to statutory interpretation.	 [Para 13,15,16,17,18,19]

heading: Premises hired for war purposes in the year 1942
HeadNote.description:
Premises hired for war purposes in the year 1942 - Refusal to de-hire premises - Government entitled to claim protection of Rent Act - Held refusal to de-hire premises was not violative of Art. 14 of the Constitution on ground of arbitrariness.

Words and phrases - Distinction between 'hiring' and 'requisitioning of premises.

In the instant case premises were originally hired for war purposes but the fact remains that by virtue of the said agreement, the relationship of landlord and tenant is created and the State is entitled to claim protection of the Bombay Rent Act. It cannot be said that the State has acted arbitrarily or unreasonably. If the possession of the State Government is protected by the Bombay Rent Act, its refusal to de-hire the premises cannot be said to be violative of article 14. Government has framed a policy for de-hiring of the premises. The policy adheres to the well known principles of seniority.  Simply because the petitioner's number is not likely to reach in near future, the policy cannot be branded as unreasonable.  [Para 10]

Compulsory letting under rule 81 is not the same as requisitioning under rule 75-A. If the term 'requisition' has acquired any technical meaning during the two world-wars, it has been used in the sense of taking possession of property for the purpose of the State. or for such purposes as may be specified in the Statute authorising a public servant to take possession of private property for a specified purpose for a period in contra-distinction to acquisition of property by which title to the property gets transferred from the individual to the State or to a public body for whose benefit the property is acquired. In 'requisition' the property dealt with is not acquired by the State but is taken out of the control of the owner for the time being for certain specified purposes. Even for this limited purpose, however, the owner becomes entitled to compensation, because 'requisition' of the property amounts atleast to temporary deprivation of the property.  [Para 7]

Letting out is intended to be a permanent arrangement while requisition is intended to be only a temporary arrangement.  [Para 8]

heading: Letting of accommodation
Power of legislature
HeadNote.description:
Letting of accommodation - Power of legislature - Legislature has power to regulate or control the letting of accommodation or the rent to be charged on letting - Power to regulate letting is different than the power to requisition any premises - R.81 relates to power of controlling letting of premises; such power of regulation includes the power of directing letting of any premises to specified person or persons or classes of persons or in specified circumstances.

There is a clear distinction between the power of requisition which was conferred under Rule 75-A and the power of control of letting conferred under Rule 81 of the Defence of India Rules. Rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules enabled the provincial government to requisition any property when it was necessary or expedient so to do for securing the defence of British India, public safety, the maintenance of public order or efficient prosecution of the war or for maintaining supplies and services essential to the life of the community. Clause (bb) of Rule 81 on the other hand provided for regulating the letting and sub-letting any accommodation and controlling of the rents of such accommodation. In the circumstances mentioned in the Rule, the government could compel a person to let any premises either generally or to any specified persons and also control the rent at which the premises were let either generally or when let to specified persons or in specified circumstances. Object and purposes of Rule 75-A and Rule 81 were different. While Rule 75-A authorised the government to requisition any premises for securing the defence of British India, public safety or other purpose mentioned in the rule, Rule 81 permitted the government to control letting or sub-letting of the premises and the rents either generally or for specified persons or in specified circumstances. Power under Rule 81 was similar to the power of control of housing accommodation and prevention of any unreasonable increase in the rent as also accommodation being required to be made available instead of being kept unused. It may be noted that under Rule 81, government could require the accommodation to be let either generally or to specified person or persons or classes of persons and not only to the government while Rule 75-A only permitted the accommodation to be requisitioned for government purposes. The requisitioning of the premises may come to an end when the purpose for which the premises which are requisitioned ceases to exist, while the letting made to any person in persuance of Rule 81 may continue till the contract continued or the Rule existed or any other protection granted to a tenant under any other Act (such as any Rent Control Act) continued.  [Para 7]

Constitutional validity of the several Rent Control Acts passed by legislatures of different States has been upheld. It therefore cannot be contended that the legislature has no power to regulate or control the letting of the accommodation or the rent to be charged on letting. Power to regulate letting is different than the power to requisitioning any premises. Rule 81 of the Defence of India Rules relates to the power of controlling letting of premises; such power of regulation includes the power directing letting of any premises to specified person or persons or classes of persons or in specified circumstances.  [Para 8]

heading: Release of
HeadNote.description: Requisitioned Land (Continuance of Powers) Act (1947), Ss.3, 4 - Requisition made under R.75-A - Release of - A requisition made under R.75-A and continued under later enactments could not be released without an order in writing, specifying the person to whom possession is to be given - Held, requisition subsists for want of a release order. 1980 VJ (S.C.) 340 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Requisition made under R.75A
HeadNote.description: Requisition made under R.75A - Petitioners accepted as direct tenants by Trust - Petitioners who were successors in interest cannot stand on higher footing - Held, if their predecessor in interest were wearing sandals of leather, the petitioners cannot pretend to wear sandals of gold. 1979(82) B.L.R. 19 and AIR 1962 SC 247 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

heading: Requisition of land made under R.75-A
HeadNote.description:
Requisition of land made under R.75-A - Right of landlord to create a direct tenancy, not suspended merely because an order of requisition is made - Right of landlord flows from his right of ownership.

Right of a landlord to let out his premises is a right which flows from his right of ownership. This right is not extinguished merely because his property is requisitioned.

Requisitioning of a property released leads to a temporary deprivation of the landlord from using and possessing his property but otherwise does not distract from his title. It is still open for him to accept a direct tenant whose right to use and possess the property may remain suspended during the period of requisition if he is a person other than a Government allottee. That is however, different than saying that the right of the landlord, to create a direct tenancy is curtailed or suspended. A situation can be countenanced where an owner may voluntary choose to confer a direct tenancy right upon a Government allottee and if this happens without compulsion, the State Govt. allottee who is already in use and occupation may be vested with the rights and protections available to a tenant.  AIR 1984 SC 866 - Ref to.	 [Para 10,11]

heading: Distinction between
HeadNote.description:
Letting and requisition of premises - Distinction between - Letting out is intended to be a permanent arrangement, while requisition is intended to be a temporary arrangement.

Rule 81 confers powers on the Government to regulate the letting and sub-letting of any accommodation or class of accommodation as well as control of the rents.  Plain reading of the aforesaid rule shows that there exists element of compulsion in hiring the premises of the landlords and the Government was vested with powers for regulating general control of industry and the relevant provisions relating to the control of rents as contained in clause (bb) of Rule 81.  In the case of compulsory letting, there is a creation of relationship of landlord and tenant even though element of compulsion is inherent in such arrangement.  On the other hand, in requisition the properties are taken out of the control of the owner for the time being for certain specified purpose, subject to payment of compensation.  Thus, it is clear that letting out is intended to be a permanent arrangement, while requisition is intended to be only a temporary arrangement.(1994) 4 SCC 192 - Followed.	   [Para 23]

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Additional floor space/Transferable Development Rights (TDR) - Grant of - Development control Regulation (DCR) are traceable to law forming part of S.22(m) of MRTP Act - Providing or imposing any condition, contrary to it, while granting Development Certificate of land, is illegal and would not be binding on parties - Said condition cannot come to aid of Municipal Corporation to deny statutory rights of petitioner-developer - Petitioner agreed to develop amenity and hand it over to corporation free of costs in lieu of TDR - Permission/commencement certificate not suggesting that there was convention of plot from industrial Zone to residential Zone - Even assuming that there was such conversion, that by itself cannot be valid ground/reason for denying petitioner of his statutory right to claim additional TDR after he complies with Cl.6 of Appendix 'W' of "DCR".			(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 20, 22, 23)

heading: Resolution
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Resolution - Challenge to - Agenda in General Body Meeting of Corporation to consider subject of alignment of 18 meters road passing through particular survey number - Resolution passed was including policy matter of further modification of Development Control Rules (1967) - Procedure envisaged under provision was not followed - In absence of specific agenda in this regard it was not open to General Body to examine policy matters - Corporation on basis of resolution issued advertisement, submitted proposal for minor modification - Part of impugned resolutions is liable to be quashed and set aside - Ordered accordingly. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Sanctioned plan
Modification of
HeadNote.description:
Sanctioned plan - Modification of - Methods.

The scheme of the Act gives importance to the implementation of the sanctioned plan as it is and it is only in certain contingencies that the provision thereunder is permitted to be modified, and that too after following the necessary procedure made in that behalf.  [Para 46]

There are only two methods by which modifications of the final Development Plan can be brought about. One is where the proposal is such that it will not change the character of the Development Plan, which is known as minor modification and for which the procedure is laid down under Section 37 of the Act. The other is where the modification is of a substantial nature which is defined under Section 22A of the Act. In that case the procedure as laid down under Section 29 is required to be followed. There is also one more analogous provision though it is slightly different i.e. the one provided under Section 50 of the Act, for deletion of the reservation where the appropriate authority (other than the planning authority) no longer requires the designated land for the particular public purpose, and seeks deletion of the reservation thereon.  [Para 47]

heading: Formulation of plan
HeadNote.description:
Formulation of plan - One has to implement it as it is - It is only in rarest of rare cases departure can be justified - No exclusive power given to the State Government, or to the planning authority, or to the Chief Minister to bring about any modification, deletion or de-reservation, and certainly not by a resort to any of the D.C. Rules. (Paras 146, 152)

When the gazette notification is published, and the public notice in the local newspapers is published under Section 29 (or under Section 37) it must briefly set out the reasons as to why the particular modification is being proposed. Since Section 29 provides for publishing a notice in the 'local newspapers', we adopt the methodology of Section 6 (2) of the L.A. Act is to be adopted and it is expected that the notice shall be published atleast in two daily newspapers circulating in the locality, out of which atleast one shall be in the regional language. The notice it expected to be published in the newspapers with wide circulation and at prominent place therein.  [Para 153]

heading: Petrol station
HeadNote.description: Petrol station - Object of DCR 2.6 - Held, the underlying object of DCR 2.6 is to ensure that the operation of a petrol filling station does not pose a danger to public safety - The public interest is sought to be protected by stipulating a minimum distance between the nearest gate of a specified establishment and the petrol station - The distance has to be measured from the nearest gate.			(Para 7)

heading: Power of relaxation
HeadNote.description:
Discretionary powers of Municipal Commissioner - Powers have to be exercised in conformity with intent and spirit of the Rules - Power of relaxation - Held, the power of relaxation is conditioned by Public convenience and welfare - Relaxation cannot be allowed indiscriminately - Else a relaxation will swallow the rule - Such relaxations are not intended to subserve the interest of developers but to answer a genuine and pressing public need.

The discretionary powers of the Municipal Commissioner have to be exercised in conformity with the intent and spirit of the Rules. Clauses (i), (ii) and (iii) are indicative of the nature of the power. Clause (i) envisages a situation of an error in an order, requirement or decision. Clause (ii) deals with exceptional cases, or cases of doubt or controversy. Clause (iii), applies where the layout on the ground varies with the layout in the Development Plan. Sub-clause (v) empowers the Commissioner to authorise the operational construction of a public service building or the use of an undertaking only for public utility purposes where he finds these to be reasonably necessary for public convenience and welfare, even if it is not permitted in any land use classification. The existence of a reasonable necessity, founded in public convenience and welfare is the touchstone. The regulations are made in the interests of planned development and are based on public interest. The power of relaxation is conditioned by public convenience and welfare. Relaxations cannot be allowed indiscriminately. Else a relaxation will swallow the rule. Such relaxations are not intended to subserve the interests of developers but to answer a genuine and pressing public need. Unfortunately this is lost sight of and relaxations are granted to obviate compliance with the intent and spirit of development rules. That is a perversion of planning. No law can permit it. Judicial interpretation cannot countenance it.  [Para 10]

heading: Environment (Protection) Act (1986), S.3
HeadNote.description: Environment (Protection) Act (1986), S.3 - Environment Protection Rules (1986), R.5(3)(d) - Coastal Regulation Zone Notification dt.19.2.1991 - Permission to develop land - Land in coastal Regulation Zone II - Notification freezes building activity in area falling under CRZ-II to the law prevalent and in force as on 19.2.1991 - Draft Rules of 1989 would not, therefore apply as they were not existing law in force and prevalent as on 19.2.91, since new Regulations came in force on 20/3/1991 - Plea that under S.46 Planning Authority has to take into consideration 1989 Regulations is devoid of merits.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Norm of permissible FSI
HeadNote.description: Norm of permissible FSI - Is 1.33 but FSI permitted may be allowed to be exceeded in respect of luxury hotels with previous approval of Government.	(Para 10)

heading: Development of land
Discretion of Government
HeadNote.description: Development of land - Grant of additional FSI - Discretion of Government - Government to exercise discretionary power in consonance with Art.14 of Constitution and not arbitrarily.			(Para 12)

heading: Deemed grant
HeadNote.description: Deemed grant - Is permissible only if permission applied is strictly in conformity with rules - Grant of additional FSI requested was under consideration of authorities - Competent Authority had not considered the plans submitted by applicant - Applicant is not entitled to deemed grant - Further it is for the Government to decide grant of additional FSI and Court cannot direct Government to sanction additional FSI as was granted to other hotels - Court can only direct that Government in exercise of its discretion will take into consideration relevant material including fact that other applicants were granted additional FSI for hotels in the past.		(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Shifting of reservation
HeadNote.description:
Shifting of reservation - Procedure.

The shifting of the reservation has to be without altering the size of the area under reservation. Besides it is permissible only on three conditions namely, that (1) it cannot be beyond 200 metres of the original location in the Development Plan, (2) it has to be within the holding of the owner in which the reservation is located, and (3) the alternative location ought to have a similar access and land level as the original location. Obviously the shifting of the reservation to a far off place could not be justified under D.C. rule 13.5.  [Para 49]

heading: R.6.6.2.2. does not deal with shifting of reservation from one plot to another which is covered under R.13.5
HeadNote.description: R.6.6.2.2. does not deal with shifting of reservation from one plot to another which is covered under R.13.5 - R.6.6.2.2 has no application to shifting of reservation at all. (Para 79)

heading: Eviction petition on ground of bona fide requirement
HeadNote.description:
Eviction petition on ground of bona fide requirement - Delay in filing leave to defend - Rejection of application for leave to contest - Cannot be allowed by invoking provisions of Limitation Act.

In the instant case, the landlord filed an eviction petition under Section 14(1)(e) of the Delhi Rent Control Act, 1958 before the Rent Controller, for eviction of the Tenant. After filing of the eviction proceeding, summons was issued in compliance with Section 25(3)(a) of the Act to the tenant/respondent to appear before the Rent Controller on a specified date for the purpose of defending the eviction proceeding. The tenant/respondent filed an affidavit by way of an application praying for leave to defend the eviction proceeding after delay of 8 days from the date of service of notice upon him. By an order dated 28th of February, 2001, the Affidavit (the application for leave to defend) was rejected by the Additional Rent Controller as it was filed 8 days beyond the date mentioned in the summons. Since there was a delay of 8 days, Additional Rent Controller held that under the Act, he was not conferred with any power to condone the delay in filing such affidavit. Since the prayer for leave to defend the proceeding was rejected as a follow up action, an eviction order was passed by the Additional Rent Controller, Delhi in favour of the landlord in compliance with sub-section (4) of Section 25-B of the Act.

Held that, order of Rent controller was not justified. From a careful perusal of sub-section (4) of Section 25-B of the Rent Act, it would be clearly evident that the tenant shall not be permitted to contest the prayer for eviction unless he files an affidavit before the Controller stating the ground on which he seeks to contest the application for eviction and obtains leave from the Controller. This Section also clearly indicates that in default of his appearance in compliance with the summons or his obtaining such leave, the statement made by the landlord in the eviction proceeding shall be deemed to be admitted by the tenant and the landlord shall be entitled to an order for eviction on the ground mentioned in the eviction petition. Also, R.23 of Delhi Rent Control Rules (1959) cannot be applied, because of applicability of Section 25-B, which is a special code and specific procedure for eviction of a tenant by a landlord on the ground of bona fide requirement, and it cannot be said that in view of Rule 23 of the Rules, the provisions of the Civil P.C. can be applied in the present case and, therefore, the High Court had acted illegally and with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction in setting aside the order of eviction and in allowing the affidavit filed by the tenant for the purpose of defending the proceedings for eviction. Thus, the High Court has acted illegally and with material irregularity in the exercise of its jurisdiction in affirming the order of the Additional Rent Controller whereby the Additional Rent Controller had allowed the application for setting aside the order of eviction and restored the application for leave to contest the eviction proceeding when such power, in our view, was not conferred on the Rent Controller to entertain such an application filed by the tenant/respondent. There is another aspect of this matter. It is difficult to understand how an application for leave to contest having been rejected, may be on the ground of delay, could be allowed when it is not disputed by the tenant respondent that no application for condonation of delay could be entertained by the Rent Controller as the provisions of the Limitation Act, 1963 could not be attracted. Consequently, the order of eviction passed by the Additional Rent Controller stands restored, the impugned order of the High Court is set aside and the application filed by the landlord under Section 14(1)(e) of the Act stands allowed.  [Para 14,22,25,29,32]

heading: Bonafide requirement of landlord
HeadNote.description:
Bonafide requirement of landlord - Leave to defend sought by tenant - Fact that landlord is doing business from various other premises cannot foreclose his right to seek eviction from tenanted premises so long as he intends to use them for his own business.
(1983) 1 SCC 301 Rel. on. 	(Para 5)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
Against public servants
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.120B, 420 - Prevention of Corruption Act (1988), S.13(1)(d) - Quashing of proceedings - Against public servants - For offence under Prevention of Corruption Act and IPC committed in course of same transaction - Claim for - On ground that prior consent of State Govt. u/S.6 of Delhi Special Police Establishment (Amendment) Act (2006), is not taken - Initially public servants were not named in FIR - Their names surfaced during investigation - Thereafter, post-facto consent was given by State Govt. u/S. 6 of 2006 Act to authorities to investigate public servants - No pleadings by public servants with regard to prejudice caused to them on account of non-obtaining of prior consent u/S.6 - Proceedings cannot be quashed against public servants. (Paras 14, 19, 21)

heading: Workman
HeadNote.description: Workman - Driver employed by a school - Being skilled person, he would be a 'workman' for the purpose of Industrial Disputes Act.	(Para 19)

heading: Retrenchment of employee
Legality
HeadNote.description: Retrenchment of employee - Without prior approval of Director of Education - Legality - Held, S.8(2) is a procedural safeguard to employees against arbitrary and unreasonable termination - State Legislature has competently enacted such a provision - Decision of DB of Delhi HC striking down said S.8(2) is erroneous and based on misconstruction of TMA Pai Foundation [2013 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 177] - True purport of Katra Education Society [AIR 1966 SC 1307] not appreciated by DB - In any case, S.8(2) was struck down by DB after the notice of retrenchment in instant case - Therefore, compliance with S.8(2) was necessary by management on relevant date - Impugned retrenchment not sustainable.  113(2004) DLT 703 (DB) Held Not Good Law. 2013 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 177, AIR 1966 SC 1423, 2008 ALL SCR 643 Ref. to. 	(Paras 30, 31, 33, 34, 35, 37)

heading: Manufacturing of drugs
HeadNote.description:
Manufacturing of drugs - Exemption from operation of all or any of provisions of DPCO, 1987 - True construction of Para 28 of DPCO, 1987 read with exemption notification dt.28th Feb., 1992 - Held, for an exemption notification it is 'manufacture' and not 'sale' which is relevant.

From bare perusal of paragraph 28 of DPCO, 1987 it is clear that the exemption relates to drug manufacturing units or classes of such units. The very exemption order which has also been set out by us (supra) again refers only to bulk drugs and formulations based thereupon which are "manufactured" by the company. Further, a reading of the guidelines of 1989 also makes it clear that the exemption only relates to manufacture and has no reference to sale whatsoever.  [Para 8]

It will be noticed that the reference is to the date of commencement of commercial production of a bulk drug which has reference to manufacture alone. However, reference made to sub-clause (viii) of the guidelines of 1989 in order to argue that after the expiry of the period of exemption, the manufacturer has to submit an application for fixation of the price of a bulk drug under the provisions of the DPCO.	 [Para 9]

Sub-clause (viii) of Guidelines of 1989 cannot be read in isolation but must be read as a part of the entire scheme of the guidelines. All that sub-clause (viii) says is that after the period of exemption, which is after the period which has reference to manufacture and not sale of goods, such goods as are manufactured after the exemption will be subject to the drill of sub-clause (viii). Read in this light, arguments based on this sub-clause, rejected.  [Para 10]

It can be seen that the issue that arose in the Glaxosmithkline case [(2014) 2 SCC 753] was completely different from the issue that arose in Ranbaxy's case [(2008) 7 SCC 502] and the present case. Ranbaxy's case and the present case are directly concerned only with an exemption notification, and not a notification for fixation of price. Also, what is relevant for an exemption notification is the manufacture of drugs, whereas what is relevant for a price fixation notification relates to sale and not manufacture. Obviously, therefore, the Glaxosmithkline decision would have no relevance to the facts of the present case (2008) 7 SCC 502 Rel. on. (2014) 2 SCC 753 Dist.  [Para 13]

HeadNote.act_name: Directives on Recruitment of Junior Commissioned Officers and Other Ranks (2014)
heading: Service in Army
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Service in Army - Rejection of candidature on ground of candidate having been held guilty by Juvenile Board - Not justified - One of objects of JJ Act of 2000 is to rehabilitate juvenile/child in conflict with law - By virtue of S.19(1) of JJ Act such disqualification has been specifically removed and non obstante clause used therein would override Directive no.33 (d) - Direction issued to reconsider candidature of petitioner on his own merits. 	(Paras 10, 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Dock Workers (Safety Health and Welfare) Act (1966)
heading: Death of worker while doing unloading work in the docks
HeadNote.description: Death of worker while doing unloading work in the docks - Complaint against company and its Managing Director - MD aged 80 years old and unable to walk and was under bed rest - Exempted from personal appearance - He demonstrated his bona fides by depositing Rs.1 lakh in court - Further amount of Rs.1,66,290/- was paid by Bombay Stevedores Association - Held in peculiar facts and circumstances High Court can in its inherent powers absolve petitioner from offences by making available monetary sum deposited to heirs and legal representatives of deceased.	(Para 7)

heading: Mediation process
Confidentiality
HeadNote.description: Mediation process - Confidentiality - In order to reach a settlement, parties may make such statements in mediation proceedings which otherwise they would not have made in court of law - Such statements ought not to be used against makers, if mediation fails and matter reaches to court - Confidentiality is essential element of mediation. (2010) 8 SCC 24, (2011) 1 SCC 466, 2018 ALL SCR 295 Ref.to.	(Para 24)

heading: Mediation process
Confidentiality
HeadNote.description: Mediation process - Confidentiality - In suits for custody and guardianship, principles of confidentiality are not strictly adhered to - Because, such issues are resolved on touchstone of "best interest of child" - Reports of Counsellor as to background of child or any record of interaction with child, may assist court in determining welfare of child - Such records can be presented in court - Not barred by confidentiality principle.	(Paras 25, 27, 28)

heading: Appointment of Counsellor
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Counsellor - By Committee of High Court - Not in conformity with S.6 of Family Courts Act - Yet it cannot be set aside - Said appointment was in complete knowledge of parties and with express acceptance of High Court - When paramount consideration is welfare of child, there cannot be undue reliance on technicality.	(Para 29)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description: Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch of MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - DCI found deficiencies on inspection - In ad interim order also this Court did not permit petitioner to admit students for 1st year of new session 2013-14 - Though ad interim order was not challenged, it cannot be reason for not granting reliefs at final stage on hearing of both parties. 	(Para 30)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description: Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch of MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - DCI found deficiencies on inspection - Communication invoked by respondent no. 1 invoking S.10-A (4) by which concerned parties were called upon for personal hearing to decide about renewal of permission - It means mode of personal hearing is not foreign - Submission that no such procedure is available under Act - Submission liable to be rejected. 			(Para 35)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description:
Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch to the MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - Ground that DCI found deficiencies on inspection - Whereas the earlier two batches were permitted admission on same infrastructure - Respondents are directed to reconsider action of non granting renewal.

In the instant case permission was granted to 1st and 2nd batch on basis of same infrastructure and material on which earlier two batches were granted permission. Right was curtailed without assigning any reasons for composite action. Decision taken as without considering legal rights of all concerned parties. Another facet of principles of natural is that merely because DCI is expert body, it is not sufficient and that itself does not empower them to pass unreasoned and unsupportive order. Deficiencies are not reason to discontinue important final year course of 1st batch and 2nd batch. Same reason cannot be reason for not admitting students of 3rd batch. Renewal of yearly permission cannot be equated to fresh initial permission. Submission that order is restricted to 3rd year new batch is self contradictory. Respondents are directed to reconsider action of non granting renewal.  		          		         [Para 36,37]

heading: Execution proceedings
HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.6 - Execution proceedings - Objection to execution of decree passed in suit for recovery of possession - On ground that suit u/S.6 of Specific Relief Act was barred by S.185 of Delhi Land Reforms (DLR) Act 1954 - Bar u/S.185 is applicable only when land is used for purpose of agriculture, horticulture or animal husbandry - Suit land has ceased to be agricultural in nature on date of institution of suit and was not being used for purposes contemplated by DLR Act - Land was not governed by DLR Act and bar u/S. 185 not attracted - Rejection of objection to execution of decree, proper.	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens (Amendment) Rules (2016)
heading: Suit for eviction of daughter-in-law
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction of daughter-in-law - Contention that suit is not maintainable as plaintiff-father in law had not made any request for maintenance u/S.4 of Senior Citizens Act - Held, Delhi Maintenance Rules (2016) entitle a senior citizen to seek eviction of his son, daughter or his legal heir on account of ill-treatment - Said Rules were framed in aid of protecting life and property of senior citizens and not in furtherance of S.4 of the Act - Therefore, claim for maintenance u/S.4 is not condition precedent for maintaining suit for eviction - Contention as to maintainability of suit, rejected. 	(Para 6)

heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description:
Scope of - Registration and its cancellation - All matters relating to registration and cancellation of designs are intended to be governed by the new Act and not the old Act - Old Act being completely repealed, all things done under old Act, after the enactment of new Act,will be governed by new Act.

The old Act of 1911 is repealed. As regards registration etc.. done under the old Act, sub-section (2) clearly lays down that it shall continue to be in force and have effect as if done under the corresponding provisions of the new Act.  This means that registration of the design must continue in force and have effect as a thing done under section 4 of the Act.  It is, therefore, clear that the intention of Parliament is that all things done under the old Act can only be continued to be in force and have effect as if made under the corresponding provision of the new Act.  The only exception made in section 48 is provided in sub-section (4) which provides that any proceeding pending in any Court at the commencement of the new Act may be continued in that Court as if the new Act had not been passed.  It is, therefore, clear that Parliament intended that all things done under the old Act, after the enactment of the new Act be governed only by the new Act, the old Act being completely repealed.

In particular, as regards the question of registration and its cancellation, the Statement of Objects and Reasons for the new Act throws light on the intention of Parliament to govern these matters according to the new Act of 2000.

It is obvious, that it was the avowed intent of Parliament to provide for new ground for cancellation of registration so as to include prior publication in any other country and also to bring about changes in the conditions for registration of designs vide clause 5.  It appears that it is the intention of Parliament to specifically consider the question of prior publication "on global basis instead of regional basis i.e. in India" vide clause 19.  It is therefore clear that it is the intention of Parliament that all matters pertaining to registration and its cancellations are intended to be governed by the new Act i.e. the Designs Act, 2000 and not the old Act i.e. the Designs Act, 1911.  (1995)3 SCC 709 - Followed. (1999)9 SCC 334 - Distinguished.   [Para 9,10]

heading: Injunction
Copying of design
HeadNote.description: Injunction - Copying of design - Washing machine of plaintiff having rectangular shape on one side and semi circular shape on other side - It makes product of plaintiff unique - Plaintiff has made out prima facie case of infringement of its statutory rights by defendant and also passing of - If injunction not granted plaintiff would be deprived of exclusive use of its novel and unique designs which were registered in 2009 - Defendant can manufacture and market products other than impugned product - No irrepairable injury would be caused to defendant - Injunction is liable to be granted. (Para 24)

heading: Copyright in designs
HeadNote.description: Copyright in designs - Plaintiffs designing and selling gold sheet articles of deities and religious symbols - Drawings created on computers claimed to be original artistic work of ownership of plaintiffs - Their Ex. Manager joining defendants as CEO around August 2010 - Defendants changing original designs of their articles and producing in gold plates articles of deities and religious symbols using their design - Cease and desist notice issued - Suit filed in 2011 - On comparing photographs and articles - Defendant's articles found to be substantial and material copies of plaintiff's artistic work - Held, plaintiff's work enjoys protection under Copyright Act - No culpable delay in approaching court - Interim injunction granted against defendants. (Paras 15, 16, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Copyright in 'design'
HeadNote.description: Copyright in 'design' - Cessation after 50 times reproduction - Scope and applicability of S.15(2) - Provision applies only to designs and not to artistic work - To ascertain 'design' shape or configuration of whole article is to be seen - Functional part of an article does not fall within definition of 'design' rather it is 'artistic work' - Drawings of plaintiff are skilled diagrams which serve only functional purpose - Such drawings are therefore not 'design' but 'artistic work'- S.15(2) would not apply - Copyright in said drawings will continue even after several reproduction and will not cease as per S.15(2). 2009 (39) PTC 609 (Bom) Rel. on. 			(Para 25)

heading: Suit against infringement
HeadNote.description: Patents Act (1970), Ss.10, 64 - Suit against infringement - Powers of court to examine validity of registration - Provisions under Designs Act and Patents Act are not comparable to Trade Marks Act in this regard - Said two Acts expressly permit the court to look into validity of registration - Even though TM Act has no such provision, it has Ss.28 and 31 which are not to be found in other two acts - Its provision cannot be interpreted with reference to a different act. (Paras 37, 38)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Infringement and passing off - Order of temporary injunction restraining infringement and directing inspection of defendant's premises - Appeal against - Plaintiff registered design of copper tube with bell-shaped end - Product of defendant apparently similar, having no material difference apparent to naked eyes - Mere difference as to smoothness or roughness of surface, not material - Defence raised as to lack of novelty and originality in design - Contention also raised that registered product has no exclusive functionality - However, plaintiff himself has not claimed any functionality in its design - Uniqueness claimed only in shape which makes it both original and novel - No material produced by defendant to show that such a design was already publicized when plaintiff sought registration - Defence that design is not novel, is contrary to defendant's own application for registration of same design - Plaintiff's registration was earlier in point of time - By the time defendant entered market, plaintiff's sale had crossed Rs.4.31 crore - Plaintiff alleged that defendants had earlier worked with him and had access to its manufacturing work - Prima facie case made out - Balance of convenience also tilts in favour of plaintiff - Order of injunction, proper. (2008) 10 SCC 657, (2014) 5 AIR Bom.C.R. 396, 2012(7) ALL MR 269 Ref. to. 2011 (5) Bom.C.R 456 Disting. 			(Paras 15, 16, 17, 19)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Orders cancelling registered designs passed by controller at Calcutta, challenged - Appeal be filed in Calcutta High Court and not to any other High Court on account of impact of cancellation in any particular State.

Section 51-A(1)(a) of Designs Act (1911) i.e. old Act very clearly provides that at any time after registration of the design, an application for cancellation of the registration could be made to the High Court on the grounds indicated therein. Section 51-A(1)(b) makes an exception and provides that within one year from the date of registration of the design, an application could be made for cancellation of the registration to the Controller on the grounds specified in Sub-clauses (i) and (ii) of Clause (a). Section 51-A(2) provides that an appeal from the order of the Controller would lie to the High Court. The cause of action for the instant proceedings is most certainly the cancellation of the registered design of the appellant which happened in the State of West Bengal which gave the Calcutta High Court the jurisdiction to deal with the matter. The Delhi High Court, erred in holding that the cause of action had arisen within its local jurisdiction, whereas the jurisdiction of the High Court was on account of the cancellation of registration of the design and not on account of the impact thereof in any particular State. Thus, the High Court was led into error in holding that the consequence of the cancellation gave jurisdiction to the Delhi High Court to entertain the suit, without considering in its proper perspective the provisions of Section 51-A of the 1911 Act in contrast to the provisions of Section 19 of the 2000 Act.  FAO Nos.131 and 132 of 2008, Dt.12-5-2008 (Delhi) - Reversed.  (1978)14 Delhi L.T. 132 - Expl. and Distinguished.   [Para 19,22,23,25]

Also, In contrast to the provisions of Section 51-A(1)(a) of the 1911 Act, Section 19(1) of the 2000 Act, which also deals with cancellation of registration, provides for a petition for cancellation of registration of a design to be filed before the Controller and not to the High Court. On a comparison of the two provisions of the two enactments, it will be obvious that under the 2000 Act the intention of the Legislature was that an application for cancellation of a design would lie to the Controller exclusively without the High Court having a parallel jurisdiction to entertain such matters. It is also very clear that all the appeals from any order of the Controller under Section 19 of the 2000 Act shall lie to the High Court. The basic difference, therefore, as was pointed out to the High Court and noticed by it, is that while under Section 19 of the 2000 Act an application for cancellation would have to be made to the Controller of Designs, under Section 51-A of the 1911 Act an application could be preferred either to the High Court or within one year from the date of registration to the Controller on the grounds specified under Sub-clauses (i) and (ii) of Clause (a) of Section 51-A(1). Under Section 19 of the 2000 Act the power of cancellation of the registration lies wholly with the Controller. On the other hand, an application for cancellation of a design could be made directly to the High Court under Section 51-A of the 1911 Act. Under the 2000 Act, the High Court would be entitled to assume jurisdiction only at the appellate stage, whereas under Section 51-A of the 1911 Act the High Court could itself directly cancel the registration. (Para 21)

heading: Infringement of design
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Infringement of design - Suit for - Defendant in turn challenging originality of plaintiff's registered design of footwear - Ground that it was developed from 'padukas' known since time immemorial - Though existence of padukas in ancient time cannot be denied, there are some modifications in plaintiff's product which are not made by any other person - Hence, plaintiff's design is certainly original u/s.2(g) - That apart plaintiff not claiming to be inventor of padukas and even exclusivity by way of patent right - Rather, claiming exclusivity in creative expression 'look and feel' i.e. use of strap in footwear - Defendant cannot be heard to contend that plaintiff's design is not new. (Paras 15 to 17)

heading: Article "capable of being made and sold separately"
HeadNote.description: Article "capable of being made and sold separately" - Cap of oil bottle - Not capable of registration under the Act - It has no identity in market by itself - Held, though it can be made separately and sold separately it is not having an independent life as an article of commerce - Cap of oil bottle is thus not article within meaning of S.2(a) of Designs Act - Injunction restraining other party from using it cannot be granted. 1995 R.P.C. 167 (HL) - Rel. on.	(Para 9)

heading: Infringement of registered design
HeadNote.description: Infringement of registered design - Defendant can show that registered design on basis of which suit is filed falls within prohibited categories - Then no injunction can be issued based on such registered designs - In such case there is no need for defendant to apply for cancellation of registered trade mark - Challenge can be made while defending suit. 	(Para 11)

heading: Prohibition on registration
HeadNote.description:
Prohibition on registration - Even if some parts of Whirlpool design having no value by themselves resemble parts of some other earlier machines - It cannot be said that design falls within ambit of phrase 'combination of known designs' - Thus design registered by petitioners is not hit by prohibition contained in section 4(c).

 'Design' means design of article capable of being made and sold separately. Phrase 'combination of known designs' referred in S.4(c) means combination of known articles. If 2 or more independent articles capable of being sold separately having distinctive designs are put together to create new design, same cannot be termed as original. Contention that design not significantly distinguishable from 'combination of known designs' cannot be registered. It means combination of known designs includes combination of parts of articles which by itself has no independent identity. Contention if accepted would mean rewriting section. It would be virtually impossible to register new design. Even if some parts of Whirlpool design having no value by themselves, resembles parts of some other earlier machines it cannot be said that designs fall within ambit of phrase 'combination of known designs'. Thus design registered by petitioners is not hit by prohibition contained in section 4(c).       [Para 15,17]

heading: Design
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Design - Registration of - Act contemplates that person can have one or more designs, which are similar to each other - However this privilege cannot be and is not meant to be available to person seeking registration of design similar to design registered in name of another person - Permitting it would defeat object of Act - Contention that if 2 designs with hardly any difference can be registered and sold by Whirlpool then design marketed by Videocon which is far more differentiating characters also can be registered and sold - Contention liable to be rejected.

Object of Act is to ensure effective protection to registered designs, to promote design activity and at same time to ensure that protection granted to such registration does not unnecessarily extend beyond reasonable period so as to stifle further innovations. Act contemplates that person can have one or more designs which are similar to each other. However this privilege is not availed by person seeking to register design similar to design registered in name of another person. Permitting it would run counter to very object for which Act of 2000 is enacted. 'Y' infringing design registered by 'X' cannot be equated with 'X' who is proprietor of 2 registered designs of similar nature. The above argument, therefore, cannot be accepted.          [Para 20,21]

heading: Registration
HeadNote.description: Registration - 2 designs registered by Whirlpool have hardly any differentiating characters between them - Contention that 2nd design registered by Whirlpool cannot be called as original in view of 1st registration - Held, even assuming that only 1 of designs registered is valid, still Videocon will have to show whether washing machine marketed by it is distinct from at least one of registered designs - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected. (Para 22)

heading: Infringement of registered design
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of registered design - Judging solely by eye - Merely by placing certain ornamentation, changing position of knobs or adding colour scheme, Videocon has not made any difference to its product - Shape and configuration of Whirlpool's machine can be clearly seen in machine marketed by Videocon - Videocon has infringed design registered by Whirlpool - Test applied by Trial Judge of judging solely by eye alone and conclusion that both machines are similar cannot be faulted - Case under S.22(1)(a) of Act is made out.
1996 PTC (16) Ref. to. (Para 26)

heading: Passing off
HeadNote.description:
Passing off - Videocon washing machine is same as machine marketed by Whirlpool - Merely because consumer of such goods are educated and have higher disposable income it cannot be said that there will be no deception - Contention that there is no question of confusion and when one makes conscious choice there is no passing off - Contention liable to be rejected.

For maintaining action of passing off it is not necessary that person must actively carry out misrepresentation. It is enough that instrument of deceit is created with full knowledge and intention and also no steps are taken to stop deceit. Action of passing off can be maintained if offender with full knowledge creates situation where consumer can be deceived is enough to sustain action under passing off.Once consumer is attracted to design, consumer can very well opt for cheaper and smaller version of designe when placed it in same showroom. Average consumer of washing machine need not necessarily make logical choice based on functionality and brand when decision is to be made based on aesthetic appeal.
1987 R.P.C. 303 Ref. to.       [Para 29,31]

heading: Passing off
HeadNote.description: Passing off - Design registered by Whirlpool has been a success and is in market since 2010 - No reason is placed on record how Videocon thought of designing washing machine with same distinctive shape in 2012 - It was to take advantage of popularity of design of Whirlpool washing machine - Hence, Videocon held, guity of passing off. (Para 32)

heading: Passing off
HeadNote.description: Passing off - Merely because Videocon is well known brand it is not that it will not indulge in passing off products of another well known brand - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected. (Para 33)

heading: Infringement of registered design
HeadNote.description: Infringement of registered design - Even on solely judging by eyes both Whirlpool and Videocon washing machines are found extremely similar - Prima facie case is made out that registered design of Whirlpool is infringed - Order of injunction against Videocon to be upheld. (Para 35)

heading: Registration of design
HeadNote.description: Registration of design - Once design is registered, owner of design gets exclusive right to apply it to any article in any class of articles in which design is registered. (Para 11)

heading: Cancellation of registration
HeadNote.description:
Cancellation of registration - Plaintiff alleging copying of design of washing machine by defendant - Photographs of machine placed on record - Contention of defendant that product is imitation of what was available in market since 1935 therefore registration is bound to be cancelled - Whereas perusal of design reveals its uniqueness - On basis of photographs, defendant's contention is liable to be rejected.
1996 PTC (16) 202 Ref. to. (Para 14)

heading: Copying of design
HeadNote.description: Copying of design - Registered proprietor has right to make application for registration of one or more designs in said class - Further if unregistered owner of design already registered becomes registered proprietor of design previously registered - Such person would get benefit of S.6 - Contention that plaintiff itself has registered 2 almost identical designs - Designs of plaintiff are not new and original hence not registrable - Contention is liable to be rejected. (Para 15)

heading: Copying of design
HeadNote.description: Copying of design - Contention that plaintiff's design is not new and it is imitation of design already published is rejected - Plaintiff's designs are undisputedly registered - Plaintiff is entitled to exclusive application of designs registered in its favour to its product. (Para 16)

heading: Copying of design
HeadNote.description:
Copying of design - Rectangular and semi circular shape of plaintiff's design is registered - Defendant has only used different colour and ornamentation but imitated basic shape and configuration - Plaintiff's rights were violated - Uniqueness of shape makes plaintiff's design fall in term 'capricious' - Defendant could not point out any washing machine prior in market having shape of plaintiff's design - Defendant has imitated striking and novel factor of plaintiff's design - Prima facie case of infringement of statutory rights of plaintiff is made out.
1996 PTC (16) 202 Ref. to. (Para 18)

heading: Copying of design
HeadNote.description:
Copying of design - Washing machine of plaintiff having rectangular shape on one side and semi circular shape on other side - It makes product of plaintiff unique - Plaintiff is manufacturing and selling product since September 2010 - Sale in tune of about Rs.308 crore of said product - Defendant after 2 years has introduced washing machine with similar features - Plaintiff has achieved substantial goodwill in market due to distinctive and novel design of product - Establishing goodwill gives cause of action on copying of plaintiff's goods by defendant.
1999(1) ALL MR 64, 1996 PTC (16) 202 Ref. to. (Para 21)

heading: Copying of design
HeadNote.description:
Copying of design - Defendant's washing machine is undisputedly imitation of plaintiff's product - Defendant is selling same for much lower price - Contention that high price product of plaintiff would be bought after making enquiry and satisfaction by consumer - Ability of consumer to discern is not necessarily related to economic status or social class - Contention in this regard is liable to be rejected.
1999(1) ALL MR 64, 1996 PTC (16) 202 Ref. to. (Paras 22, 23)

heading: Publication of design
HeadNote.description: Publication of design - Publication of design in magazine, constitutes its publication - Contention that merely because substantially similar designs are shown to have been published and goods produced or manufactured, they must be taken as not published at all - Contention not tenable. 1958 R.P.C. 411 and 50 R.P.C. 240 - Rel.on.(Para 12)

heading: Infringement of design
HeadNote.description: Infringement of design - Comparison between two products - Alleged infringement of design of plaintiff's copper tubes by defendants - Originality and novelty claimed in plaintiff's design is that one end of each tube has an expanded bell shape - Defence taken that curvature of bell-ending in plaintiff's product is 90 degrees whereas in defendant's product it is 45 degrees - Same is distinction without difference - Held, what is to be considered are broad and salient features - Microscopic examination of minute juxtaposed differences is impermissible - No meaningful distinction between the two products. (2015) 1 Bom CR 137 Rel. on. 			(Paras 9, 11, 24)

heading: Prayer for injunction
HeadNote.description: Infringement of design and passing of - Prayer for injunction - Alleged infringement of design of plaintiff's copper tubes by defendants - No meaningful distinction between the two products - Novelty and originality to plaintiff's product, is undeniable - No functionality demonstrated by either side nor does plaintiff claim any right to any functionality - Defendants failed to show any use by them or anybody else prior to plaintiff - Defendants' past association with plaintiff, is circumstance that weighs against defendants - Plaintiff also produced invoices and challans to prove that defendant's goods are available in Mumbai - More than prima facie case made out - Balance of convenience favours plaintiff - Irretrievable prejudice would be caused if injunction is refused - Injunction therefore granted. 			(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Sale of medicine
HeadNote.description: Sale of medicine - Maximum retail price not printed on the bottle - Offence under Para 20 stood established - Instead of three months of imprisonment, sentence of fine increased in view of fact that incident occurred 25 years back.	(Paras 15, 18, 19)

heading: Drugs price control
HeadNote.description:
Drugs (Prices Control) Order (1995), Para 12 - Drugs price control - Purport and intent of DPCOs - Concept of retention price, pool price and selling price is encompassed in DPCOs. 

The Drugs Prices Control Orders (DPCOs) have been framed under Section 3 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955. The said Act is referable to Article 39 (b) of the Constitution of India. The DPCOs provide a price control mechanism by which the Government seeks to control the prices of drugs so that the ultimate beneficiary is the consumer who then stands to get the drug in question at an affordable and reasonable price. The concept of the retention price, pool price and the selling price is, therefore, encompassed in the DPCOs. The DPCOs by the said price fixing mechanism, inter alia, provide for fixing the profit margins which a manufacturer would be entitled to. The said price fixation is done by controlling the prices of the bulk drug which is used in the formulation by the manufacturer. This was done, in the context of the present petition, by the method prescribed by under para 11 of the DPCO, 1979. The retail price fixed for a formulation allows a manufacturer a particular price at which he can buy the ingredient bulk drug. If he buys the drug at a lower price than the price allowed, he has to deposit in the DPEA the difference between the price allowed and the lower price at which he has bought the bulk drug. By this process, an equilibrium is sought to be struck by the Government so that the manufacturer gets the bulk drug at the controlled price resulting in the retail price of the bulk drug being controlled in a fashion so as to benefit the ultimate consumer.                          			                                                                                                                          [Para 17]

heading: Accrual of the amount
