HeadNote.description: Accrual of the amount - No adjudication process is involved - Liability accrues as soon as actual procurement price falls below allowed price of the bulk drug utilised in the formation.                 (Para 22)

heading: Accrual of obligation or incurring of liability
HeadNote.description: Accrual of obligation or incurring of liability - It is not necessary to quantify or determine liability. 			(Para 23)

heading: Bar of jurisdiction
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Bar of jurisdiction - Applicability - Suit for injunction on basis of possession - Issue as to which khasra no. disputed land falls in - Bar u/S.83 of Land Revenue Act not attracted - Civil court has jurisdiction.

The Land Revenue Act does not expressly bar the jurisdiction of the Civil Court in respect of boundary disputes. The boundary disputes are between two revenue estates and does not include the demarcation of the land of the parties. Section 83 of the Land Revenue Act bars the jurisdiction of the Civil Court in respect of: (a) the arrangement of area of the patwaris; (b) claims by any person to any of the offices mentioned in section 13 or 14 or to any emolument or fees appertaining to such office, or in respect of any injury caused by his exclusion therefrom, or claims by any person to nominate persons to such offices; (c) the formation of the record of rights or the preparation, signing, or attestation of any of the documents contained therein, or the preparation of the annual register. No such dispute arises for consideration in the present matter.

Still further, the suit is simpliciter for injunction based upon possession of the property. The said suit could be decided only by the Civil Court as there is no mechanism prescribed under the Land Revenue Act for grant of injunction in respect of disputes relating to possession. The Civil Court has plenary jurisdiction to entertain all disputes except in cases where the jurisdiction of the Civil Court is either expressly or impliedly barred in terms of Section 9 of the Code.

2019 SCC OnLine SC 1052 Rel. on. (Paras 18, 19)

heading: Dissolution of Council
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of Council - Show cause notice by Administrator - Reasonable opportunity of being heard - Adverse material of which notice is not given to councilors ought not be used in decision making - Recording of reasons is also unavoidable. 

The provision contained in Section 298 of the said Act also contemplates that the Council shall be given reasonable opportunity of being heard before its dissolution. The concept of 'reasonable opportunity' is by now well established. One of the facets of such 'reasonable opportunity' would be that the party which is proposed to be proceeded against, has to be furnished with all the adverse material, upon which reliance is proposed to be placed for the purposes of arriving at the impugned decision. Unless the party is made known to the adverse material proposed to be used against it, the party would be deprived of reasonable opportunity to show cause against the same or to explain the same. Negatively stated that this principle means and implies that no adverse material of which the party has been given no notice ought to be used by the decision maker in making the impugned decision. In the present case, as shall be demonstrated hereafter, in making the impugned order, the Administrator has indeed made reference to and relied upon some adverse material against the Councillors and the Council, without the Councillors or the Council having effective opportunity to meet with the same. The facts constituting gravamen of charge have to be communicated. It follows as a necessary corollary therefrom that what has not been communicated or not relied on in the show cause notice as a ground providing reason for the proposed removal cannot be relied upon as furnishing basis for the order of removal. The person proceeded against, has to be made aware of the precise charge which is required to meet and therefore he must be apprised of the exact content of the abuse of power attributed to him. The authority taking the decision must apply its mind also to the explanation furnished by the person proceeded against and this must appear from the order made.          [Para 15,20]

The requirement of recording reasons is also one of the facets of natural justice. Reason is the very life of law. When the reason of law once ceases, the law itself generally ceases, such is the significance of the reasoning in any rule of law. Giving reasons furthers the cause of justice as well as avoid uncertainty and helps in observance of law of precedent. When reasons are announced and can be weighed, the public can have assurance that the process of correction is in place and working . Reasons for an order would ensure and enhance public confidence and would provide due satisfaction to the consumer of justice under our justice dispensation system.

The Council or the Councillors are also required to respond to show cause notice under Section 298 of the said Act with utmost despatch and seriousness. In matters of this nature, a Council or councillors are not expected to adopt any dilatory approach.         [Para 23,24]

HeadNote.act_name: District Transport Officers (Motor Vehicles Department) Departmental Examination Rules (1984)
heading: Promotion
HeadNote.description: Promotion - Passing of departmental examination by District Transport Officer (DTO) within period of 2 years and within 3 chances, is condition precedent - While counting 'three chances' exam for which DTO neither applied nor appeared cannot be considered - Term 'within three chances' in Rule 4(3) means within three chances 'availed of' by candidate/District Transport Officer and not within three opportunities/chance provided under Rule 7.			(Paras 20, 21, 22, 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Dock Workers (Safety Health and Welfare) Act (1986)
heading: Accidental death of dock worker
HeadNote.description: Accidental death of dock worker - Liability of employer or contractor - Prosecution for failure to provide safety measures - Accident occurred while loading containers from ship - Respondents-company engaged in activities of loading and unloading ships only - Workers provided to it by Dock Yard Labour Board - Said Board was responsible for making wages, levy, welfare funds to workers - Respondent not making payment to workers directly but only through said Board - Hence, liability of providing safety measures was of Board and not of Respondent - Acquittal of respondent therefore, proper. (Paras 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Dock Workers (Regulation of Employment) (Inapplicability of Major Ports) Act (1997)
heading: Invocation of
Distinguished.	 [Para 14]
HeadNote.description:
Doctrine of promissory estoppel - Invocation of - In order to invoke the principle of promissory estoppel, it is necessary that the Government or any statutory authority should make a promise knowing or intending that it would be acted upon by the promisee or in fact the promisee acting in reliance on it has altered its position and in such a situation the Government or the statutory authority would be held bound by the promise and the promise would be enforceable as against the Government at the instance of promisee, notwithstanding that there is no consideration for the promise and the promise is not recorded in the form of a formal contract.

In the present case, the resolution to provide compassionate employment to the dependants of gangworkers who were declared as surplus, again it may be stated at the cost of repetition, was subject to the said dependants fulfilling the required conditions of the Recruitment Rules and in such a situation, the petitioner/s cannot compel the respondent-M.P.T. on the principle of promissory estoppel to follow the said resolution. In order to invoke the principle of promissory estoppel it is necessary that the Government or any statutory authority should make a promise knowing or intending that it would be acted upon by the promisee or in fact the promisee acting in reliance on it has altered its position and in such a situation the Government or the statutory authority would be held bound by the promise and the promise would be enforceable as against the Government at the instance of the promisee, notwithstanding that there is no consideration for the promise and the promise is not recorded in the form of a formal contract.  It may be stated that the MDLB upon persistent requests made on behalf of the petitioner/s had taken the said Resolution and later on had called many of them for the interviews to fill in certain vacancies which ultimately did not arise. At no stage have the petitioner/s altered their position pursuant to the said Resolution and/or after having been called for the said interview and in such a situation the doctrine of promissory estoppel based on the said Resolution would not be applicable to the case of the petitioner/s.  (2004)6 SCC 465 - Distinguished.	 [Para 14]

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description:
Copy of test reports of samples - Petition for - Offence committed under NDPS Act - Samples also taken by authorised officer under the provisions of NDPS Act - Test reports cannot be sought under the provision of Act of 1940 - S.25 of 1940 Act would be attracted only when the action is taken under that Act, not otherwise - Contention that by virtue of S.80 of NDPS Act reports can be sought even under provisions of 1940 Act, not tenable. 

In the instant case the petitioner requested for a copy of test reports of samples taken by Authorised Officer under S.25 (2) of Drugs and Cosmetics Act. However the offence in question was committed under NDPS Act. Held, the requirement of furnishing one copy of the report of the Government Analyst to a person from whom the sample is collected under Section 25(2), is in respect of the samples collected in exercise of the powers under Chapter-IV of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act of 1940. That is amply clear from sub-section (1) of Section 25 which refers to Section 23(4) of the Act of 1940. Section 23 in turn opens with the expression that where an inspector takes any sample of a drug or cosmetic under that chapter of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act. This pre-supposes that the provisions of Section 25 will be attracted only in respect of action taken by the Inspector appointed under the Act of 1940; and which action is in exercise of powers thereunder and not otherwise. The question of issuing writ directing respondent authority to furnish one copy of the Government Analyst report to the petitioner under Drugs and Cosmetics Act does not arise.

Section 80 of the NDPS Act envisages that the provisions in that Act or the rules made thereunder shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of the Act of 1940 or the rules made thereunder. The question of applicability of S.25 of 1940 Act, even in a case under NDPS Act, may arise in a case where the collection of samples was by the Inspector appointed under that Act. That is not the case. This interpretation cannot be said to be in derogation of the provisions of the Act of 1940. The provisions in section 80 of the NDPS Act cannot be made the basis to issue direction to the authorised officer under the NDPS Act to comply with the procedure provided in the Act of 1940.  [Para 2,3,4]

heading: Possession of contraband
Legality
HeadNote.description: Possession of contraband - Conviction under Ss.15, 22 and 25 of NDPS Act and S.18(c) of Drugs and Cosmetics Act - Legality - Poppy straw weighing more than 100 kg and Nitrosun tablets were recovered from shop of accused - Accused and his servant were present at time of raid - No explanation given by them at time of seizure or even after seizure - No other article kept in shop for sale - Circumstances sufficiently show knowledge and participation of accused in possession of contraband - Seizure and sampling of poppy straw were properly done and proved - It was in commercial quantity and offence is punishable u/s.15 - However, as regards Nitrosun tablets i.e. psychotropic substance, sampling was not done properly and evidence in that regard is not convincing - Hence, conviction u/s.22 of NDPS Act and u/s.18(c) of Drugs and Cosmetics Act, improper - There is no question of conviction u/s.25 of NDPS Act also which provides for penalty when premises is allowed to be used by others. 			(Paras 32, 33, 38, 39, 41, 42)

heading: Anticipatory bail
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Anticipatory bail - Petition for - Offence of manufacturing of spurious drugs and supply thereof - Offence is not only against an individual but against public at large - Custodial interrogation of petitioners is required - Not a case where discretion should be exercised in favour of accused - Therefore, petition for anticipatory bail, dismissed. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Quashing of proceedings - Manufacturing of substandard drug - Applicant manufacturer of drug replied to show cause notice on 31.8.2015 - Complaint however filed by drug inspector on 4.3.2016 - Though Drug Inspector knew expiry date of drug as on 5/2016, no explanation given for not filing complaint immediately - Due to expiry of drug vital right of applicants to get sample re-analyzed is violated - Magistrate without considering said fact issued summon on 31.3.2016 - Besides, sanction was accorded within 5 days from date of issuance of show cause notice i.e. even before reply given by applicant - As regards applicant no.2, no mention in complaint that he is responsible for day to day affair of company of applicant no.1 - Merely because he is director of company, he cannot be held vicariously liable - No explanation given by drug inspector for not issuing notices u/S.18-A of Drugs and Cosmetics Act to other accused - Fit case wherein Court can invoke powers u/S.482 - Quashing allowed.  2010 ALL MR (Cri) 2593 (S.C.), 2017 ALL MR (Cri) 3236, 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 1394, 1998 ALL MR (Cri) 1302 (S.C.), 2013 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 1, 2008 ALL MR (Cri) 1768 (S.C.) Rel.on.	(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
Complaint about
HeadNote.description: Quashing of proceedings - Manufacturing drugs without licence - Complaint about - Application for licence was filed and licence was granted a day before drugs were seized - Mere making of application does not entitle manufacture and/or sell of drugs and hence High Court was not justified in quashing proceedings holding the lapse as only a technical breach.	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Conviction under for possession of adulterated drugs
HeadNote.description: Conviction under for possession of adulterated drugs - Accused persons sentenced on the basis of plea bargaining understanding with prosecutor - Practice of such inducement deprecated - Order of conviction and sentence on such plea bargaining liable to be set aside.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Revisional order
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Revisional order - Challenge - Trial court had ordered dismissal of complaint which was filed 16 years back in which not even summons for appearance was served upon accused - Revisional court set aside said dismissal while treating summons case on erroneous footing of being warrant case - Held, for said reason order of revisional court liable to be set aside - Matter relegated back to revisional court for fresh decision. 	 (Paras 3, 6, 7)

heading: Bail
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Bail - Grant of - Alleged recovery of cartons containing bottles of Corex Cough Syrup from transport company of which appellant is manager - Govt. notification dt.10/3/2016 sought to prohibit manufacture, distribution and sale of 344 FDC including Corex - However, said notification quashed by Order of Delhi High Court dt.1/12/2016 - Appellant is in custody since 24/8/2016 - In view of said circumstances, bail granted.  (Paras 4, 7, 8)

heading: Issuance of process
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Issuance of process - Challenge - Case of manufacturing of sub-standard drug - Petitioners/directors of company arrayed as accused in complaint alongwith manufacturer/original accused - Drug "Sarratiopeptidase" found to be substandard drug - Impugned order not showing as to for what offences process issued against petitioners - No averments in complaint that petitioners were in charge or were responsible for conduct of business of company - Said drug not found to have Category B defects - It is not clear whether prosecution is contemplated in respect of said drugs - As application for amendment of complaint is pending before Magistrate, it would not be proper to deal with merits of said application at this stage - Matter remitted back for fresh consideration.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Quashing of complaint
HeadNote.description: Quashing of complaint - Alleged manufacturing of spurious and sub-standard drugs by company - Govt. analyst found subject drug non-compliant with IP Standards with respect to dissolution - Petitioners against whom process issued by JMFC, were appointed as directors of company after samples being drawn - Both of them were not in charge of and responsible for affairs of company at time of commission of alleged offence - Respondent authorities failed to follow predicates of Act and filed complaint against petitioner even without issuing show cause notice to them - Process issued by JMFC without application of mind - Order was made without recording even in cryptic manner, its reasons - No effective alternate remedy shown to be available to petitioners - Order issuing process and complaint liable to be quashed and set aside. 			(Paras 15, 16, 21, 22)

heading: Issuance of process
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Issuance of process - Challenge - Distribution of sub-standard drugs - Process issued against petitioners who are directors of company - They are residing at place beyond area of jurisdiction of Magistrate issuing process - Procedure u/S.202 however not followed - Hence, process liable to be quashed. 			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Issuance of process
HeadNote.description:
Issuance of process - Applicant allegedly sold drug of sub-standard quality despite being a competent seller and distributer of medicine - Invoices submitted by applicant show the supplier’s names which proves that applicant is not the manufacturer - Reliance placed by applicant on analyst report furnished by supplier to applicant providing warranty that subject drug is of standard quality - Applicant had no reason to doubt correctness of this warranty - Nor did he know and could not possibly know that the subject drug by way of sample from his shop was of sub-standard quality - No prima facie case against applicant - Issuance of process, not proper. 
 2008 ALL MR (Cri) 701, 1978 (I) Allahabad HC 237 Rel.on. 
 (Paras 3, 10, 11, 13, 14)

headline: Drugs and Cosmetics Act (1940), Ss. 19(3), 25(3), 18B – Issuance of process, quashed – Retailer could not possibly know that the subject drug by way of sample from his shop was of sub-standard quality

heading: Addition of accused
HeadNote.description:
Addition of accused - Name of company as accused, was dropped by complainant himself - Then at later stage, company was sought to be added and tried with other accused - No exceptional circumstances to invoke extra-ordinary power u/s.319 Cr.P.C. - Even the trial of other accused coming to end - Addition of company as accused, not allowed.

(1983) 1 SCC 1 Ref.to.

2002 (2) Crimes 536 Rel.on.	(Para 25)

heading: Trade mark
Infringement of
HeadNote.description: Food Safety and Standards Act (2006), S.3(1)(x) - Trade mark - Infringement of - Trade mark "cheri" and "Multi cheri" - Plaintiff's goods "Cheri" are 'drugs' within meaning of Act (1940) - They are meant to be therapeutic in nature and basically used in pharmaceutical preparations - They are to be used "as directed by physician" - Defendant's products "Multi Cherry" are 'proprietary food' covered under Act (2006) and not 'drugs' as per Act (1940) - They are avowedly "not for medicinal use" - They are to be used 'as directed by dietician' - Prices of two products are different and so are their end uses - There is no concrete likelihood of deception or confusion in minds of user - No case made out of infringement of trade mark.			(Paras 8, 12)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Manufacture and sale of sub-standard drugs - Appeal against acquittal - Case of prosecution based on report of Govt. analyst which shows that samples were not of standard quality - As per S.20 of Drugs and Cosmetics Act, Govt. analyst can be appointed by State Govt. by notification in official gazette and said notification should also prescribe area in which analyst is required to exercise his powers and specify classes of drugs and cosmetics he can analyse - There is no such gazette notification published by State Govt. regarding appointment of Govt. analyst on whose report, case of prosecution stands - Appointment of Govt. analyst was not valid and proper being not in accordance with provisions of S.20 - Report of Govt. analyst cannot be relied on to prosecute accused - Acquittal of accused, proper. 			(Paras 7, 10, 12, 13, 15, 16)

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art. 227 - Quashing of issuance of process and proceeding - Petition for - Proceeding for manufacturing of drugs which is not of standard quality - As per R. 45 testing of sample has to be done within 60 days - Testing is beyond statutory period prescribed under R. 45 - When sample was tested after expiry period, result is bond to be ‘not of standard quality’ - Such report cannot be considered at all - Benefit of such lapse should go to accused - Further within 28 days from knowledge of report accused stated that they are not agreeing with report and would like to have rechecking - Before accused had received notice regarding sub-standard quality of drugs, sanction to prosecution was granted by competent authority - Complainant filed proceeding belatedly just one day before drug was to expire - Vital right of accused to get sample rechecked have been violated because of belated filing of complaint - Proceeding liable to be quashed.  MANU/MH/0996/2019; 2018 ALL MR (Cri) 3946; AIR 2008 SC 1939 Rel. on. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Denial of
HeadNote.description: Right to get sample analysed by Central Drugs Laboratory - Denial of - Sample taken from accused found sub-standard - Accused disputing report of Government Analyst and demanding test by Central Laboratory - No action taken thereon - Complaint filed about a month short of the expiry date of the drug and it was well nigh impossible to get sample tested before its expiry - Held appellant was deprived of a valuable right under S.25(3) and 25(4) which must necessitate quashing of proceedings against them.	(Para 10)

heading: Manufacture of sub standard drug
HeadNote.description: Manufacture of sub standard drug - Report of Govt. analyst showing that sample drug was below standard - Sample sent to Director Central Drugs Laboratory for test - Report of Central Laboratory showing that sample was of standard quality - Report of Central Laboratory is final and it substitutes report of Govt. analyst - Prosecution of accused has to be quashed.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Offence by firm
Liability of partner
HeadNote.description:
Offence by firm - Liability of partner - Only the partner who was in overall control of the day to day business of the firm would alone be liable to be convicted. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.439.

The partner of a firm is liable to be convicted for an offence committed by the firm if he was in charge of and was responsible to the firm for the conduct of the business of the firm or if it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of the partner concerned. AIR 1971 SC 28, AIR 1981 SC 872 Rel.on.	 [Para 11]

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Infringement of right of accused u/s.25(4) - Prayer for quashing of proceeding - Maintainability - Charge against applicants for manufacture of sub-standard quality drug - Though Govt. Analyst's report received in February 2011, complaint filed only on 31-10-2011 - As shelf value of product was getting lost in November 2011, it was not possible for applicants to get sample analyzed from CDL in November 2011 - Thus, valuable right available to applicants u/S.25(4) was infringed by complainant - Therefore, criminal complaint against applicants liable to be quashed. 
2008 ALL MR (Cri) 1768 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Adulterated drug
Process quashed.
HeadNote.description: Adulterated drug - Prosecution against Directors of the Company - No allegations that Accused are responsible for carrying on day to day business of the Company - Process quashed.

heading: Sample of medicine found to be not of standard quality
HeadNote.description:
Sample of medicine found to be not of standard quality - Report not acceptable to accused  and request made to Inspector to send another sample to Central Drugs Laboratory for reanalysis - No action taken by Drugs Inspector - It affects prosecution adversely - Conviction is misconceived.

Section 25(3) makes it clear that after the receipt of the report of the Government Analyst by the accused, in case the accused is intending to adduce evidence in controversion of the said report, he is required to notify in writing the Inspector or the Court before which any proceedings in respect of the sample are pending, within 28 days from the date of receipt of such report. This subsection contemplates two forums to be approached by the accused within 28 days from the receipt of a copy of the report of the Government Analyst. First, the Inspector and the second is the Court before whom the proceedings in respect of the sample are pending. The accused is entitled to approach any one of the above referred authorities within the stipulated period of 28 days and since in the instant case, the accused has approached the Inspector within 28 days, as contemplated by sub-section (3) of section 25 of the Act, it cannot be said that there was any delay whatsoever on the part of the accused to move the authority concerned as contemplated under sub-section (3) of Section 25 of the Act. Therefore, it was not only necessary but incumbent upon the Drug Inspector to immediately move the Magistrate, as contemplated under sub-section (4) of Section 25 of the Act, for necessary direction. However, in the instant case, the Drug Inspector did not do anything inspite of the intimation. The inaction on the part of the concerned officer results in depriving the citizens from exercising their available statutory rights which ultimately adversely affects the prosecution and the Courts are required to quash the same.  [Para 16,18,19]

heading: Drug 'Gentimex Topical Cream' found in shop detected to be sub-standard
HeadNote.description: Drug 'Gentimex Topical Cream' found in shop detected to be sub-standard - Receipt obtained showing some other cream - Accused taking plea that drug was not kept for sale but for distribution to Primary Health Centre - Merely because receipt was not produced by prosecution it does not mean that it was not kept for sale - Even otherwise keeping Stock of substandard drug for distribution to PHC is covered by S. 18 - Partner who was present at time of taking sample can be held to be in charge and responsible for offence. (Para 3)

heading: Manufacturing sub-standard drug
Offence by company
Liability of director
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing sub-standard drug - Offence by company - Liability of director - Proceedings sought to be quashed by director on ground that General Manager of company was infact person in charge and responsible to affairs of company at relevant time - Contention raised that petitioner had not filed any reply to notice taking any such stand - Not acceptable - In reply he already made it clear that different person was in-charge and responsible for affairs of company - Complaint was lodged against petitioner merely because he was director of company - No specific averments made against him carving out actual role in commission of alleged crime - Hence, FIR against him liable to be quashed. 1998 ALL MR (Cri) 1302 (S.C.), 2010 ALL MR (Cri) 921 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 1890, 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 419 (S.C.), 1999 (3) MLJ 850 Ref.to. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Offence under
HeadNote.description:
Offence under - Prosecution not procuring presence of independent witnesses when it found Aldomet Tablets in the premises of accused - Entry in inspection report i.e. in form 15 and 35 also not made - Held order of discharge could not be interfered with.

In matters under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, technicalities are very important. There is a lapse on the part of the prosecution on this aspect. In view of the breach of technicalities, prosecution could not, prima facie bring any material before the Court, and therefore, order of discharge passed by the learned metropolitan Magistrate cannot be said to be erroneous.  [Para 7]

heading: Quashing of FIR
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Misbranding of drugs and cheating - Quashing of FIR - Inspection done by officers of drug department showing that original date of manufacture and original date of expiry of sanitizers were changed by affixing new labels on containers of sanitizers - Record showing that price was also changed - Representative of accused-company stated that they have received instructions from Directors - Applicants-accused claiming that they were investor in company and not involved in management of company - Nothing on record to show that management was entrusted to particular person by Directors - Further, licence to distribute, sale drugs were issued in name of applicants - Record showing that one of applicants is founder of company and another applicant has purchased 43% shares in company and in that capacity was Director in company - Accused persons committed offence of creation of false record and also offence of cheating - Material on record is sufficient to show that applicants are responsible for conducting business of company - Prima facie case made out against applicants - FIR cannot be quashed. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Drugs and cosmetics
Re-analysis of sample
HeadNote.description: Drugs and cosmetics - Re-analysis of sample - Non sending part of sample to appellant-manufacturer as required u/S.23(4)(iii) of Act - Cognizance of offence taken more than two years after filing of complaint - Delay on both counts is not attributable to appellants - Valuable right of accused for re-analysis vested under Act stood violated having regard to possible shelf life of drug in question - Criminal proceeding against appellant-company and its directors quashed. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Vicarious liability of Directors
HeadNote.description:
Vicarious liability of Directors - Arises if at relevant time person was in charge of and also responsible to the company for the conduct of its business - Phraseology used conveys actual participation in day-to-day affairs of the company - In absence of proof to that effect onus of proof cannot shift from prosecution to accused.

Section 34 of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and Section 17 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, are practically identical. Both these Sections speak about the offences committed by the companies. If these two Sections are carefully read, there is no manner of doubt that the vicarious liability of a person for being prosecuted for an offence committed under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, by a company arises if, at the relevant time, he was in charge of and was also responsible to the company for the conduct of its business.  [Para 20]

The phraseology used in Section 34 of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and Section 17 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, has a special significance. A commission of offence by company under Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, requires different treatment by virtue of Section 34 of the Act of 1940 and Section 17 of the Act of 1954. The phraseology used in Sections 34 of the Act of 1940, and Section 17 of the Act, 1954, conveys actual participation in day-to-day affairs of the company.  [Para 21]

A person in charge of and responsible to the company for the conduct of the business of the company means that the person who effectively exercises all control of the day-to-day business of the company or firm. What is legally required is overall control over the day-to-day business of the company and the firm. If this element is present then only the directors of the company are responsible for the contravention of the provisions of Drugs and Cosmetics Act of 1940, and Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.  [Para 22]

In both the cases in hand, except bald statement made in the complaints filed by the Drug Inspector and Food Inspector, there is no whisper in the complaints that the petitioners were in charge of and were also responsible to the companies for the conduct of the business of the companies. The Drug Inspector and the Food Inspector, have drawn a presumption with regard to involvement of the Directors of the company without any averments with regard to control of day-to-day business of the companies.  [Para 24]

The onus of proving that a particular director was in charge of and also responsible to the conduct of the business of the company, at the time of contravention of the provisions of Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, and Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954, is on the prosecution. If it is shown that a particular director has overall control over the day-to-day business of the company and he participates in the day-to-day affairs of the company then, in that event, there will be transformation of onus of proof from prosecution to the accused. In the instant case, the initial burden is not discharged by the prosecution.  [Para 31]

heading: Supply of roller closed woven bandage
HeadNote.description:
Supply of roller closed woven bandage - Report of Analyst that sample does not comply with specification prescribed under Act - Accused proprietor not notifying his intention of getting sample analysed by Central Drug laboratory within 28 days after receipt of report - Accused loses his right to get it analysed - Report becomes conclusive evidence.

A combined reading of sub-sections 3 and (4) of S.25 clearly indicates that right to get the drug tested by Central Drugs Laboratory does not arise unless requirement of sub-section (3) of Section 25 of the Act is complied with.	 [Para 8]

In the instant case, the copies of report of Government Analyst were received by the accused petitioners on 1-6-1995 but inspite of that the petitioners did not notify their intention to adduce their evidence in controversion of the said report within 28 days either to the Inspector or the Court concerned and, therefore, the right of the petitioners to get the sample re-tested by Central Drugs Laboratory through the trial Court stood extinguished and the report of the Government Analyst became conclusive evidence under sub-section (3) of Section 25 of the Act. In view of this, the contention of the petitioners that even if they did not notify their intention to get the sample re-tested from the Central Drugs Laboratory within 28 days of the receipt of report of Government Analyst, as contemplated under Section 25(3) of the Act, they have statutory right under section 25(4) of the Act to request the trial Court to send the sample to Central Drugs Laboratory for re-analysis on the date of their first appearance before the trial Court cannot be accepted. Therefore, rejection of application filed by accused persons is just and proper and does not call for  interference.

heading: Mislabelling ayurvedic drug
HeadNote.description: Mislabelling ayurvedic drug - Sildenafil citrate (brand name viagra), an allopathic drug used for erectile dysfunction - Company was not having licence to manufacture sildenafil citrate - Ozomen capsule sold by company contained 33.9 mg to 46.82 mg. of sildenafil per capsule - Selling this drug without displaying its name is offence under Ss.18 and 27 - Prosecution directed to be launched against accused.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Prohibition of quality and percentage
HeadNote.description:
Prohibition of quality and percentage - Scope and constitutional validity of R.106-B - Rule 106-B intended to ensure that there is no diversion or misuse of alcohol which is used in the preparation of homoeopathic medicines - No discrimination between homoeopathic and Ayurvedic medicines - It is not necessary for legislature to regulate every conceivable activity in order to regulate something - Legislature can recognize and distinguish between degrees of evil and regulate those areas where its intervention is most required - Such a classification cannot be regarded as arbitrary or unconstitutional.

The manufacture of drugs must be pursued in a manner which is consistent with the protection of public interest and Rule 106-B is intended to ensure that there is no diversion or misuse of alcohol which is used in the preparation of homoeopathic medicines. There is absolutely no merit in the submission that there is a discrimination between manufacturers of Homoeopathic and Ayurvedic medicines. Even on the assumption that a similar diversion of alcohol may conceivabley take place in the manufacture of Ayurvedic medicines, the argument of the Petitioner at the highest would be that the classification is under inclusive, but it is well settled that it is not necessary for the legislature to regulate every conceivable activity in order to regulate something. The legislature can recognize and distinguish between degrees of evil and regulate those areas where its intervention is most required. Such a classification cannot be regarded as arbitrary or unconstitutional. The submission that Rule 106-B has been brought into force without complying with mandatory procedural requirements is based on the allegation that the Drugs Technical Advisory Board did not have any representative with an expert knowledge in the field of Homoeopathy. The constitution of the Board is provided for in Section 5(2) of the Act. Hence, it would not be for the Court to mandate any change in the statutory provision relating to the Constitution of the Board. That is for the Parliament to best determine.
  [Para 7,8,9]

heading: Report of analyst
Report is conclusive
HeadNote.description: Report of analyst - Report is conclusive - No reasons are needed in support of conclusion given in the report, nor it is required that the report should contain the mode or particulars of the analysis - However, law permits the drug manufacturer to controvert the report expressing his intention to adduce evidence to controvert the report within the prescribed limitation of 28 days. AIR 1970 SC 318 - Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Offence of selling substandard medicines
HeadNote.description: Offence of selling substandard medicines - Petitioner licensee taking plea of defence under S.19(3)(c) - No allegations against petitioner that sales or packing thereof were tampered with - It could be held that charge of non-compliance or failure to take required care under S.34 on account of violation of S.18 was not made out - Consequently action of suspension of licence based on inadequately worded notice was wholly unjustified.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Offence by company
Liability of directors
Complaint
HeadNote.description: Offence by company - Liability of directors - Drug found to contain fungus - Complaint - Averments clearly stating that Directors were privy to manufacturing of medicine by company - Not a bald statement - Complaint cannot be quashed as offence had direct impact on public health - It cannot be said that averments like those required by S.138 of NI Act were necessary. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482.	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Offences by companies
HeadNote.description: Offences by companies - Prosecution case that accused firm along with its partners contravened provisions of Act by manufacturing for sale or distribution and selling drug 'Framycetin Sulphate Cream' (Fratouch) which was not of standard quality and was spurious - No averment in complaint that respondent accused was in charge of and responsible to accused firm for conduct of its business - Letter allegedly written by one of partners that respondent was authorized to take care of day to day affairs of firm though marked as an exhibit, its contents were not proved - Other letter written and signed by respondent accused stating that he has power of attorney to manage firm also not proved through handwriting expert - Thus, no evidence to prove that respondent accused at relevant time was in charge of and responsible for conduct of business of accused firm - Acquittal of respondent accused therefore, is proper. (Paras 19, 22, 23, 24)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Appeal against acquittal - Maintainability - Offences under Drugs and Cosmetics Act - Appeal before Addl. Sessions Judge, not maintainable - Appropriate remedy to be adopted before appropriate forum. 	(Para 3)

heading: Offence by companies
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Offence by companies - Prayer for quashing of process - Process issued against Petitioner Company and its partners for manufacturing sub-standard drug - However, label on said drug revealed that manufacturer of drug was one "Mano Pharmaceuticals" and not petitioner - Process was issued against petitioner only on ground that it had issued manufacturing licence to Mano Pharmaceuticals - Not justified - Allegation in complaint is not that spurious drug was manufactured on basis of license issued by petitioner - Analysis report received by complainant was also sent to Mano Pharmaceuticals and not to petitioner company as complainant was also of opinion that it was manufacturer who would be held liable - Process issued against petitioners liable to be quashed. 2002 Cri. L.J. 4843 Ref. to.  (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Complaint u/Ss.18(a)(i), 27(d)
Application for quashing
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing of sub-standard drugs - Complaint u/Ss.18(a)(i), 27(d) - Application for quashing - Sample of chloramphenicol eye ointment was not of standard quality - Said eye ointment manufactured by original accused i.e. M/s Joyti Capsules - Applicants were directors of accused company - Specific averments made against original accused and other accused - However, complaint is totally silent in respect of role of applicants - Merely because applicants are directors that by itself not sufficient to bring them within clutches of Act - Complaint against them required to be quashed. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Offences by companies
Cannot be accepted
HeadNote.description: Offences by companies - Samples of Hemfer syrup bottles collected by Drug Inspector found to be not of standard quality - Material on record showing that petitioners directors were conducting business of company and so they were involved in manufacturing process - It cannot be said that there are no specific allegations against petitioners - Petitioners accused have no right to say that they can be added subsequently after leading of evidence - Plea that experts whose names were submitted for obtaining licence by accused company were only responsible u/S.34 and prosecution cannot lie against directors - Cannot be accepted - Order issuing process against petitioners is proper. 			(Paras 16, 19, 21)

heading: Offences by Companies
HeadNote.description: Offences by Companies - Persons accused must be in charge and /or responsible for the company and for the conduct of business of the company. 	(Para 9)

heading: Offence u/S.27(b)(ii)
HeadNote.description: Offence u/S.27(b)(ii) - Prayer for quashing criminal proceedings - On ground that offence u/S.27(b)(ii) being non-cognizable offence, its cognizance could not have been taken on basis of chargesheet filed by police officer - In view of S.32, cognizance of said offence should have been taken on basis of complaint as defined u/S.2(d) Cr.P.C. - Having not done so, criminal proceedings filed against petitioner quashed. 2008 ALL MR (Cri) 1189 (S.C.), (2000) 2 SCC 636, 1998 ALL MR (Cri) 144 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Manufacturing cosmetics for sale or for distribution - Grant or renewal of licence - Manufacturing of Mehandi products not categorized in Sch.M-II - Neither licence is required to manufacture Mehandi cones or Mehandi powder - Nor conditions of license as provided under R.142 of Rules and manner of labelling as prescribed under R.148 of Rules needs to be followed - Hence, criminal proceedings for offence punishable u/S.18(c) of the Act and Rules thereunder quashed. (Paras 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Illegal sale of drugs and cosmetics - Quashing of proceedings - Applicant allegedly selling medicine from medical shop of which license was cancelled - Applicant arraigned as accused along with co-accused - Applicant is medical practitioner whereas accused no.1 running medical shop in premises owned by applicant - At time of raiding accused no.3 was closing said shop and one patient was out of shop - However, applicant was not present in said shop - Prescription recovered from patient by raiding party not showing name of applicant as examining doctor nor name of patient - Nothing on record to show that applicant was conducting business from said shop - Just because applicant is owner of that premises, inference cannot be drawn that applicant and accused no.1 were acting in connivance with each other in selling medicine from said shop - Applicant cannot be prosecuted only on basis of conjectures - Accused no.1 is prosecuted being proprietor of shop without license - There is no provision like common intention or vicarious liability of any other person - In view of facts, continuation of proceedings against applicant would be abuse of process of law - Same is liable to be quashed. 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 812 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Report of government analyst
HeadNote.description:
Report of government analyst - Manufacturer not entitled to get copy of report as a right - He is not however, liable to be acquitted on ground of legislative lacuna (if at all it is lacuna) of not supplying copy of report of analyst.

The conclusiveness meant in Section 25(3) of the Act need be read in juxtaposition with the persons referred to in the sub-section.  In other words, if any of the persons who receives a copy of the report of the Government Analyst fails to notify his intention to adduce evidence in controversion of the facts stated in the report within a period of 28 days of the receipt of the report, then such report of the Government Analyst could become conclusive evidence regarding the facts stated therein as against such persons.  But as for an accused, like the manufacturer in the present case, who is not entitled to be supplied with a copy of the report of the Government Analyst, he must have the liberty to challenge the correctness of the facts stated in the report by resorting to any other modes by which such facts can be disproved.  He can also avail himself of the remedy indicated in sub-section (4) of Section 25 of the Act by requesting the Court to send the other portion of the sample remaining in the Court to be tested at the Central Drugs Laboratory.  Of course no Court is under a compulsion to cause the said sample to be so tested if the request is made after a long delay.  It is for that purpose that a discretion has been conferred on the Court to decide whether such sample should be sent to the Central Drugs Laboratory on the strength of such request.  However, once the sample is tested at the Central Drugs Laboratory and a report as envisaged in Section 25(4) of the Act is produced in Court the conclusiveness mentioned in that sub-section would become incontrovertible.	 [Para 25]

When the provisions can be interpreted in such a way as to avert absurd consequences in the manner indicated above it is not congenial to the interest of criminal justice to acquit the manufacturers of forbidden medicines or drugs on a technical ground that there is a lacuna in the legislation by not supplying copy of the report of the Government Analyst to the manufacturer in certain situations.  To adopt the course of acquitting such offending manufacturers only on the legislative lacuna (if at all it is lacuna) would be hazardous to public health and the lives of the patients to whom drugs are prescribed by medical practitioners would be in jeopardy. [Para 28]

heading: Offence by company
Issuance of process
HeadNote.description: Offence by company - Issuance of process - Non-compliance with sub-sections (3) and (4) of S.25 of Drugs and Cosmetics Act - Petitioner-company manufacturing drug viz. compound sodium lactate injection IP was having white coloured fibrous substances, suspended in injectable function - Factory was inspected on 3rd August, 2012 and one sample was sent to Govt. Analyst on 6th August, 2012 - Report was received on 30th August, 2012 and was communicated to petitioners/accused u/S.18A of Act on 4th Sep., 2012 that drug was not of standard quality - On 11th Sep., 2012, petitioners communicated non-acceptance of report and wanted to get examined all samples of four bottles, as in report only one sample is tested and wants to adduce more evidence - Quality of drug of petitioner is not challenged by anybody till today - When petitioners appeared before Court, shelf life of sample was expired on 30th October, 2012 and petitioners had lost their right - Thus, there is non-compliance of sub-section (4) of S.25 of Act, which is very valuable right of accused - Order of issuance of process against petitioners was liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Complaint under
HeadNote.description:
Complaint under - Prompt lodging of complaint, prime importance - Provisions of enactment to be more precise and accurate - Samples drawn must be sent for analysis forthwith.

In cases falling under the Act prompt action at every stage is a must  though it is not expressly made clear in the Act.  The samples drawn must be sent for analysis forthwith.  Portions thereof must be given to  the concerned parties without loss of time.  Report must be prepared expeditiously.  It must be sent to the Inspector with expedition.  Copies of the report must be served on the concerned parties as soon as possible and complaint must be lodged without wasting time.  Reason for this expedition at every stage is the shelf-life of a drug and the need to get it analysed within a particular time frame.  While sub-section (1) of Section 24 of the Insecticides Act 1968, the Insecticide Analyst has to submit his report within a period of 60 days, surprisingly there is no such provision in the Act providing for an outer limit for submission of the report.  It is elementary that no complaint could be filed till such time as the report of the analyst is received.  If the report is delayed consequently the complaint would be delayed.  Delayed complaint may result in denying the accused or the complainant the right to get the samples tested from the Central Drugs Laboratory before the shelf-life of the drug is over.  That would frustrate the prosecution.  Prompt lodging of the complaint therefore is of prima importance.

There are no clear provisions in the Act indicating that when the sample is not drawn from the premises where it is manufactured, one portion of the sample should go to the manufacturer.  In such a case he has to divide the sample in 4 portions.  One portion is to be sent to a person whose name is disclosed under Section 18-A.  Section 18-A only requires a person not being a manufacturer to disclose name of the person from whom he has acquired the drug.  That may not necessarily be the accused.  In an enactment such as this one wishes, that to obviate  reducing the prosecution to a farce, the provisions would be more precise and accurate.

heading: Petition for discharge
HeadNote.description: Offence of manufacturing sub-standard drug - Petition for discharge - Sodium chloride injection manufactured by accused, not found of standard quality in Govt. analyst report - As it contained suspended matter visible to unaided eyes - Though report of Govt. analyst received in 1987, complaints filed in 1988 i.e. just before expiry of shelf life of sample - As result, accused lost their valuable right to get sample tested from Central Laboratory - Even if report of Govt. analyst accepted as it is, accused cannot be said to have contravened Act of 1940 - Moreso because development of visible particles is natural phenomena during storage due to variation in temperature - Therefore, accused discharged. 2001 ALL MR (Cri) 2261, 1988(3) Bom.C.R. 207, AIR 1967 SC 970, AIR 2008 SC 1939 Ref.to. (Paras 8, 9, 11, 12, 16, 18)

heading: Manufacturing substandard drugs
Legality
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing substandard drugs - Complaint by Drug inspector - Legality - Drug inspector collected samples from shop of accused in April 1992 and also searched premises of accused in April 1993 - As per S.21, a drug inspector is empowered to discharge his official duties once his appointment is notified in Official Gazette - However, in present case, though drug Inspector was appointed on 1.8.1992, his appointment was notified in Official Gazette on 7.10.1993 - It means date on which raid and search of premises of accused was conducted, he was not Inspector within meaning of S.21 of Drugs and Cosmetics Act - Though complaint was lodged by drug inspector in 1994, it was without any authority and, therefore, bad in law - Acquittal of accused proper. 1999 ALL MR (Cri) 773 Rel. on. 			(Paras 7, 8, 10)

heading: Blacklisting of appellant-supplier
Effect
HeadNote.description: Supply of sub-standard drug/cream - Blacklisting of appellant-supplier - Delay in sending sample - Effect - Drawal of sample long after supply of drug - Sample received by Govt. analyst, one month after its drawal - First test report dated few days before expiry of shelf life of cream, found sample to be below acceptable standard - Sample sent to Central Drugs Laboratory long after expiry of goods in question - Even blacklisted for 2 years on basis of first test report - Appellate report showed that Govt. analyst's report was wholly incorrect - Post decisional hearing given to appellant by Drugs Committee and order of blacklisting found to be proper - Held, delay in sending sample for testing, violative of valuable right of appellant - And post decisional hearing was eye wash as Committee did not even refer to findings of appellate report - Blacklisting of appellant, liable to be set aside. (Paras 4, 5, 12, 15)

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art. 227 - Quashing of issuance of process and proceeding - Petition for - Proceeding for manufacturing of drugs which is not of standard quality - As per R. 45 testing of sample has to be done within 60 days - Testing is beyond statutory period prescribed under R. 45 - When sample was tested after expiry period, result is bond to be ‘not of standard quality’ - Such report cannot be considered at all - Benefit of such lapse should go to accused - Further within 28 days from knowledge of report accused stated that they are not agreeing with report and would like to have rechecking - Before accused had received notice regarding sub-standard quality of drugs, sanction to prosecution was granted by competent authority - Complainant filed proceeding belatedly just one day before drug was to expire - Vital right of accused to get sample rechecked have been violated because of belated filing of complaint - Proceeding liable to be quashed.  MANU/MH/0996/2019; 2018 ALL MR (Cri) 3946; AIR 2008 SC 1939 Rel. on. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Exclusion from criminal liability
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion from criminal liability - Person acting on behalf of licensee in contravention of Act and Rules - Not to be excluded from criminal liability under provisions of Act and Rules - Contention that licensee alone is to maintain records and registers in prescribed forms and for any contravention thereof, the licensee alone is responsible for breach of Rule, not tenable.

In the instant case, the applicant would be a person who has sold the drugs on behalf of the licensee in contravention of the Rules and, therefore, in view of the provisions of section 18(A)(vi) read with section 27 of the Act is liable to be prosecuted. It is not available to the applicant to raise the defence that under Rule 65 as well as sub-clauses of the said Rule impose the duty on the licensee alone to maintain records and registers in the prescribed forms and for any contravention thereof it is the licensee alone who is responsible for such breach of Rule and is alone liable for prosecution. It must be borne in mind that the legislature thought it fit to prohibit every person whether he is a licensee himself or other person who is acting on behalf of such licensee (in whichever capacity) to sell any drug or cosmetic in contravention of any of the provisions of the Act and Rules made thereunder. Neither section 18 nor section 25 carves out any exception in this regard in favour of person who is acting on behalf of the licensee from the criminal liability. In absence thereof, it is not possible to exclude a person who is acting on behalf of the licensee and the act of such person contravenes the provisions of the Act and Rules, to be excluded from the Criminal liability under the provisions of the Act. The contention of the learned counsel for the applicant if accepted in this regard, would frustrate the scheme of sections 18 and 27 and, therefore, the same is rejected.

The purport of sections 18 and 27 is every person whether licensee agent or may be a qualified person, is prohibited from selling any drug in contravention of provisions of Act and Rules without any exception to this Rule and, therefore, all those who sell drug in contravention of the provisions of the Act and Rules are responsible for such contravention and can be proceeded against. Any other interpretation of sections 18, and 27, in my view would be totally inconsistent with the legislative intent as well as object and purpose for which these provisions are enacted by the legislature. For the reasons stated hereinabove, the contention canvassed by Shri Manohar, learned Counsel for the applicant in this regard is misconceived and devoid of substance.	 [Para 22,23]

heading: Offences by companies
Improper practice
HeadNote.description:
Offences by companies - Addition of Directors as accused - Alleged offences took place in 1995 - Information as to their Directorship received from Memorandum of Association prepared in 1987 - Records maintained by Registrar of Companies not verified - Improper practice - Documents produced by applicants showing that they had resigned from Directorship much prior to date of offence - Even otherwise, there was no specific averment in complaint that on date of offence, applicants were in charge and responsible for conduct of business of company - Addition of applicants as accused, not justified.

It was admitted that in the complaint, against applicants, there was no averment that the applicants/accused are Directors and they are incharge and responsible to the conduct of business of company on the date of alleged offence.  It is necessary to specifically aver in complaint that when offence was committed accused was incharge of and responsible for the conduct of business of company. This averment is an essential requirement of relevant provision of the Act and has to be made in complaint.  Merely being a Director of Company is not sufficient to make a person liable unless he is responsible and in-charge of day-to-day affairs of company.  1998(4) LJ 830, 2001 ALL MR (Cri) 1206 (S.C.), 2004 ALL MR (Cri) 598 (S.C.); 2004 ALL MR (Cri) 3170 (S.C.), 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1118, 2006(6) ALL MR (S.C.) 131, 2007 ALL MR (Cri) 1445 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 526 : 2007 ALL MR (Cri) 560 (S.C.), 2007 ALL MR (Cri) 870 (SC), 2009 ALL SCR 1656, 2009 ALL SCR 1524 - Rel. on.  [Para 12,14,16]

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing of substandard drug - Appeal against acquittal - Prosecution case that accused manufactured drug 'caryrox' which was a suspension of generic drug 'Roxithromicin' and each 5 ml of medicine was to contain 50 mg of 'Roxythromicin B.P. - Manufacture's standards were not ascertained or followed at time of analysis - No evidence to show that medicine was stored under standard conditions as required - Further, sample was analyzed at fag end of expiry period - In that view of matter, acquittal of accused by giving benefit of doubt is proper. 2001 ALL MR (Cri) 1980 (S.C.) Ref. to.  (Paras 8, 9)

heading: Quashing of FIR
Petition for
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Selling drug without permission - Quashing of FIR - Petition for - Unlabelled allopathic drug tablets were found in residential premises of petitioner - FIR was lodged on 09.12.2016 - Police report was submitted before Court on 24.10.2017 along with copy of seizure panchanama of unlabelled tablets, statement of petitioner and copy of analysis report - Bare reference to information received that petitioner is selling unlabelled tablets to patients suffering from body ache and joint pain - No positive material in form of statement of any such patient is presented before Court - Lodging of FIR and continuation of proceedings with such baseless material, is nothing but abuse of process of law - FIR quashed. 2017 ALL MR (Cri) 999 Ref.to. (Paras 21, 26)

heading: Report of Govt. analyst
HeadNote.description: Report of Govt. analyst - Right to get sample re-examined - No intention to adduce evidence in controversion of report notified within specified time - Results in extinguishment of right to get sample re-examined - Govt. analyst's report became final and binding - Though complaint was filed after expiry of shelf life of drugs - Right to re-examination already being extinguished - Prosecution cannot be quashed for delay in filing complaint.

heading: Offences by companies
Vicarious liability
Cannot be prosecuted.
HeadNote.description: Offences by companies - Vicarious liability - Directors of offending Company - In absence of any evidence or allegation to indicate that they were responsible to company for conduct of business or were in charge of the company - Cannot be prosecuted.

heading: Partnership firm
HeadNote.description: Partnership firm - No evidence to show that partners were in charge of or were responsible  for day to day conduct of the business of the Firm - Held no fault could be found with order discharging them. (Para 10)

heading: Provision about payment of fair price of sample taken is mandatory
HeadNote.description: Provision about payment of fair price of sample taken is mandatory - No   proof of payment - No proof that sample was for sale and not for personal use - Held, accused was properly discharged. (Para 12)

heading: Provision about taking four portions/containers is mandatory
HeadNote.description: Provision about taking four portions/containers is mandatory - No evidence that only three Borolin Antiseptic Perfumed Cream tubes were available - Failure to take four tubes is violative of mandate of S.23(3) and 23(4). (Para 16)

heading: Prosecution for the offence
HeadNote.description:
Prosecution for the offence - Nature of evidence to be produced.

The position of law under Section 34 of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 is very clear, viz. unless and until the prosecution makes an averment and produces the evidence to the effect that the concerned Director was incharge of and responsible to the conduct of the business, the prosecution cannot lie against such a Director against whom no such evidence is produced.  [Para 20]

heading: Appointment of Drug Inspector
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Drug Inspector - Issuance of the notification in official Gazette - Is not discretionary.

The intention of the legislature is very clear from the Section 21 of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 that the appointment of such a person holding such an important post as a Drug Inspector, especially in the interest of public health, obviously will have to be notified in the official Gazette and that the said notification should indicate the area in which the said Drug Inspector can exercise his powers. In fact, Section 21 does not say that the publication of notification in official Gazette is discretionary. If one were to look at the wording of the said section carefully, the Central Government or the State Government may appoint such qualified persons as the drug inspectors as it thinks fit. In fact, the wording of the said Section 21 shows that there is coma after the word 'may' and not before the said word so as to construe that the issuance of the notification in the official Gazette is discretionary.  [Para 40]

heading: Appointment of Drug Inspector
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Drug Inspector - Can only be through official gazette notification indicating area in which he can exercise his powers.

Taking into account all the purposes and objects of the Act and the powers conferred on the Drug Inspector who is the vital authority to initiate the prosecution, the appointment of Drug Inspector can only be through an Official Gazette Notification and not otherwise.  Such a notification should also indicate the area in which such a Drug Inspector can operate and exercise his powers, and the same should not be left to conjectures and surmises of the public.  [Para 41]

heading: Appointment of Drug Analyst
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Drug Analyst - Notification in official Gazette is mandatory.

Considering the clear wording of Section 20 of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940, the provisions therein are mandatory and thus, the State must publish in an official Gazette the appointment of the Government Analyst specifying therein the area wherein the Government Analyst can operate and also specifying therein the products with which the Government Analyst can test and analyse.  [Para 56]

heading: Report of Government Analyst
HeadNote.description:
Report of Government Analyst - His oral evidence prevails over the report.

There is no doubt that the Report ex facie could be admitted in evidence as to its contents also, but, the issue is that if the Government Analyst were to be examined as a witness, then, his oral evidence prevails over his report. The Analyst is subjected to cross-examination and as such, the evidence of the Analyst cannot be conclusive only on the basis of the report. Once the prosecution decides to examine the Government Analyst his oral evidence would prevail over the statement contained in his written analysis report.

39 Bom. L.R. 629 Refd.  

Taking into account all the facts and circumstances and especially the detailed evidence of Drug Analyst and in view of the categorical statement of the said witness admitting that the Laboratory did not have any facility for sterility test and that no standard preparation was available so as to compare the accuracy of test to be conducted, refusal to produce the working standards and also the records of the actual tests conducted, it is clear that the prosecution has failed to establish that the tests were conducted in a reasonable and proper manner so as to uphold the report of the Government Analyst.  [Para 73]

heading: Prosecution for sub-standard quality
HeadNote.description:
Prosecution for sub-standard quality - Injections of Sodium Chloride and Dextrose - Samples collected containing suspended matter - Development of particles is a natural phenomenon in the process of storage - This may happen due to non-observance of standard of storage in a cool place for which manufacturer cannot be held responsible - It was not the case of prosecution that injections contained any foreign material - Proceedings quashed for failure to make out a prima facie case.

1989 Cri.LJ 2028, 1991 Drugs Cases 386 Rel.on.	(Paras 7,8)

heading: Prosecution under
HeadNote.description:
Prosecution under - Prosecution of partners of firm who were not alleged or shown to be in charge of the business of the firm - Prosecution cannot be upheld.

1998 Drugs Cases 11 Rel on.	(Para 11)

heading: Area of operation of the Drug Inspector
HeadNote.description:
Area of operation of the Drug Inspector - Need not be specified in the official gazette - G. R. transferring Drug Inspector to Mumbai would be sufficient compliance if the said G.R. is duly notified in the official gazette.

1999(2) Mh. L.J. 650 Doubted.	(Para 8)

heading: Manufacture without requisite licence
HeadNote.description: Manufacture without requisite licence - Drug intended only for export - Drug not banned in the country of export - Drug seized from Air Port was not stored for immediate sale - Central Government had permitted export of the drug and had issued NOC for manufacture of drug - Held there was no contravention of S.18(c) and there was no reason to interfere with order of discharge under S.27.	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Public Analyst
HeadNote.description:
Public Analyst - Requirement to produce notification published in official gazette to prove identity of person issuing test report - Even if gazette is produced for inspection of court at stage of arguments, provision can be said to be complied with. 

AIR 1960 Patna 243 Rel.on. 	 (Para 18)

heading: Offence by company
HeadNote.description: Offence by company - Prosecution of person in-charge without impleading company - Permissibility in exceptional cases where due to some legal snag, company cannot be proceeded against - In instant case, name of company dropped from proceedings as it could not be served independently - Held, it cannot be termed as a legal snag or legal bar to proceed against company - Provisions of Cr.P.C. provide for issuance of summons, warrant and proclamation - Further, no sanction obtained from court for not proceeding against company - Trial could not proceed only against alleged in-charge of the company. 	(Paras 22, 23, 24, 26)

heading: Offence by company
HeadNote.description:
Offence by company - Vicarious liability of person in-charge - No averment in complaint that accused was responsible for carrying business of firm - Complaint not even mentioning the designation of accused in the firm - Mandatory requirement not satisfied - Even the letters allegedly written by partners of firm that accused was authorised to take care of production, sale etc. was not proved by examining authors of those letters - Reason for writing those letters to Drug Inspector, also not known - Prosecution failed to prove that accused was in-charge of and responsible for business of firm - Acquittal proper.

2010 ALL MR (Cri) 4012 (S.C.), (1981) 2 SCC 454 Disting.

1999 ALL MR (Cri) 773, 1999 (3) Mh.L.J. 850, 2005(5) ALL MR 1118 (S.C.) Ref.to. 			(Paras 37, 41)

heading: Contention not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Prosecution of person in-charge - No averment in complaint that accused was responsible for business of company - But, evidence produced on record to establish that accused was in-charge of company - Contention that in view of such evidence, court cannot go back to averments in complaint - Contention not acceptable - If averments in complaint are not seen, then accused would never be in a position to get discharge on ground of absence of required averment.	(Paras 38, 40)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Illegal sale of drugs - Appeal against acquittal - Ketamine Hydrochloride Injections were found stocked in garments shop run by original accused - However, he had license for distribution of said drug under which he could distribute same anywhere in India - Defence that said drugs were to be distributed at somewhere else and were stocked in said shop during transit - Vials were found in packed boxes - Nothing found in shop to establish that said injections were exhibited or offered for sale or were actually sold in that shop - As such, mere possession of drugs not meant for sale cannot be an offence - As regards co-accused being original lease holder of said shop, it cannot be said that he shared common intention to commit offence - No evidence that co-accused had any knowledge of said stock - Even no charge framed against both accused for contravention of Rule 62 - Hence, acquittal proper. 1979 Cri. L.J. 466 Rel. on. (1974) 4 SCC 209, 28(1985) DLT 392, 2012(2)ALD (Cri) 26, (1975) 3 SCC 322 Disting. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Ingredients of S.27
HeadNote.description: Ingredients of S.27 - Word "stocks" used u/S.27 contemplates only about stocking drugs for purpose of sale - Thus, S.27 postulates three separate categories of cases i.e. manufacture for sale, actual sale, stocking or exhibiting for sale or distribution of any drugs - As such, unless all ingredients of this category are satisfied, S.27 of Act would not be attracted. (Para 11)

heading: Cancellation of license
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of license - Violation of conditions of license - Petitioner, a powder manufacturing company did not obtain permission from licensing authority to carry out ETO treatment - Also did not inform authority after such treatment - No residual testing of ethylene oxide carried out - Which is necessary in case of ETO treatment - Petitioner only submitted analysis report of three batches out of fifteen - To sell powder without carrying out residual testing is serious lapse - Petitioner also failed to obtain loan license for said procedure - Held, issue of petitioner not obtaining loan license was raised only at appellate level - Operative order of appellate authority not based on this fact - Respondent must seek to sustain impugned orders only on basis of what is stated in show cause notice - However, issue of failure to obtain loan license is of general importance - Ought to be considered by authorities - Matter remanded back to appellate authority for fresh consideration after affording petitioner opportunity of being heard on this point. 	(Paras  12, 14, 18, 19)

heading: Cancellation of license
Doctrine of proportionality
Samples were preserved
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of license - Doctrine of proportionality - Petitioner's license has been in existence for about fifty years - Factory has about 2000 employees - Only 15 batches were treated without mandatory residual testing - Records were properly maintained - No tampering with records by petitioner - Samples were preserved - Without any obligation to do so, petitioner carried out tests to indicate  powder did not contain harmful residue - Authorities are to consider bona fides of petitioner - Taking into consideration all these facts and doctrine of proportionality, cancellation of license with respect to petitioner factory is harsh - Liable to be set aside. (Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Cancellation of license
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of license - Whether impugned cancellation ought to remain in force though matter is remanded back for fresh decision - Alleged incorrect procedure for which licence was cancelled, adopted only in respect of 15 batches of product - Procedure never adopted thereafter - Revoking license would only serve as penalty - Question of quantum of penalty is to be determined on remand - There are 2000 workers in factory - No complaints have been received so far against petitioner - No reason for impugned orders to remain in force.	(Para 24)

heading: Offence by company
Liability of directors
HeadNote.description: Manufacturing of sub-standard injection - Offence by company - Liability of directors - Petition for quashing of criminal case filed by Directors - On ground that complaint does not disclose that they were responsible for business of company - Not a case that applicants had resigned from post of Director - Clear assertion in complaint that applicants carry business of company - That, manufacturing license is in their name - That, during investigation, applicants themselves produced records of manufactured products - Said assertions satisfy requirements of S.34 and clearly show that applicants were responsible for business of accused company - Further, petition u/S.482 is filed after 13 yrs. of complaint - No such objection raised at time of framing of charge - Quashing cannot be allowed.  (Paras 8, 9, 10, 11, 15)

heading: Offence under
HeadNote.description: Offence under - Territorial jurisdiction of Court to try - Drug manufactured in Nagpur - Drug sold in shop at H - Samples obtained at H and proceedings initiated in H - Prosecution against manufacturers of Nagpur in H without impleading owner of drug shop in H as co-accused - Court has jurisdiction and setting aside proceeding by Sessions Court is illegal.	(Para 13)

heading: Right of accused to get sample analyzed by Central Drugs Laboratory
HeadNote.description:
Right of accused to get sample analyzed by Central Drugs Laboratory - Inaction on part of Drugs Inspector and expiry of life of drug - Proceedings are liable to be quashed.

In the instant case, the sample had been analyzed by the Govt. analyst.  In view of the intention of the petitioners and the fact that the expiry date was fast approaching the Drugs Inspector should have taken positive steps to ensure that not only sample was sent at the earliest but he should have ensured that the sample was received by the Central Drugs Laboratory before the date of its expiry.  There is no prohibition under the Act or the Rules barring Inspector from sending sample direct to Central Drug Laboratory.  In the circumstances it has to be held that on account of inaction and lack of diligence on the part of the Drugs Inspector, the valuable right which is vested in the accused under Section 25(4) had been lost.  At any rate, the accused are not to be blamed at all in this process.  It may also be pointed out even when the sample was sent on 05.04.1994, the Drugs Inspector should have requested the Court that the sample in question be sent by hand delivery so that it was received by the Central Drugs Laboratory prior to the date of its expiry.  Hence the continuation of proceedings against the accused persons would amount to abuse of process of law and are required to be quashed.			 [Para 22,23,24]

heading: Blacklisting of Pharmacist
Validity
