HeadNote.description: Blacklisting of Pharmacist - On ground of misbranding of medicine - Validity - Drugs not found to be spurious or adulterated - Medicine not supplied by appellant to respondent, yet show cause notice referred further action in term of tender for supplying misbranded medicine to respondent - In absence of supply by appellant, order of blacklisting invoking clause of tender is fundamental flaw - Reply to show cause notice was not considered by respondent at any stage - Further, show cause notice did not state that action by blacklisting was to be taken, or was under contemplation - If respondent expressed their mind in show cause notice to blacklist, appellant could have filed an appropriate response to same - Order of blacklisting stands vitiated from very inception, liable to be set aside. (Paras 8, 9, 12)

heading: Appointment
Desirable qualification
HeadNote.description:
Appointment - To post of Assistant Commissioner (Drugs) and Drug Inspectors - Desirable qualification - Experience of manufacturing or testing in research and development laboratory is desirable qualification - It cannot be considered as eligible qualification - Said experience gives preference to candidate only if he possess basic eligibility qualification and practical experience in manufacturing and testing of drugs for stipulated period of years.

	In present case challenge is to order of High Court holding that candidates possessing the requisite years of experience in research and development of drugs and testing of the same, are also eligible to be considered for appointment to the post of Assistant Commissioner (Drugs) and Drug Inspectors under separate advertisements dated 04.01.2012 and 31.03.2015.

	The plain reading of the advertisement provides that a degree in Pharmacy or Pharmaceutical Chemistry or in medicine with specialization in Clinical Pharmacology or Microbiology from a University coupled with the requisite years of experience thereafter in manufacturing or testing of drugs were essential qualifications. Preference could be given to those possessing the additional desirable qualification of research experience in the synthesis and testing of drugs in a research laboratory. Manufacture has been defined as a process for making, altering, ornamenting, finishing, packing, labelling, breaking up or otherwise treating or adopting any drug or cosmetic with a view to its sale or distribution. Therefore, the experience of testing has to be correlated to the manufacturing process which naturally will be entirely different from the testing carried out in the research and development laboratory before the product is released for manufacture and sale in the market. To say that experience in testing of drugs in a research and development laboratory would be at par with the testing done at the time of manufacture before sale cannot be countenanced and has to be rejected. The preference clause in Clause 4.7 only means that if a candidate with the required degree qualification and practical experience in the manufacturing and testing of drugs for stipulated period of years has an additional desirable attribute of a research experience in a research laboratory, other things being equal, preference could be given to such a candidate. The term "preference" mentioned in the advertisement cannot be interpreted to mean that merely because a candidate may have had the requisite experience of testing in a research and development laboratory he/she possessed the essential eligibility and had a preferential right to be considered for appointment. 

1996 (6) SCC 282 Rel. on. 				 [Para 12,13,14]

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Running pharmacy without license - Reversal of conviction by revisional court - For non-examination of erstwhile shop owner and license holder - Legality - Documents wherein respondent admitted of having purchased medical shop and running it without license, not considered - In said documents, respondent pleaded that he was not aware of requirement to obtain license in his own name - In his reply notice, he did not disclose names of suppliers but only apologized for his mistake - In view of such admission, non-examination of erstwhile owner, not fatal - Though documents of admission was subsequently denied by contending that signature of respondent was taken on blank page, no complaint made by respondent in this regard either with Police or with higher authorities - Reversal of concurrent findings, not justified - Conviction restored. 		(Paras 9, 10, 12, 13, 15, 16)

heading: Punishment
HeadNote.description: Punishment - For contravention of S.18(c) - Power to award less than minimum sentence - Accused was running pharmacy without license - Considering time gap of 10 yrs. from date of contravention, clear antecedents of accused and his plea of ignorance, sentence of 1 year imprisonment reduced to 3 months only. 	(Para 17)

heading: Prohibition to manufacture of drugs
HeadNote.description:
Prohibition to manufacture of drugs - Exercise of powers by Central Govt. u/S.26A of 1940 Act - Prior consultation of Drugs Technical Advisory Board (DTAB) set up u/S.5 of the Act, not mandatory - Power u/S.26A must be exercised only if it is found necessary or expedient to do so in public interest - Factors to which Central Govt. has to apply its mind to base its satisfaction, stated.

Section 26A of Drugs and Cosmetics Act (1940), has been introduced by an amendment in 1982. A bare reading of this provision would show, firstly, that it is without prejudice to any other provision contained in this Chapter (meaning thereby Chapter IV). This expression only means that apart from the Central Government's other powers contained in Chapter IV, Section 26A is an additional power which must be governed by its own terms. Under Section 26A, the Central Government must be "satisfied" that any drug or cosmetic is likely to involve (i) any risk to human beings or families; or (ii) that any drug does not have the therapeutic value claimed or purported to be claimed for it; or (iii) contains ingredients in such quantity for which there is no therapeutic justification. Obviously, the Central Government has to apply its mind to any or all of these three factors which has to be based upon its "satisfaction" as to the existence of any or all of these factors. The power exercised under Section 26A must further be exercised only if it is found necessary or expedient to do so in public interest. When the power is so exercised, it may regulate, restrict or prohibit manufacture, sale or distribution of any drug or cosmetic.	 [Para 15]

Undoubtedly, Section 26A has to be read with the rest of the Drugs Act. So read, it is clear that unlike Section 6(2), Section 8(2), second proviso to Section 10, proviso to Section 12(1), Section 16(2), proviso to Section 18(2), Section 33 and Section 33N, there is no explicit requirement to consult the Drugs Technical Advisory Board (DTAB) set up under Section 5 of the Drugs Act. The question is did the Parliament do so deliberately or is it something that the Court should read into the provision?	 [Para 16]

	As has been stated hereinabove, Section 26A was brought in by an amendment in 1982. The amendment specifically made changes in Sections 33 and 33N in which it added the words "on the recommendation of the Board". From this, it is clear that Parliament in the very Amendment Act which introduced Section 26A made certain changes which involved the DTAB under Section 5 of the said Act. It is clear that the additional power that is given to the Central Government under Section 26A does not refer to and, therefore, mandate any previous consultation with the DTAB. On the contrary, the Central Government may be "satisfied" on any relevant material that a drug is likely to involve any risk to human beings etc. as a result of which it is necessary in public interest to regulate, restrict or prohibit manufacture, sale or distribution thereof. So long as the Central Government's satisfaction can be said to be based on relevant material, it is not possible to say that not having consulted the DTAB, the power exercised under the said Section would be non est. WP Nos.21933 & 25442/2011 (Mad), (2014) 5 Kant LJ 440 Approved.  [Para 17]

heading: Ban on many Fixed Dose Combinations (FDCs)
HeadNote.description:
Ban on many Fixed Dose Combinations (FDCs) - In view of peculiar facts of the cases, matter sent to Drugs Technical Advisory Board (DTAB) set up u/S.5 of 1940 Act and/or a sub-committee formed by it, for purpose of having a relook into the cases - Appropriate directions issued to DTAB in this regard.

	First and foremost in each case, the DTAB/Sub-Committee appointed by it must satisfy itself that the use of the Fixed Dose Combinations (FDC) in question is likely to involve any one of the aforesaid three things:
(a) 	that they are likely to involve any risk to human beings or animals; or
(b) 	that the said FDCs do not have the therapeutic value claimed or purported to be claimed for them; or
(c) 	that such FDCs contain ingredients and in such quantity for which there is no therapeutic justification.  [Para 33]

The DTAB/Sub-Committee must also apply its mind as to whether it is then necessary or expedient, in the larger public interest, to regulate, restrict or prohibit the manufacture, sale or distribution of such FDCs. In short, the DTAB/Sub-Committee must clearly indicate in its report:
(1) 	as to why, according to it, any one of the three factors indicated above is attracted;
(2) 	post such satisfaction, that in the larger public interest, it is necessary or expedient to (i) regulate, (ii) restrict, or (iii) prohibit the manufacture, sale or distribution of such FDCs.	 [Para 34]

The DTAB/Sub-Committee must also indicate in its report as to why, in case it prohibits a particular FDC, restriction or regulation is not sufficient to control the manufacture and use of the FDC. We request the DTAB/Sub-Committee to be set up for this purpose to afford the necessary hearing to all concerned, and thereafter submit a consolidated report, insofar as these FDCs are concerned, to the Central Government within a period of six months from the date on which this judgment is received by the DTAB. We may also indicate that the Central Government, thereafter, must have due regard to the report of the DTAB and to any other relevant information, and ultimately apply its mind to the parameters contained in Section 26A of the Drugs Act and, accordingly, either maintain the notifications already issued, or modify/substitute them or withdraw them.	 [Para 35]

With these directions given on the peculiar facts and circumstances of these cases, the appeals are disposed of.  [Para 36]

heading: Fixation
HeadNote.description: Retail price of formulation - Fixation - Consideration of data and information furnished by pharmaceutical manufacturers and companies - Drugs (Prices Control) Order shown was aware of different systems of drug delivery, including sustained release - Omission by appellants, manufacturers to show that systems used by them were unique or different - Would not affect their obligation to follow pricing norms and ceiling prices fixed by impugned notifications. 	(Para 12)

heading: Bringing drugs under price control
HeadNote.description:
Bringing drugs under price control - Fixation of annual turnover - It means domestic sales figures and nothing else - Export sales ought to be excluded while calculating the turnover.

'Turnover' in its ordinary sense connotes amount of business usually expressed in terms of gross revenue transacted during a specified period (vide Collins Dictionary).  Broadly speaking, it represents the value of the goods or services sold or supplied during a period of time.  The amount of money turned over or drawn in a business during certain period, is another shade of meaning.  We need not refer to the definition of 'turnover' in Sales Tax and other fiscal enactments as they are not quite relevant for the purpose of understanding the expression 'turnover' occurring in a policy document.  Nor should we seek any assistance from the definition of 'sale turnover' occurring in DPCO in a different context and for a different purpose.  Going by its ordinary meaning and the way in which it is commonly understood in trade and commerce, it is difficult to equate turnover to the value of stock acquired either by means of imports or production.  For instance, the entire stock in trade, say, lying in a godown and not calculated in business, cannot be regarded as turnover, even giving broadest meaning to the expression 'turnover.'  The reasoning which could be spelt out from the order passed by NPPA and in the counter-affidavits filed by the appellants that indigenous production plus imports furnishes an indicia of the total business in the country in relation to a particular bulk drug, cannot be accepted.  It is only what is sold out and marketed that could be legitimately regarded as turnover of the specified drug.  It may be that in the absence of availability of reliable data regarding sales, the import value and production value could be the basis to estimate the sale value after giving due allowance to various factors such as wastage, unsold stocks etc.  But, treating the turnover as nothing but the value of stock produced or imported during a given period will be doing violence to the ordinarily accepted meaning of the expression 'turnover.'	 [Para 5.7]

Para 9 of the Drug Policy, 1994 makes it clear that the high turnover of a drug is an index of its extent of usage.  'Usage' has obvious reference to consumption and consumption within the domestic market.  Whether the drug is extensively used within the country is one of the considerations kept in view to clamp price control.  The export potential of the drug or its usage in foreign countries could not have been the reason to notify the specified drugs for price control. If there is any doubt in this regard, it is dispelled by what is stated in paragraph 10 of the rejoinder affidavit which we quoted supra.  To repeat, it was stated therein that the intent behind using the word 'turnover' has been to determine the extent of usage of a bulk drug in the country.	 [Para 5.8]

heading: Bringing drugs under price control
HeadNote.description: Bringing drugs under price control - Confining expression "formulations" to single ingredient formulations - Does not amount to giving distorted meaning to the expression "formulator" much against the spirit of the policy.	(Para 5.9)

heading: Drugs policy fixing criteria for bringing drugs under price control
HeadNote.description: Drugs policy fixing criteria for bringing drugs under price control - Exercise of discretion by Central Government - Even assuming that discretion is available the factum of exercising discretion for relevant reasons should be disclosed - In the absence of such disclosure Court must proceed on basis that Govt. stood by the criteria and saw no need to deviate there from.	(Para 6)

heading: Inclusion of bulk drugs in the schedule
HeadNote.description:
Inclusion of bulk drugs in the schedule - Petitioners solely relying on ORG data which is neither comprehensive nor conclusive as to turnover of bulk drugs - High Court not examining whether petitioners purposely withheld the data which they were in a position to produce - High Court striking down inclusion of drugs in 1995 order merely because Govt. has failed to effectively rebut averments made by petitioner - In such a situation further probe and analysis was required before striking down inclusion of drugs in the Schedule.

If, on reconsideration, the turnover of any drug is found to be very close to the figure-400 or 100 lacs, as the case may be, the relevant criterion must be deemed to have been satisfied.  Mathematical accuracy is not what is required.	 [Para 8.5,8.6]

heading: Regulation of prices of certain drugs
HeadNote.description: Regulation of prices of certain drugs - State Government has power to revise retail price - Discrepancies in prices of some non-scheduled formulation - Government can revise their retail prices.	(Paras 4 to 6)

heading: Saving clauses under
HeadNote.description: Saving clauses under - Power for recovering amount accrued under DPCO 1979 is saved - Saving clauses are not limited only to the amounts determined - Such an interpretation that saving clauses are limited only to amounts determined would negate the entire policy relating to drug price control - Non-application of S.6 of the General Clauses Act would be of no consequence in view of specific saving clauses. 	(Paras 26, 28)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Inclusion of Drug within purview of Control Order - Validity - Export sales figure considered in deciding to bring drug within price control - Also inclusion made on basis of domestic production figures - Held, such figures irrelevant in deciding inclusion into price control.	(Paras 79, 80)

heading: Increase in admissions
HeadNote.description:
Increase in admissions - Whether one time or permanent - Council is obliged to ensure proportionate increase in infrastructural facilities - This it can do only on receipt of schemes from colleges for approval.

The highest standard of medical education is only possible when the requirement of provisions of Section 10A and the regulations are compiled with. It has been experienced that unless there is required infrastructure available in the medical college, the standard of medical education  has  declined.  Unless  an institution can provide complete and full facilities for training to each student who is  admitted in  various disciplines,  the medical  education  would  remain incomplete and the medical college would be turning out half-baked doctors which, in turn, would adversely affect the health of public in general. Thus, for every increase in the admission capacity either it is one time or permanent, the Council is obliged to ensure a proportionate increase of infrastructure facilities. The Medical Council can only make recommendations to the Central Government for grant of permission for one time intake capacity in seats only when it is satisfied  that scheme to be submitted by the medical colleges fulfills all the requirements. Unless such a scheme providing for all the requirements provided for in the Act and the regulations is submitted to the Central Government and the Medical Council is satisfied that the  scheme  complies  with  all  the requirements and makes a recommendation to that effect, only then the Central Government can consider for grant of permission for increase of admission capacity in a medical college. Similarly, the Central Government without compliance of the Act and the regulations cannot grant, without recommendation of the Medical Council, any permission for one time increase in admission capacity in various courses conducted by the medical colleges.  [Para 9]

heading: Increase in admission capacity of colleges
HeadNote.description:
Increase in admission capacity of colleges - High Court cannot issue direction to Central Government dehors the Statutory provision - Fact that a large number of students already admitted would be dislodged for no fault of theirs if a direction is not issued to Central Government to consider one time increase in admission capacity without ascertaining availability of infrastructural facilities on the basis of schemes submitted by Colleges is no ground for issuing such a direction in exercise of writ jurisdiction - High Court's refusal to issue writ justified.

It is no doubt true that a large number of Students who were already admitted in the colleges and incurred a lot of expenditure in taking  admissions were to be dislodged by issue of the revised merit list. In such a situation one can sympathise with the plight of such students who for no fault of their own were to be dislodged. However, the compassion and sympathy has no role to play where a rule of law is required to be enforced. The High Court has rightly declined to issue any direction to the Central Government to grant one time increase in the admission capacity in the medical colleges, otherwise it would not have been proper exercise of jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution. Adjusting equities in exercise of extraordinary jurisdiction under Article 226 is one thing, and the High Court assuming the role of the Central Government and the Medical Council under Section 10A of the Act is a different thing. The Court cannot direct to waive the mandatory requirement of law in exercise of its extraordinary power under Article 226. It is not permissible for the High Court to direct an authority under the Act to act contrary to the statutory provisions. The power conferred on the High Court by virtue of Article 226 is to enforce the rule of law and ensure that the State and other statutory authorities act in accordance with law. However, it does not mean that the High Court is powerless in that regard. It can do so only when it finds that there was some illegality in the order of the Central Government in refusing to increase the admission capacity in various colleges. The increase  in  admission  capacity  is permissible only when a scheme, in accordance with the regulations, is submitted by a medical college under Section 10A of the Act to the Central Government and the Medical Council is satisfied that the scheme complies with the requirement of the Act and regulations and thereafter   the   Medical   Council recommends for such an increase in admission capacity. So long as the requirements under Section 10A of the Act are not complied with, no permission can be granted by the Central Government. If any direction is issued by the High Court to the Central Government to increase the admission capacity in a medical college, it would be in the teeth of the statutory provisions and amounted to amending the provisions of Section 10A. It is not permissible for the High Court to direct an authority under the Act to act contrary to the statutory provisions. The power conferred on the High Court by virtue of Article 226 is to enforce the rule of law and ensure that the State and other statutory authorities act in accordance with law.					 [Para 11]

heading: Increase in admission capacity
HeadNote.description:
Increase in admission capacity - State Government seeking one time increase in seats in various medical colleges in the State - But scheme complying with S.10A(7) and the regulations by colleges to Central Government not submitted which is mandatory - Refusal by Central Government to permit increase in capacity is justified.

A perusal of the provisions of Section 10A read with regulations shows that it is mandatory on the part of the institution or management desirous of increasing its admission capacity in any course of study to submit a scheme complying with the provisions of sub-section (7) of Section 10A and the requirements envisaged under the regulations. If any of the infrastructure facilities, as required either under sub-section (7) or under the regulations are absent, it is open to the Central Government to refuse permission for increase in the admission capacity in any course of study in a medical college. The object of compliance of requirements mentioned in sub-section (7) of Section 10A and the regulation is to ensure the maintenance of highest standard of education. The compliance of the requirements under the   Act   and  the   regulations  being mandatory,  in  the  absence  of  its compliance, no permission can be granted by the Central Government for increase in admission capacity in any course in any medical college. In the present case, the State Government sought one time increase in admission capacity in various medical colleges on the premise that medical colleges possessed all the facilities. This was not sufficient. What was required, was that medical colleges desirous of one time increase in admission capacity should have submitted  a  scheme  prepared  in accordance with the Act and the regulation to the Central Government. No such scheme was submitted to the Central Government and medical council has no occasion to verify the sufficiency of the facilities and other requirements. There being no compliance of requirements under the Act, the Central Government was justified in refusing the permission for one time increase in the admission capacity in the medical colleges.				 [Para 8]

heading: Essentiality certificate
Withdrawal of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Essentiality certificate - Withdrawal of - Validity - Order withdrawing essentiality certificate and cancelling affiliation passed by Vice Chancellor - As per provision of S.73 of 1998 Act withdrawal or cancellation of affiliation has to be by Academic Council - No provision in 1998 Act permitting delegation of such an obligation - Choice of particular course of action cannot be left open by Academic Council for adjudication or determination of any other authority or on individual - However obligation cast upon council, has been shifted to Vice Chancellor - This abdication is contrary to S.73 of 1998 Act - Withdrawal of essentiality certificate, not proper. 	(Para 15)

heading: Increase in admission capacity
HeadNote.description: Increase in admission capacity - Existing admission capacity not recognized - College is not qualified to make application under Reg.18 - Incomplete application or scheme can be returned by Central Government to the applicant - High Court justified in attaching sanctity to time schedule and in not directing Central Govt. to modify time-schedule. 	(Paras 7, 8, 14)

heading: Admission process
HeadNote.description: Admission process - Power to recognize college or to stop/cancel the admission - Power is vested only in the Central Government under Dentists Act - Registrar of Maharashtra University of Health Sciences does not have jurisdiction to issue such direction to stop the admission process or cancel the admission.	(Para 13)

heading: Notification Dt.6-3-2009
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Notification Dt.6-3-2009 - Validity - Said notification issued under Section 10(4)(b) of the Act entering the Maruas College, Mauritius and its BDS degree, at Sl. No.96 in the III Schedule to the Act is not valid.

Though Mauras College is situated outside India, the BDS students of the Mauras College who successfully complete the course of study and pass the examination conducted by the Bhavnagar University possess the dental qualifications awarded by an authority in India (namely Bhavnagar University). They do not possess any dental qualification awarded by an authority or institution outside India. Section 10(4) of the Act will apply only if the dental qualification is granted by an authority or institution outside India, and as a consequence, such qualification will have to be listed under Part-III of the Schedule to the Act. The respondents do not dispute the fact that the BDS examinations for the students of Mauras College are held by Bhavnagar University and the degrees are also granted by Bhavnagar University and not by any authority or institution outside India. So long as the Mauras College is affiliated to Bhavnagar University and the said University is the examining body and is the authority which grants the BDS degree dental qualification to the students of Mauras College, Section 10(4) and Part-III of the Schedule to the Act will not apply. As Bhavnagar University is not an authority outside India, the dental qualifications granted by it cannot be included in Part-III of the Schedule to the Act even if the college/institution affiliated to the said University is outside India. Therefore the notification dated 6.3.2009 is illegal being contrary to and violative of section 10(1) and (4) of the Act and liable to be struck down.   [Para 11,12,19]

HeadNote.sub_clause: Ss.20, 10(4), (5) read with Dental Council of India Screening Test Regulations (2009)
heading: Screening test
HeadNote.description:
Screening test - BDS graduates from Mauras College affiliated to Bhavnagar University, Gujarat need not have to take the screening test under the DCI Screening Regulations, 2009, for recognition of their BDS degrees in India.

The BDS degrees granted by the Bhavnagar University to the students of Mauras College of Dentistry at Mauritius shall be treated as a recognized dental qualification granted by an authority in India governed by section 10(1) of the Act, if Mauras College, Mauritius is added by the Central Government as an affiliated institution under Column (2) of Entry 62 in Part-I of the Schedule to the Act. In such an event, the holders of such degree will be entitled to all benefits and advantages as persons holding recognized dental qualifications under section 10(1) of the Act and need not undergo the screening test under the DCI Screening Test Regulations 2009. Thus, Unless and until Mauras College is included as an affiliated institution in Column (2) of Entry 62 in Part-I of the Schedule to the Act, the Indian students of Mauras College of Mauritius will have to undergo a screening test as per the first proviso to Regulation (4) of DCI Screening Test Regulations, 2009.   [Para 19]

heading: BDS Course
HeadNote.description: BDS Course - Power of DCI to frame rules providing maximum period for completion of course, whereas Dentist Act not providing for the same - DCI by amendment dt.27/4/2015, has put limit of 9 yrs. for clearing entire BDS course including internship of one year - Thereby, substituted earlier rule putting restriction of 3 yrs. for clearing BDS 1st year course - DCI had authority to make such provision in exercise of powers u/S.20 of Dentists Act - Said amendment approved by Central Govt. - DCI by framing such rules not acted inconsistent with provisions of Dentists Act. WP No.8351/2013, dt.29/10/2015 (Aur.) Rel. on. 	(Paras 24, 25, 27)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description: Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch of MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - DCI found deficiencies on inspection - In ad interim order also this Court did not permit petitioner to admit students for 1st year of new session 2013-14 - Though ad interim order was not challenged, it cannot be reason for not granting reliefs at final stage on hearing of both parties. 	(Para 30)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description: Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch of MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - DCI found deficiencies on inspection - Communication invoked by respondent no. 1 invoking S.10-A (4) by which concerned parties were called upon for personal hearing to decide about renewal of permission - It means mode of personal hearing is not foreign - Submission that no such procedure is available under Act - Submission liable to be rejected. 			(Para 35)

heading: Non renewal of permission
HeadNote.description:
Non renewal of permission - Permission for 3rd batch to the MDS (O.M.F.C.) course was not renewed - Also new admissions were restricted - Ground that DCI found deficiencies on inspection - Whereas the earlier two batches were permitted admission on same infrastructure - Respondents are directed to reconsider action of non granting renewal.

In the instant case permission was granted to 1st and 2nd batch on basis of same infrastructure and material on which earlier two batches were granted permission. Right was curtailed without assigning any reasons for composite action. Decision taken as without considering legal rights of all concerned parties. Another facet of principles of natural is that merely because DCI is expert body, it is not sufficient and that itself does not empower them to pass unreasoned and unsupportive order. Deficiencies are not reason to discontinue important final year course of 1st batch and 2nd batch. Same reason cannot be reason for not admitting students of 3rd batch. Renewal of yearly permission cannot be equated to fresh initial permission. Submission that order is restricted to 3rd year new batch is self contradictory. Respondents are directed to reconsider action of non granting renewal.  		          		         [Para 36,37]

heading: Expulsion from membership
HeadNote.description:
Expulsion from membership - Scope of jurisdiction under Art.227 - Expulsion of members from housing society for default in payment of dues - High Court upholding expulsion order - Counsel for members making request to direct society to allot vacant apartments to members - Request was conceded by counsel without any express authorization by society - Court also made no query about such authorization with the counsel - Held, in absence of such caution High Court was not justified in issuing direction for additional quarters.

In the present case, what was challenged by the members of the Society was an order passed by the Registrar and the Revisional Authority under the provisions of the Act and the Rules framed thereunder. The prayer was to set aside the orders passed by the authorities below. Even if the said petitions(s) were styled as a petition under Article 226, the content and the prayers thereunder being ones requiring exercise of supervisory jurisdiction only, could be treated as petitions filed under Article 227 of the Constitution only. The Court, while, exercising its powers under Article 227 ought to have confined itself to the subject matter and the issues raised by parties in the Writ Petition. The digression of or expansion of the supervisory jurisdiction under Article 227 would open precarious floodgates of litigation should the limitation on the supervisory jurisdiction not be observed mindfully. If for any reason, the Writ Court perceived the oral request made by the respondents to have justified the ends of justice and desired to accept the concession so made by the counsel for appellant-Society, the said request not being the subject matter of the Writ Petition required the Court to query whether the counsel for the appellant-Society has been authorized to make such a statement by the appellant-Society or whether any such resolution has been passed by the appellant-Society giving concession in matters of this nature. Since the required caution was not exercised by the learned Judges of the Writ Court, the directions issued by the Writ Court suffer from infirmity and hence require to be set aside.    [Para 18,21,22]

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Auction sale of mortgaged property - Setting aside by DRAT - On ground that said property was only property left with borrower and that he has already paid amount to auction purchaser at which he has purchased property - Validity - Auction sale was already confirmed by Recovery Officer - Sale deed was also executed in favour of auction purchaser - Further, DRAT was only in seisin of issue of transfer of proceedings and not merit of dispute - Setting aside of auction sale, improper. 	(Paras 5, 6, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Development Authority (Disposal of Developed Nazul Land) Rules (1981)
heading: Lease of Nazul land
HeadNote.description:
Lease of Nazul land - Termination by efflux of time - Subsequent acceptance of rent by Development Authority - Would not amount to an automatic renewal of lease.

2005(5) ALL MR 848 (S.C.), 2006(3) ALL MR 211 (S.C.), (1990) 4 SCC 406 Rel. on. (Para 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Development Authority (Disposal of Developed Nazul Land) Rules (1981)
heading: Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act (1971), Ss.2(e), 2(g), 5
HeadNote.description:
Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act (1971), Ss.2(e), 2(g), 5 - Transfer of Property Act (1882), Ss.113, 116 - Lease of Nazul land - Granted by Delhi Development Authority (DDA) - Lease deed effective for 20 years and renewable for further 20 years - Clause in lease deed provided for renewal upon 6 months prior request of lessee and acceptance thereof by DDA - Pending such request for renewal, DDA notified breach of lease condition and asked lessee to rectify the same - Upon failure of lessee, renewal of lease declined and notice of termination issued - However, no further action taken and DDA accepted rent for subsequent months when respondent continued to occupy the premises - Held, even on acceptance of rent by DDA, lease would not be renewed - Intention of non renewal is clear from notice of breach and termination notice - Suit premise is a "public premise" within meaning of S.2(e) and respondent is "unauthorized occupant" u/S.2(g) of Public Premises Act, liable to pay damages - Impugned order perpetually restraining DDA from taking any action under termination notice - Is erroneous and liable to be set aside.

2005(5) ALL MR 848 (S.C.), 2006(3) ALL MR 211 (S.C.), (1990) 4 SCC 406 Rel. on. (Paras 25, 27, 29, 30, 31, 34, 35)

heading: Land acquisition
Non-payment of compensation
Justifiability
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Non-payment of compensation - Justifiability - Sale of acquired land subsequent to S.6 notification - Plea that due to dispute between original owner and the subsequent purchaser, compensation could neither be tendered nor paid - Held, such subsequent sale being illegal by virtue of S.4 of Delhi Act, said plea is of no avail - Moreover, authorities were not in dilemma at all as to who should be paid - Therefore, non payment of compensation not justified. (2008) 9 SCC 177 Ref. to.	(Para 23)

heading: Scheme of granting and utilization of TDR under Reg.67(6) is different from that under Reg.33 (7)
HeadNote.description: Scheme of granting and utilization of TDR under Reg.67(6) is different from that under Reg.33 (7) - Plans under Regulation 67 cannot be approved except for repairs and reconstruction and not for redevelopment - Whereas "reconstruction" implies re-erecting the structure exactly as it was, without any change, the term "redevelopment" involves an erection of a new structure with a completely new plan, dimensions etc. 	(Para 70)

heading: Development plan
Legality
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Arts.226, 227 - Development plan - Allotment of Plots reserved for open space/garden to respondent trust by MHADA - Legality - Subject plots are sub-plots of bigger plot nos. 3 and 6 - Layouts sanctioned by BMC in 1967 showing subject plots as kept reserved for garden - However, in revised development plan dt.15/10/1999 said bigger plot nos.3 and 6 shown as plots of Housing Society but internal sub-division of said big plots not shown - Error appeared in revised plan - MHADA itself sent proposal to MCGM for rectification of said revised layout plan - However, officer of MHADA overlooking approval of his predecessor in office, passed impugned order holding that respondent Trust has complete and absolute right to nominate, select and reject beneficiary of sub-plots of said big plots - Impugned action is violative of doctrine of public trust and order suffers from "procedural impropriety" - Hence, impugned order, quashed and set aside. 			(Paras 38, 39, 40, 45, 48)

heading: Development plan
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Arts.226, 227 - Development plan - Allotment of Plots reserved for open space/garden to respondent trust by MHADA - Plots required to be kept for open space as per DCR 1967 and also as per DCR 1991 - Action of MHADA parting away with said plots giving enormous benefit to private parties without public exchequer getting slightest benefit thereof - Would come within ambit of "irrationality" - Impugned order set aside. 	(Para 63)

heading: Development plan
HeadNote.description: Development plan - Reservation for open space - DCR 1967 and also DCR 1991 required certain part of land to be kept as an open space - Plots reserved for open space in layout plan are sub-plots of a bigger plot - Affidavit by MHADA showing said bigger plot to be residential area, would not mean that area reserved for open space can also be used for construction - Such affidavit cannot make statutory provisions redundant , and that itself will not take away reservation of open area in a layout. 			(Para 59)

heading: Demolition of building
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Demolition of building - Challenge to - Ground that building is declared as proposed Grade II-B heritage structure in list published by Municipal Corporation - Decision as to gradation of building as recommended by concerned authority is to be taken by State Govt. - They have to apply their mind not only to recommendations made by various authorities and suggestions but also to consider objections raised if any - No such decision on gradation of building taken by State Govt. - Matter remanded back with direction to State Govt. to make it clear whether building in question is Grade II-B or Grade III heritage structure or only part of heritage precinct. 	(Paras 35, 36, 37, 38)

heading: Impermissible
HeadNote.description: Scheme for cluster development - Inclusion of petitioner Housing Society in redevelopment scheme only on suggestions of neighbouring societies - Without obtaining consent of petitioner and without even hearing petitioner - Impermissible - Petitioner's choice as to nature of development they desire and propose are left open. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: issuance of Development Right Certificate (DRC)/Transferable Development Right (TDR) - Challenge - Owner of plot of land which is reserved for public purpose is eligible for award of DRC - Municipal Corporation has issued DRC to respondent for construction of road on a part of his land reserved for public purpose - Further, quality and rates of construction work of road undertaken by respondent is to the satisfaction of Municipal Corporation - Work completed by respondent as per Development Control Regulations - Grant of DRC to respondent, proper. 	(Para 11)

heading: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules (1955), Rr.58, 102
HeadNote.description:
Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Rules (1955), Rr.58, 102 - Property vesting in Govt. - Declaration under S.38E of Tenancy Act in favour of person - Has to be totally ignored - Property is unencumbered in hands of Govt.

In view of S.102A of Tenancy Act the land which is vested in the Government and which is held by the Government, has to be left out of consideration while applying the provisions of the Tenancy Act, 1950, to any land. In short, the provisions of the Tenancy Act are to be made applicable to the land held by the Government. It is not in dispute that the property in question, no doubt, stood vested in the Government, in pursuance of the provisions of the 1950 Act and, therefore, even if there happened to be a declaration under section 38E of the Tenancy Act in favour of the petitioner, that has to be totally ignored while applying the provisions of the 1950 Act and 1954 Act. Thus, even though a declaration is there in favour of the petitioner, that will have to be totally ignored for all practical purposes and the property will have to be held to be totally unencumbered into the hands either of the Custodian or the Settlement Commissioner under the provisions of 1950 Act or manager under the provisions of 1954 Act.					 [Para 13]

heading: Vesting by way of conveyance
HeadNote.description:
Vesting by way of conveyance - Survey report as well as minutes of the meeting of screening committee showing that petitioner was entitled to regularisation of his occupation - Deed of conveyance duly executed in his favour - Secretary cannot reopen the case by setting aside the conveyance.

AIR 1979 Bom 143, Decision in W.P.No.5091/1987 dt. 19.996 (Bom), Decision in W.P. No. 3174/89 dt. 17.10.1996 (Bom) and Decision in W.P.NO.4681/1985 dt. 6.11.1992 Rel.on. (Para 6)

heading: Land acquired under S.12
HeadNote.description: Land acquired under S.12 - Allotment of land to petitioner - Some excess land allotted to petitioner than he was entitled to - Petitioner asked to deposit the cost of excess land and obtain possession - No steps taken by petitioner and same land was allotted to other person for defaults of petitioner - Managing officer had power to cancel allotment and delegate powers to collector to take possession of such property - Such person asked to approach Collector for possession - Managing Officer's power stand delegated.	(Paras 7,11)

heading: Scope of
HeadNote.description: Scope of - Regularisation of open space - Powers of State Government - Once vesting of property takes place in favour of a person by way of a conveyance, it is not open for the State Government to set aside the conveyance by resorting to S.33 - S.33 has no application after vesting of property taking place in favour of a person by way of conveyance. 1997(1) ALL MR 694, 1997 (2) Bom. C.R. 662 and AIR 1979 Bom. 243 - Followed. 	 (Para 3)

heading: Allotment of land
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land - Enquiry as to whether predecessor-in-interest of claimant had left land in Pakistan when they migrated to India is necessary - High Court could not have issued a direction to the State to straightaway allot the land. C.W.P. No.14050 of 1998, Dt.13-7-2000 (P&H) - Reversed.	(Paras 4, 5, 8)

heading: Refusal to accept
HeadNote.description:
Allotment of agricultural land - Refusal to accept - Provisions of R.61 operate only when there is express refusal to accept the allotment of any agricultural land - The consequence prescribed is that the claim of such allottee for compensation to that extent is deemed to have been satisfied - Such land then becomes available for allotment to any other claimant - Therefore, held, even if allotment is refused, the claim towards compensation is deemed to have been satisfied and thus in statement of accounts his entitlement to compensation gets reduced to that extent.

(1995) 5 SCC 302 - Ref. to. (Para 19)

heading: Title dispute
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Title dispute - Declaration by Managing Officer that sale certificate issued in favour of respondent is genuine whereas claim of other party that suit property was purchased by them from Custodian of Evacuee Property is not genuine - Appeal against - Ground that an authority under Displaced Persons Act has no jurisdiction to decide validity of sale by another authority under Evacuee Property Act - Respondent had produced various documents viz. receipt of deposit, acceptance letter, sale certificate etc. to support her title - However, no evidence nor even sale certificate produced by appellant - In absence of any evidence, contention as to jurisdiction cannot be considered - Reliance placed on findings of earlier civil suit (filed by husband of respondent), that suit property is Evacuee Property - Would be of no avail, because, respondent herself was not a party to said suit - Appeal dismissed. 	(Paras 9, 13, 14)

heading: Acquisition of evacuee property
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of evacuee property - Vesting of property in Central Govt. free from all encumbrances - As soon as notification is published property ceases to be evacuee property. Administration of Evacuee Property Act (1950), S.7.			(Paras 106, 107, 111)

heading: Revisional Power of Chief Settlement Commissioner
HeadNote.description: Revisional Power of Chief Settlement Commissioner - Has no jurisdiction to revise order passed by Collector-cum-Dy. Custodian under Evacuee Property Act. Administration of Evacuee Property Act (1950), S.7.			(Paras 110, 111)

heading: Allotment of land to displaced persons
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land to displaced persons - Evacuee land forming part of compensation pool - Transferred to State Govt. - Officers of State Govt. entrusted with functions of Managing Officer or Settlement Commissioner - Chief Commissioner of Land Administration Andhra Pradesh as delegate of Central Govt. has no power to make allotment of land forming part of compensation pool which stood transferred to State Govt. 	(Paras 28, 29, 30)

heading: Evacuee land transferred to State Govt.
HeadNote.description: Evacuee land transferred to State Govt. - Continues to be part of compensation pool - To be disposed of by empowered officers of the State - Only after displaced persons are settled, the State Govt. may utilize the land for other purposes. 	(Para 31)

heading: Time limit
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land to displaced persons - To make good verified claim - Time limit - Predecessor-in-interest of appellant had not raised any grievance during his lifetime and for more than 13 years of his death - Appellant cannot agitate issue which have attained finality - Successor in interest is also required to file claim before date fixed by S.4.			(Para 32)

heading: Allotment of land to displaced persons
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land to displaced persons - Appellant, Successor-in-interest of claimant not entitled to equivalent land as is verified claim.	(Para 33)

heading: Transfer of evacuee land to State Govt.
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of evacuee land to State Govt. - Lack of use of expression "package deal" - Will not change nature of transfer which is in terms of S.16 of Displaced Persons Act with date of transfer specified as June 1, 1980 in terms of R.34 of Rules.

The lack of use of expression ‘package deal’ will not change the nature of transfer which is in terms of Section 16 of the Act with the date of transfer specified as June 1, 1980 in terms of Rule 34 of the Rules. The transfer of land forming part of compensation pool is contemplated by Section 16 of the Act, when it provides that for the custody, management and disposal of the compensation pool, the Central Government constitute such authority or corporation. Thus, if the Central Government could transfer land forming part of the compensation pool to a corporation, then it could very well transfer land to a State Government.			(Para 35)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Merely because a property vests in custodian does not mean that the property vests in the Central Govt - Evacuee property does not belong to Central Govt - Property can be acquired, not just under S.12 but even under Land Acquisition Act - Land Acquisition Act (1894), S.4.	(Para 15)

heading: Show cause notice under S.19
HeadNote.description: Show cause notice under S.19 - Assistant Custodian functioning under Administration of Evacuee Properties Act empowered to act as Managing Officer - He can validly issue show cause notice under S.19.	(Para 5)

heading: Show cause notice under
HeadNote.description: Show cause notice under - Petitioner evacuee allotted premises in 1950 as Managing Director of a company on condition of not sub-letting or assigning right title or interest therein - When company was wound up premises were transferred in the personal name of petitioner in 1959 and thereafter rent receipts were issued by Custodian in personal name of petitioner - Held, authorities had waived condition in the letter of allotment when they accepted transfer in the name of petitioner who was successor in interest of the company and hence show cause notice issued after a lapse of 40 years was liable to be quashed.			(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Power to call for record of any proceeding under the Act
HeadNote.description: Power to call for record of any proceeding under the Act - Power is vested with Central Government - Exercise of such power by Secretary to Government of Maharashtra, held, is without jurisdiction.	(Para 8)

heading: Powers of review
HeadNote.description: Powers of review - Powers cannot be exercised after a conveyance has been executed and purchase price has been paid. 1997(1) ALL MR 694 - Rel. on.	(Para 8)

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Exercise of power under S.33 - Limitation for - No period of limitation has been prescribed in S.33 - Therefore it would be open to Government to call for the record at any time in any proceedings and pass orders which in its opinion required to be passed - However, such powers cannot be exercised after inordinate delay of 5 years - Where limitation is not prescribed in the statute Government is expected to act within reasonable period and not after inordinate delay. AIR 1969 SC 1297 - Ref. to.	(Para 9)

heading: Acquisition of evacuee property
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of evacuee property - Private person having interest in such property - Property can be acquired under L.A. Act even though it is owned by Government - Properties that vest in custodian as evacuee properties can be acquired for some other public purpose.
(2003) 10 SCC 321 Rel. on. (Paras 45, 46)

heading: Effect
HeadNote.description: Administration of Evacuee Property Act (1950), S.8 - Issuance of notification u/S.12 of DPCR Act - Effect - Subject land ceases to be evacuee property after publication of notification - Consequently exemption clause in S.4 notification excluding evacuee land, will have no application. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Evacuee property
HeadNote.description: Evacuee property - Land vesting in Central Govt. after notification u/S.12 and ceasing to be evacuee property - Such land though vesting in Central Govt. itself can be acquired under the provisions of Land Acquisition Act. 	(Para 18)

heading: Tenancy right
HeadNote.description:
Leasehold rights in evacuee property - Tenancy right - A person in possession of an evacuee property or acquired evacuee property - Cannot claim any tenancy right under the Transfer of Property Act. 

AIR 1961 Bom 69; (1997) 4 SCC 382 - Ref. to. 	(Para 16)

heading: Notice under S.19
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of the property under the Act and its declaration as evacuee property - Notice under S.19 - Notice is directory and not mandatory. (Para 17)

heading: Maharashtra Tenancy and Agricultural Lands (Vidarbha Region) Act (1958), Ss.19, 46
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Tenancy and Agricultural Lands (Vidarbha Region) Act (1958), Ss.19, 46 - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - To entertain prayer for injunction thereby restraining defendants from interfering with possession of plaintiff over suit land - Plaintiffs-lessee of suit land claiming to have purchased suit land under Act of 1958 - Respondent declared that suit land is evacuee property - U/S.12 of Act of 1950, custodian has power to cancel any allotment - Power u/S.12 can be exercised only after issuance of notice u/S.7 - Respondent claiming compliance of provisions of law by issuance of two notices to plaintiffs - Both notices do not refer to cancellation of lease existing in favour of predecessor-in-title of plaintiffs - Procedure prescribed by law was not followed - When procedure has not been followed, plaintiffs have right to approach Civil Court for injunction not to dispossess unless procedure is followed - Court can consider prayer for injunction. (Paras 18, 19, 21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27, 32)

heading: Maharashtra Tenancy and Agricultural Lands (Vidarbha Region) Act (1958), Ss. 19, 46, 128
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Tenancy and Agricultural Lands (Vidarbha Region) Act (1958), Ss. 19, 46, 128 - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - To entertain suit seeking declaration of ownership - Plaintiffs predecessor-in-title was agricultural tenant of suit land - Plaintiffs claiming to have purchased land under Act of 1958 - Suit land was declared as evacuee property by Deputy Custodian prior to predecessor-in-title of plaintiff asserting his right to purchase land - Suit land was vested in Custodian - S.46 of Act of 1950 bars jurisdiction of Civil Court to decide question of legality of action taken by Custodian - S.128 of Act of 1958 also says that you cannot claim right to purchase against Govt. - Plaintiff cannot seek declaration of their ownership from Civil Court - Jurisdiction of Civil Court is ousted. (Paras 29, 30, 31, 32)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for City of Nagpur (2000)
heading: Loading/use of T.D.R.
HeadNote.description:
Loading/use of T.D.R. - On plots regularized under Gunthewari Act - Not permissible, even if the owner/ occupier has loaded/ used a valid T.D.R. after purchasing it from others. 

In the scheme of Gunthewari Act, the person who surrenders his marginal space for road is not entitled to claim any compensation. Free surrender of 10% plots [if unsold and unbuilt] in such layout, is also a condition for enjoying the concession. Thus the owner or occupier of such plots regularized in gunthewari development cannot earn any T.D.R. in relation to such surrender. Purchase of otherwise valid T.D.R. by respective petitioners, is not in dispute. They are having necessary development rights certificate (DRC) and they have annexed the same along with their revised building plan for sanction. However, regulation no.29.10 shows that the D.R.C. is not valid for use on receivable plots in areas which are listed thereunder and identified as no T.D.R. zone. The fact that T.D.R. cannot be used in agricultural zone or prohibited zone or restricted zone, is apparent from Clause [f] of regulation no.29.10.

Use of T.D.R. by persons like petitioners, whose developments have been regularized by showing leniency will add to mischief which is sought to be controlled or eradicated by enactment like Gunthewari Act, 2001. It may defeat proper up-gradation in gunthewari regularized areas. Drastic measures like surrender of even marginal space lying open to sky by plot owner/occupier to enable construction of public road and denial of compensation for such surrender in Gunthewari Act, itself prove inability of such owner/occupier to earn any TDR therefor. When Legislation has denied him TDR for land so surrendered during gunthewari regularization, the intent behind the same shall stand defeated, if TDR purchased elsewhere is allowed to be loaded on such gunthewari regularized plots.   [Para 30,31]

heading: Review
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Application for recovery of debt - Review - Limitation - Provisions of Limitation Act as applicable to Tribunal apply only to original application to recover debts u/S.19 - Application for review, cannot be said to be filed u/S.19 - Said application dealt u/S.22(c) r.w. R.5A.

	Review petitions are dealt with in Section 22(2)(e) read with Rule 5A of the Rules. Section 24, which applies the provisions of the Limitation Act to applications made to a Tribunal, would, as per the definition section contained in Section 2(b), apply only to applications that are made under Section 19, which are original applications to recover debts that are made by banks and financial institutions. What is clear is that an application for review cannot possibly be said to be an application filed under Section 19 even on a cursory reading of the provisions of the Act, as it traces its origin to Section 22(2)(e) read with Rule 5A of the Rules. 

	An appeal under Section 30(1) is an appeal to the Tribunal against orders of the Recovery Officer made under the Act. The reason why Rule 2(c) of the Rules defines application as including an application under Section 31A and an appeal filed under Section 31 of the Act, apart from applications filed under Section 19, is because under Rule 4 of the Rules, the procedure for filing such applications/appeal is under Forms I to III appended to the Rules. What is important to note is that even this extended definition, under the Rules, does not include an application for review filed under Rule 5A of the Rules. In point of fact, Rule 7 makes it abundantly clear that each such application, including applications for review, are viewed separately and independently, as fees payable for filing such applications are vastly different, as is clear from Rule 7(2).

	The peremptory language of Rule 5A would also make it clear that beyond 30 days there is no power to condone delay. Rule 5A was added in 1997 with a longer period within which to file a review petition, namely, 60 days. This period was cut down, by amendment, with effect from 04.11.2016, to 30 days. From this two things are clear: one, whether in the original or unamended provision, there is no separate power to condone delay, as is contained in Section 20(3) of the Act; and second, that the period of 60 days was considered too long and cut down to 30 days thereby evincing an intention that review petitions, if they are to be filed, should be within a shorter period of limitation - otherwise they would not be maintainable.

2017 ALL SCR 2366 Foll.	(Paras 6, 9, 10, 12, 14)

heading: Recovery of debts
HeadNote.description: Recovery of debts - Amounts due by borrower to lender institutions set out in profit and loss account - Amounts to admission of debt by borrower - Would be binding on the borrower - Order for recovery by Tribunal u/s.19(20) and R.12(5) is proper - Expression "admission" in R.12(5) can be read to mean an admission both in pleadings, proceeding or as evidenced by a document. Civil P.C. (1908), O.12, R.5 - Evidence Act (1872), Ss.17, 18, 21 - Companies Act (1956), Ss.210, 211(5), 215, 216.	(Para 8)

heading: Right of cross-examination of witness
HeadNote.description:
Right of cross-examination of witness - Right is not unqualified and absolute - It is circumscribed by certain circumstances present for enabling a party to exercise such right - Tribunal, if satisfied, can allow such right of cross-examination.

There is no unqualified or absolute right vested in party to have cross-examination and for that purpose a case will have to be made out and foundation will have to be laid by stating precisely on what points cross-examination is necessary.  In a given case there may be issues of facts which may require oral examination and therefore grant of permission to have oral evidence would depend upon facts and circumstances of each case.  Since in this case, the appellant has not stated necessary facts before claiming such right and sought to cross-examine the witnesses as absolute right, the Presiding Officer was justified in rejecting the application.  [Para 17]

It is not that the questions which are to be asked in cross-examination, are required to be disclosed but points or issues on which oral examination or cross-examination was necessary should have been stated in the application or at least explained in the arguments before the Tribunal; so that the same could have been examined and propriety of cross-examination could have been ascertained.  The statement in the application that having regard to the defence raised by the appellant in his written statement he desired cross-examination of the witnesses is omnibus and does not pinpoint contentions in regard to which cross-examination is necessary. [Para 11]

heading: Recovery of debt
HeadNote.description: Recovery of debt - Place of filing application R.6(a) relates to place where cause of action wholly or partly arises - No bank can file application at a place where defendant is not residing or not carrying on business or cause of action wholly or partly has not arisen - Hence R.6(a) is not ultra vires S.19.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Registration of application
HeadNote.description: Registration of application - Refusal, on ground of its maintainability - Registrar is only empowered to scrutinize application and consider whether it suffers from defect and if found any defect then allow party to rectify such defect - Registrar has no jurisdiction to decide maintainability of application - It can be decided by Debt Recovery Tribunal. 	(Para 6)

heading: Leave to cross-examine
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Leave to cross-examine - Permissibility - MSFC has instituted several applications against respondents-guarantors to loans advanced by MSFC to more than 500 persons - At time of final argument, respondents sought leave to cross-examine MFSC's officer on basis of his affidavit filed on record - Same was declined by DRT on ground of unexplained and inordinate delay in seeking leave - However, DRAT set aside order of DRT merely observing that matter had been protracted for 20 long years - DRAT failed to observe issue of delay and impact of its order on several other cases arising out of very same transaction - Also, it failed to advert to condition precedent contained under R.12(6) - Order of DRAT set aside and order of DRT restored. 2014 ALL SCR 61, 2008(3) Bom. C.R. 889, (2002) 4 SCC 275 Ref. to. 	 (Paras 6, 7, 8, 10)

heading: Plural remedies
Cause of action
What constitutes
Consequential relief
HeadNote.description:
Plural remedies - Cause of action - What constitutes - Consequential relief - Meaning of.

Term "cause of action" has been used in two places namely in Section 31 of "the Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act, 1993" and this rule 10 of the Procedure Rules. But nowhere it is defined either in the Act or Rules. Even the Code of Civil Procedure does not define the said expression.  [Para 9]

It is not that Rule 10 altogether prohibits joining different and distinct causes of action but condition in that behalf is that, reliefs prayed for, shall be consequential to one another. Thus, if the reliefs are consequential to one another, then, claim based on more than single cause of action can be joined in single application. Words "reliefs prayed for are consequential to one another" is not to be confused with the words "consequential reliefs". In considering whether Rule 10 of the Procedure Rules applies and whether the suit of the bank is hit by the same, all the averments made by the plaintiff in the plaint should be considered and it would not be proper to go simply by enumaration of transactions.  [Para 11,13]

In this case in the given loan facility there were certain transactions. First letter dated 12-5-1993 mentions that the defendants were enjoying following limits; (1) Packing Credit Limited Rs. 5 lacs, (2) FDBP/ FUBP Rs. 15 lacs and they have requested for renewal and enhancement of Packing credit Limit and other two facilities. Second letter dated 3-12-1993 also shows that the defendants enjoyed various facilities including FUBP. Thus, it cannot be said that these were independent transactions and without any documents facilities were granted by the bank. It is not that without any letter like Page No. 49 and 51, the defendants just gave foreign bills and the plaintiff-bank purchased the same and thereafter, each bill purchased, was dishonoured, so that it can be said that there were four different transactions. In a facility known as F.U.B.P. (Foreign Usance Bills Purchase), the defendants gave bills to the Plaintiff bank and the plaintiff-bank purchased the same by crediting account of the defendants and when the bills were dishonoured, claim in that facility, is made by the plaintiff-bank to the tune of Rs. 42,70,469/-. The Learned Presiding Officer has lost sight of this fact and simply took these four bills as independent transactions and rested his decision on that basis without considering earlier averments in that behalf. As such, at least this claim of Rs. 42,70,469/- was clearly within the pecuniary jurisdiction of the Debts Recovery Tribunal. Four bills dishonoured constitutes transactions in the facility of foreign usance bills purchased and as such constitutes only one cause of action.  [Para 13]

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Claim for relief under DV Act - Filed by Muslim woman in a proceeding under Dissolution of Muslim Marriage Act - Maintainability - Scheme of the Act does not restrict its applicability to particular category of women who are victims of domestic violence, nevertheless to woman belonging to particular religion - S.26 permits relief to be availed under DV Act to be sought in any legal proceedings before Civil Court, Family Court or Criminal Court affecting aggrieved person - Relief sought under DV Act in proceedings for divorce on ground of cruelty which is also domestic violence - Hence, claim held maintainable. 			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Interim maintenance
HeadNote.description: Interim maintenance - Application by Muslim wife - Husband contended that he gave talaq and remarried under presumption that wife has accepted same as she is also seeking divorce - Wife has disputed pronouncement of talaq - Factum of talaq is not proved till date and therefore, marriage cannot be said to have been dissolved - Even assuming that marriage stands dissolved, husband cannot be completely absolved of his liability to maintain his wife and children, especially when he is maintaining two children of wife whom he had remarried - Interim maintenance granted. 2017 ALL SCR 1892 Ref. to. 	(Para 9)

heading: Child marriage
HeadNote.description: Hindu Marriage Act (1955), S.13(2)(iv) - Child marriage - Repudiation under personal laws - For a marriage which is void under Child Marriage Act, a girl has to seek its annulment under personal law that too before attaining majority - Failure to amend personal laws has resulted in this anomalous situation - Child Marriage Act being a secular Act, will prevail over personal laws. 			(Paras 124, 125, 126)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Execution of decree
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Neglect and cruelty alleged by wife - Decree for divorce in terms of settlement between parties passed - Husband agreeing to pay lumpsum Rs.2,00,000/- for maintenance but defaulted - Execution of decree - Ordered appointment of Receiver and sale of shop of husband as provided in consent terms.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.51(d), O.21, R.11. Bombay High Court (Original Side) Rules, R.331.

A suit filed by a Muslim wife for dissolution of marriage, alleging cruelty and neglect : Later the parties arrived at settlement whereunder it was inter alia agreed that the marriage between them be dissolved with immediate effect and that the husband shall pay Rs.2,00,000/- to the wife for maintenance of herself and their two minor daughters.  Accordingly decree for dissolution of marriage was passed.  But the husband did not pay the amount on or before the stipulated date.  One of the clauses of the Consent Terms restrained the husband to sell/encumber his shop till payment was made.

Held, though there is no provision in the Dissolution of Muslim Marriages Act, 1939, for obtaining divorce by consent of both parties, by not refuting the allegations made by the wife in the Plaint with respect to cruelty and neglect and by filing Consent Terms inter alia for the maintenance of the children, the Defendant husband has sort of submitted to decree and is deemed to have accepted all the allegations made against him and therefore, the decree is actually deemed to have been passed under Section 2(ii) of the Dissolution of Muslim Marriages Act, 1939.  Moreover, the Court cannot and should not show leniency to a father who does not care for the welfare of his children.  The Plaintiffs are decree holders and are entitled for appointment of Receiver, as per Section 51(d) of the Civil P.C., read with Order 21 Rule 11 and Rule 331 of the Bombay High Court (Original Side) Rules, 1980.  Necessary directions for appointment of Receiver and sale of shop were accordingly passed.  [Para 7]

heading: Petition by wife for divorce on ground of cruelty
HeadNote.description: Petition by wife for divorce on ground of cruelty - Subsequently talaqnama was drawn up and signed by both parties - Marriage coming to an end - Court instead of disposing off petition as infructuous proceeding to hear it on merits - Petition decided on unopposed testimony of wife - Divorce granted on ground of cruelty and talaqnama - Held setting aside decree on merits that settlement and contest could not go together and petition was liable to be dismissed as infructuous in view of the talaqnama. (Para 9)

heading: Petition for decree of divorce by wife
HeadNote.description: Petition for decree of divorce by wife - Not providing maintenance by husband and not performing his marital obligations - Statutory period has to be counted on and from date of filing petition as required under Act - Court cannot work out position at time of delivering judgment. (Para 11)

heading: Marriage dissolved
HeadNote.description: Marriage dissolved - Husband who was in occupation of flat belonging to wife asked to hand over vacant possession of flat - Appeal by husband admitted - Stay granted subject to condition of payment of Rs.5,000/- p.m. to wife for use and occupation of flat - Husband defaulting in payment - Stay as far as flat was concerned vacated for not obeying terms of stay order.		(Para 8)

heading: Petition by wife
HeadNote.description: Divorce and dissolution of marriage - Petition by wife - Allegations of cruelty against husband - Husband categorically admitted the allegations made against him - Facts which are admitted need not be proved - It is not necessary for wife to lead any further evidence to prove acts of cruelty - Allegations made against husband clearly constitute cruelty u/s.2(viii)(a) - Both have not been residing together since more than 7 years - They have also filed joint affidavit for dissolution of marriage - Wife entitled to divorce. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Dissolution of muslim marriage by mutual consent - Permissibility - Marriage between muslim pair can be dissolved in the form of agreement also - Agreement can also be termed as 'Khula' executed between parties - Therefore, in terms of S.2(ix) the residuary clause, decree can be granted for divorce by mutual consent. 			(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Apostasy
HeadNote.description: Mullah's Mohammedan Law, S.321 - Apostasy - Whether muslim marriage subsists after a Muslim becomes an apostate - The moment a Muslim commits apostasy, he gets excluded from the Islamic common wealth - All his rights, interests, status, relations get automatically extinguished - His marital ties with Muslim wife automatically gets snapped without pronoucenment of Talak - Moreover, if husband dies without returning to Islam, such Muslim wife cannot be his legal heir. 	(Paras 25, 29)

heading: Electoral roll
Publication of
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Registration of Electors Rules (1960), Rr.22, 24 - Electoral roll - Publication of - Effect - Once electoral roll is finally published, no Court can interfere with the said publication of electoral roll.

The Courts cannot decide any issue relating to issuance or revision of an electoral roll. The remedy lies in the procedure laid down in the prescribed rules. There is scope for challenging the contents of the electoral roll. However, once an electoral roll is finally published, it becomes final and then no court can interfere with the said publication of the electoral roll and it shall be the electoral roll of the constituency. The power of delimitation of constituencies vests in the Delimitation Commission and the preparation of electoral rolls vests in the Election Commission. In the absence of a fresh order of delimitation issued by the Delimitation Commission, the Election Commission had no power to change the electoral roll for the constituency.  AIR 1963 SC 479, (2000)8 SCC 46 - Rel.on.  [Para 19,24]

The power to carry out delimitation of the constituencies has been vested with the Delimitation Commission constituted under the Delimitation Act, 2002. The object of the Act is to provide for the re-adjustment of the allocation of seats in the House of People to the States, the total number of seats in the legislative assembly of each State, the division of each State and each Union Territory having a legislative assembly in to territorial constituencies for elections to the House of People and legislative assemblies of the States and Union Territories and for matters connected therewith. Section 8 of the Act provides for re-adjustment of number of seats, Section 9 of the Act provides for Delimitation of constituencies, Section 10 of the Act provides for publication of orders and their date of operation by Commission in the Gazette of India and in the official Gazettes of the State concerned and on such publication, every such order shall have the force of law and shall not be called in question in any court. Section 11 of the Act mandates that the Election Commission shall maintain delimitation orders up-to-date.  (1995)6 SCC 721 - Ref.   [Para 11]

heading: Notification dt.19.1.2007 delimiting Parliamentary and Assembly Constituencies in the State of M.P.
HeadNote.description: Notification dt.19.1.2007 delimiting Parliamentary and Assembly Constituencies in the State of M.P. - Mhow Assembly Constituency into Dhar Parliamentary Constituency by deleting the same from Indore Parliamentary Constituency - Delimitation effected after considering all objections and suggestions received by it before specified date and got published its orders in the Gazette of the State and in the Gazette of India - Notification so published is to be treated as law and required to be given effect to. (1967)1 SCR 400 - Rel. on.	(Para 25)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Mumbai (1999)
heading: Order of investigation
Quashing of
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), Ss.452, 465, 466, 468, 471, 420, 34 - Order of investigation - Quashing of - Complaint against list of persons eligible for grant of accommodation under Slum Rehabilitation Scheme - However, on date of complaint, Annexure II (list of persons entitled) was not even prepared - Based on such vague complaint, very cryptic order was passed without recording any reasons for taking action u/S.156(3) - Non application of judicial mind by Magistrate - Only because complaint discloses commission of cognizable offence, order of investigation should not be passed mechanically - Further, no averment recorded regarding compliance of S.154(1) and (3) - There was endorsement on complaint that verification of complainant has been recorded - If that be so, pre-cognizance stage was already over when impugned order was passed - Hence, impugned order and consequent FIR deserves to be quashed. 2013 ALL SCR 3464, 2014 ALL SCR 1893 Ref. to. 	(Paras 16, 21, 26, 27, 29)
