heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - For planned development of Delhi - Challenge, on ground that notification does not mention particular purpose of acquisition - It was not necessary to mention particular purpose - Once planned development of Delhi has been specified that to be read with zonal plan applicable in area in question - Zonal plan shows that acquired area was reserved for institutional purpose which includes educational institute - Notification not bad for not mentioning that land was acquired for purpose of school. (1973) 2 SCC 337 Disting. (1975) 4 SCC 285 Rel. on.  (Paras 10, 13, 14)

heading: Local authority
HeadNote.description: Local authority - Delhi Development Authority is "local authority" and "person interested" - Definition of "local authority" and "person interested" is inclusive and not exhaustive.	(Paras 24, 27)

heading: Regularization Certificate
HeadNote.description: Regularization Certificate - Appellant challenging establishment of Pathological Centre and Nursing Home in residential building, installation of Generator sets in setback area of property blocking underground water tanks - Municipal Corporation without seeking permission of High Court issuing regularization certificate under mixed use Regulations with retrospective effect when writ petition against respondent was pending - Complaint by 18 residents of locality was not taken note of by authorities - Permission u/S.25 of Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act also not obtained though pathological centre was being run in violation of master plan for Delhi - Regularization Certificate quashed it being unlawful and against rule of law.			(Paras 30, 35, 46, 53)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Permission for development of residual area - Grant of - Where permission for development in respect of such land had been applied for and obtained construction if undertaken and carried out in terms thereof could not be treated to have been unlawfully undertaken or carried out under S.53(3)(a) of the Act.	(Para 138)

heading: Lease of Nazul land
HeadNote.description:
Lease of Nazul land - Termination by efflux of time - Subsequent acceptance of rent by Development Authority - Would not amount to an automatic renewal of lease.

2005(5) ALL MR 848 (S.C.), 2006(3) ALL MR 211 (S.C.), (1990) 4 SCC 406 Rel. on. (Para 25)

heading: Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act (1971), Ss.2(e), 2(g), 5
HeadNote.description:
Public Premises (Eviction of Unauthorised Occupants) Act (1971), Ss.2(e), 2(g), 5 - Transfer of Property Act (1882), Ss.113, 116 - Lease of Nazul land - Granted by Delhi Development Authority (DDA) - Lease deed effective for 20 years and renewable for further 20 years - Clause in lease deed provided for renewal upon 6 months prior request of lessee and acceptance thereof by DDA - Pending such request for renewal, DDA notified breach of lease condition and asked lessee to rectify the same - Upon failure of lessee, renewal of lease declined and notice of termination issued - However, no further action taken and DDA accepted rent for subsequent months when respondent continued to occupy the premises - Held, even on acceptance of rent by DDA, lease would not be renewed - Intention of non renewal is clear from notice of breach and termination notice - Suit premise is a "public premise" within meaning of S.2(e) and respondent is "unauthorized occupant" u/S.2(g) of Public Premises Act, liable to pay damages - Impugned order perpetually restraining DDA from taking any action under termination notice - Is erroneous and liable to be set aside.

2005(5) ALL MR 848 (S.C.), 2006(3) ALL MR 211 (S.C.), (1990) 4 SCC 406 Rel. on. (Paras 25, 27, 29, 30, 31, 34, 35)

HeadNote.act_name: Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act (1954)
heading: Complaint for alleged commission of offences under Act
HeadNote.description:
Complaint for alleged commission of offences under Act - Accused publishing advertisements in pamphlets relating to stone or drug which is misleading or false - Persons who paid money to accused examined - Prima facie case existing against accused persons - Proceeding cannot be quashed under S.482.

The order passed by the Magistrate refusing to stop the proceedings has been assailed but then the quashing of proceedings against the accused applicants can be ordered only if it is shown that continuation of the prosecution would amount to an abuse of the process of Court. The allegations in the F.I.R. were not vague, the evidence collected by the investigation officer in the nature of seizure and search, prima facie discloses that the offences under sections 4,5, and 7 of D.M.R. Act, have been committed, which is further corroborated in material particulars by the statements of the prosecution witnesses and in such circumstances, the inherent powers of High Court cannot be exercised especially when the said inherent power is to be exercised in the rarest of the rare case, in order to prevent the abuse of process of the law.  [Para 16]

It would clearly reveal that the applicants had published advertisement in the inner pamphlets relating to the stone or drug, which prima facie appears to be false or misleading in any manner. In view of this situation, it is difficult to accept the submission of the applicants that prima facie, no offence has been made out under sections 4,5 read with 7 of D.M.R. Act.   [Para 12]

HeadNote.act_name: Drugs and Magic Remedies (Objectionable Advertisements) Act (1954)
heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Applies to all categories of drugs whether licensed or not and whether they are prohibited or not - Advertisement referring to drug for treatment of stature of person is prohibited under S.3.

On a plain reading of Clause (b) of Section 2 of the said Act of 1954, Section 3 thereof applies to all categories of drugs, whether they are licensed or not and whether they are prohibited or not. Section 3 imposes a prohibition on taking any part in the publication of any advertisements referring to any drug which in term suggest or are calculated to lead to the use of that drug for the purposes specified in Clauses (a) to (d) of Section 3 of the said Act of 1954. Clause (d) thereof is applicable when the advertisements suggest or are calculated to lead to the use of that drug for the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment or prevention of any disease, disorder or condition specified in the schedule.

Serial No.47 of the Schedule includes a condition "stature of persons." Therefore, if any advertisements referring to any drug which suggest or are calculated to lead to the use of that drug for the treatment of stature of persons, the prohibition under Section 3 comes into picture.				      [Para 7]

heading: Objectionable advertisements
HeadNote.description: Objectionable advertisements - Advertisement of STEP-up Body Growth formula on T.V. Channel - Increase in height assured - Advertisement would be prohibited under S.3(d) - whether drug is dangerous or harmful is irrelevant to attract S.3(d).	(Para 18)

heading: Search and seizure of goods
HeadNote.description: Search and seizure of goods - Person conducting search and seizure not Gazetted Officer nor authorised by State Govt. - Such search and seizure can be called in question in trial itself and not during stage of investigation.	(Para 14)

heading: Notification by State Govt. empowering Drug Inspectors to exercise power under S.8 relating to search and seizure
HeadNote.description: Notification by State Govt. empowering Drug Inspectors to exercise power under S.8 relating to search and seizure - Inadvertant reference to Telangana area in the preliminary part of notification does not restrict its operation to Telangana area - Giving narrow interpretation would defeat the purpose for which this notification was issued.			(Para 8)

heading: Ad-interim injunction
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Ad-interim injunction - Grant of - Claim by applicant-pawner with respect to suit shares pledged by him with defendant pawnee - Injunction was sought against 'A' who was depository participant of pawnee and alleged to have transferred certain suit shares - 'A' took plea of absence of knowledge on his part regarding plaintiff's rights to suit shares - Admittedly, shares were transferred by pawner to pawnee and recorded in name of pawnees u/s.10 of Depositories Act, 1996 - Suit pledge was not created with previous approval of depository nor was Reg.58 of SEBI Regulations complied with - Consequently there were no entries in records of depository to that effect - Further pawner also failed to prove alleged presence of 'A' during his meetings with pawnee with respect to suit shares - Merely because 'A' had hurriedly transferred certain suit shares when ad interim order was passed against pawnee - Does not imply his knowledge of rights of plaintiff with respect to suit shares - No prima facie case made out to grant ad interim injunction against 'A'. 	(Paras 21, 22, 23, 28)

heading: Effect of
HeadNote.description:
SEBI (Mutual Fund) Regulations (1996), Reg.29A - Banking Regulation Act (1949), S.45ZA - Succession Act (1925), Ss.58(2), 63 - Investments of deceased in Shares/Mutual Fund/ Fixed Deposit in Bank - Nomination made by deceased in respect of such investments - Effect of - Non-obstante clause in S.109A of Companies Act or Bye Law 9.11.7 of Depositories Act or Reg.29A of SEBI Regulations or S.45ZA of Banking Regulation Act only serves to protect Company/Depository/Bank, it does not divest heir - Nominee not entitled to succeed to such investments exclusively to the exclusion of other heirs/claimants - Nomination cannot displace law of succession nor does it create a third kind of succession styled as "statutory testament". 
2010(4) ALL MR 51 Held, per incuriam in view of 2009(6) ALL MR 486 (S.C.).
2009 ALL SCR 1727, (1984) 1 SCC 424, 2000(4) ALL MR 688 (S.C.), 2011 ALL SCR 479, 2010(3) ALL MR 599, 1993 Mh.L.J. 228 Rel. on.
(2009) 151 Com.cas.92 (Del.) Not Followed. (Paras 38, 40)

heading: Nomination of shares
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act (1960), S.30 - Nomination of shares - Intent of nomination is to vest the property in the shares which includes ownership rights thereunder in nominee upon nomination validity made as per procedure prescribed - Nomination can be cancelled by holder and another nomination can be made - Such later nomination would be relied upon by Depository Participant - That would be for conferring of all the rights in the shares to such last nominee.

Section 109-A of the Companies Act is required to be interpreted with regard to the vesting of the shares of the holder of the shares in the nominee upon his death. The act sets out that the nomination has to be made during the life time of the holder as per procedure prescribed by law. If that procedure is followed, the nominee would become entitled to all the rights in the shares to the exclusion of all other persons. The nominee would be made beneficial owner thereof. Upon such nomination, therefore, all the rights incidental to ownership would follow. This would include the right to transfer the shares, pledge the shares or hold the shares. The specific statutory provision making the nominee entitled to all the rights in the shares excluding all other persons would show expressly the legislative intent. Once all other persons are excluded and only the nominee becomes entitled under the statutory provision to have all the rights in the shares none other can have it. Further Section 9.11 of the Depositories Act 1996 makes the nominee's position superior to even a testamentary disposition. The non-obstante Clause in Section 9.11.7 gives the nomination the effect of the Testamentary Disposition itself. Hence, any other disposition or nomination under any other law stands subject to the nomination made under the Depositories Act. Section 9.11.7 further shows that the last of the nominations would prevail. This shows the revocable nature of the nomination much like a Testamentary Disposition. A nomination can be cancelled by the holder and another nomination can be made. Such later nomination would be relied upon by the Depository Participant. That would be for conferring of all the rights in the shares to such last nominee.

A reading of Section 109-A of the Companies Act and 9.11 of the Depositories Act makes it abundantly clear that the intent of the nomination is to vest the property in the shares which includes the ownership rights thereunder in the nominee upon nomination validly made as per the procedure prescribed, as has been done in this case. These Sections are completely different from Section 39 of the Insurance Act set out which require a nomination merely for the payment of the amount under the Life Insurance Policy without confirming any ownership rights in the nominee or under Section 30 of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act which allows the Society to transfer the shares of the member which would be valid against any demand made by any other person upon the Society. Hence these provisions are made merely to give a valid discharge to the Insurance Company or the Co-operative Society without vesting the ownership rights in the Insurance Policy or the membership rights in the Society upon such nominee. The express legislature intent under Section 109-A of the Companies Act and Section 9.11 of the Depositories Act is clear.

Since the nomination is shown to be correctly made by her husband who was the holder of the Suit shares, the Plaintiff would have no right to get the shares of her deceased husband sold or to otherwise deal with the same.				 [Para 24,25,26]

HeadNote.act_name: Dowry Prohibition (Maintenance of Lists of Presents to the Bride and Bridegroom) Rules (1985)
heading: Enforcement of Act
HeadNote.description: Enforcement of Act - Apathy resulting into thoroughly unsatisfactory enforcement of the provisions of the Act - Supreme Court, hence, directed more rigorous and effective implementation of the Act by issuing certain directions.	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Dismissal of reservist from service
HeadNote.description:
Dismissal of reservist from service - Power to dismiss or remove vests only in Brigade Commander.

A reading of Regulation 206 of the Defence Services Regulations, 1961, would show that a man, who has been transferred to the reserve, comes under the administration and disciplinary orders of the Officer-in- Charge reservists. There is no mention in Regulation 206 that the Officer-in-Charge reservists has the power to either remove or dismiss a reservist from service. A plain reading of sub-section (3) of Section 20 of the Army Act on the other hand, would show that an officer having power not less than a brigade or equivalent commander or any prescribed officer may dismiss or remove from the service any person serving under his command other than an officer or a junior commissioned officer. Regulation 206 cannot take away the power vested under the Army Act in the brigade commander to dismiss or remove any person working under him. The High Court rightly held in the impugned judgment that the brigade commander had the power to dismiss the appellant from service.  [Para 7]

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art. 227 - Quashing of issuance of process and proceeding - Petition for - Proceeding for manufacturing of drugs which is not of standard quality - As per R. 45 testing of sample has to be done within 60 days - Testing is beyond statutory period prescribed under R. 45 - When sample was tested after expiry period, result is bond to be ‘not of standard quality’ - Such report cannot be considered at all - Benefit of such lapse should go to accused - Further within 28 days from knowledge of report accused stated that they are not agreeing with report and would like to have rechecking - Before accused had received notice regarding sub-standard quality of drugs, sanction to prosecution was granted by competent authority - Complainant filed proceeding belatedly just one day before drug was to expire - Vital right of accused to get sample rechecked have been violated because of belated filing of complaint - Proceeding liable to be quashed.  MANU/MH/0996/2019; 2018 ALL MR (Cri) 3946; AIR 2008 SC 1939 Rel. on. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Prohibition of quality and percentage
HeadNote.description:
Prohibition of quality and percentage - Scope and constitutional validity of R.106-B - Rule 106-B intended to ensure that there is no diversion or misuse of alcohol which is used in the preparation of homoeopathic medicines - No discrimination between homoeopathic and Ayurvedic medicines - It is not necessary for legislature to regulate every conceivable activity in order to regulate something - Legislature can recognize and distinguish between degrees of evil and regulate those areas where its intervention is most required - Such a classification cannot be regarded as arbitrary or unconstitutional.

The manufacture of drugs must be pursued in a manner which is consistent with the protection of public interest and Rule 106-B is intended to ensure that there is no diversion or misuse of alcohol which is used in the preparation of homoeopathic medicines. There is absolutely no merit in the submission that there is a discrimination between manufacturers of Homoeopathic and Ayurvedic medicines. Even on the assumption that a similar diversion of alcohol may conceivabley take place in the manufacture of Ayurvedic medicines, the argument of the Petitioner at the highest would be that the classification is under inclusive, but it is well settled that it is not necessary for the legislature to regulate every conceivable activity in order to regulate something. The legislature can recognize and distinguish between degrees of evil and regulate those areas where its intervention is most required. Such a classification cannot be regarded as arbitrary or unconstitutional. The submission that Rule 106-B has been brought into force without complying with mandatory procedural requirements is based on the allegation that the Drugs Technical Advisory Board did not have any representative with an expert knowledge in the field of Homoeopathy. The constitution of the Board is provided for in Section 5(2) of the Act. Hence, it would not be for the Court to mandate any change in the statutory provision relating to the Constitution of the Board. That is for the Parliament to best determine.
  [Para 7,8,9]

heading: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Manufacturing cosmetics for sale or for distribution - Grant or renewal of licence - Manufacturing of Mehandi products not categorized in Sch.M-II - Neither licence is required to manufacture Mehandi cones or Mehandi powder - Nor conditions of license as provided under R.142 of Rules and manner of labelling as prescribed under R.148 of Rules needs to be followed - Hence, criminal proceedings for offence punishable u/S.18(c) of the Act and Rules thereunder quashed. (Paras 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Petition for
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art. 227 - Quashing of issuance of process and proceeding - Petition for - Proceeding for manufacturing of drugs which is not of standard quality - As per R. 45 testing of sample has to be done within 60 days - Testing is beyond statutory period prescribed under R. 45 - When sample was tested after expiry period, result is bond to be ‘not of standard quality’ - Such report cannot be considered at all - Benefit of such lapse should go to accused - Further within 28 days from knowledge of report accused stated that they are not agreeing with report and would like to have rechecking - Before accused had received notice regarding sub-standard quality of drugs, sanction to prosecution was granted by competent authority - Complainant filed proceeding belatedly just one day before drug was to expire - Vital right of accused to get sample rechecked have been violated because of belated filing of complaint - Proceeding liable to be quashed.  MANU/MH/0996/2019; 2018 ALL MR (Cri) 3946; AIR 2008 SC 1939 Rel. on. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Exclusion from criminal liability
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion from criminal liability - Person acting on behalf of licensee in contravention of Act and Rules - Not to be excluded from criminal liability under provisions of Act and Rules - Contention that licensee alone is to maintain records and registers in prescribed forms and for any contravention thereof, the licensee alone is responsible for breach of Rule, not tenable.

In the instant case, the applicant would be a person who has sold the drugs on behalf of the licensee in contravention of the Rules and, therefore, in view of the provisions of section 18(A)(vi) read with section 27 of the Act is liable to be prosecuted. It is not available to the applicant to raise the defence that under Rule 65 as well as sub-clauses of the said Rule impose the duty on the licensee alone to maintain records and registers in the prescribed forms and for any contravention thereof it is the licensee alone who is responsible for such breach of Rule and is alone liable for prosecution. It must be borne in mind that the legislature thought it fit to prohibit every person whether he is a licensee himself or other person who is acting on behalf of such licensee (in whichever capacity) to sell any drug or cosmetic in contravention of any of the provisions of the Act and Rules made thereunder. Neither section 18 nor section 25 carves out any exception in this regard in favour of person who is acting on behalf of the licensee from the criminal liability. In absence thereof, it is not possible to exclude a person who is acting on behalf of the licensee and the act of such person contravenes the provisions of the Act and Rules, to be excluded from the Criminal liability under the provisions of the Act. The contention of the learned counsel for the applicant if accepted in this regard, would frustrate the scheme of sections 18 and 27 and, therefore, the same is rejected.

The purport of sections 18 and 27 is every person whether licensee agent or may be a qualified person, is prohibited from selling any drug in contravention of provisions of Act and Rules without any exception to this Rule and, therefore, all those who sell drug in contravention of the provisions of the Act and Rules are responsible for such contravention and can be proceeded against. Any other interpretation of sections 18, and 27, in my view would be totally inconsistent with the legislative intent as well as object and purpose for which these provisions are enacted by the legislature. For the reasons stated hereinabove, the contention canvassed by Shri Manohar, learned Counsel for the applicant in this regard is misconceived and devoid of substance.	 [Para 22,23]

heading: Non-compliance of
HeadNote.description: Non-compliance of - Seriously prejudices accused. (Paras 18,19)

heading: Drug license
HeadNote.description: Drug license - Entire scheme contained in Rules 64 to 66A is for the purposes of ensuring that licenses for sale or distribution of drugs is granted to a person about whose competence and antecedents there are no reasonable doubt or issues - In matters such as these, the legislature has laid special emphasis upon verification of competence and antecedents, particularly as any laxity in this regard can have disastrous consequences upon a poor, sick and ignorant populace.	(Para 12)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Illegal sale of drugs - Appeal against acquittal - Ketamine Hydrochloride Injections were found stocked in garments shop run by original accused - However, he had license for distribution of said drug under which he could distribute same anywhere in India - Defence that said drugs were to be distributed at somewhere else and were stocked in said shop during transit - Vials were found in packed boxes - Nothing found in shop to establish that said injections were exhibited or offered for sale or were actually sold in that shop - As such, mere possession of drugs not meant for sale cannot be an offence - As regards co-accused being original lease holder of said shop, it cannot be said that he shared common intention to commit offence - No evidence that co-accused had any knowledge of said stock - Even no charge framed against both accused for contravention of Rule 62 - Hence, acquittal proper. 1979 Cri. L.J. 466 Rel. on. (1974) 4 SCC 209, 28(1985) DLT 392, 2012(2)ALD (Cri) 26, (1975) 3 SCC 322 Disting. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Cancellation of license
HeadNote.description: Cancellation of license - Violation of conditions of license - Petitioner, a powder manufacturing company did not obtain permission from licensing authority to carry out ETO treatment - Also did not inform authority after such treatment - No residual testing of ethylene oxide carried out - Which is necessary in case of ETO treatment - Petitioner only submitted analysis report of three batches out of fifteen - To sell powder without carrying out residual testing is serious lapse - Petitioner also failed to obtain loan license for said procedure - Held, issue of petitioner not obtaining loan license was raised only at appellate level - Operative order of appellate authority not based on this fact - Respondent must seek to sustain impugned orders only on basis of what is stated in show cause notice - However, issue of failure to obtain loan license is of general importance - Ought to be considered by authorities - Matter remanded back to appellate authority for fresh consideration after affording petitioner opportunity of being heard on this point. 	(Paras  12, 14, 18, 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Rules (2009)
heading: Rule making power
HeadNote.description: Rule making power - Delegation of said power to State Govt., whether excessive - Basic policy has been determined by Parliament i.e. protection of life and property of Senior Citizen - This is to be done through action plan which is speedy and inexpensive - Provision has also been made for supervisory control of Central Govt. over the progress of implementation of Act - Delegation of power, therefore, not excessive. 	(Paras 66, 67, 68)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Rules (2009)
heading: Validity of Rules
HeadNote.description: Validity of Rules - Delhi Rules prescribing summary procedure for eviction from property of senior citizens - Challenge on grounds that (i) there being no such provision in parent Act Delhi Rules are ultra vires, and (ii) no such action can be taken by administrative authority without examining disputed questions of facts and law in a trial - Firstly, Delhi Rules are consonant with legislative policy i.e. protection of Senior Citizen - Framed on parameters of S.22 of parent Act which deals with action plan of State Govt. - Secondly, concerned officer verifies title of senior citizen, forms an opinion as to ill-treatment, hears the parties and then only passes order of eviction - Grounds of challenge not tenable - Validity of Rules upheld. 	(Para 66)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description: Custody of children - Court issuing direction at the instance of husband that if custody is resisted by wife, husband could take police help - Held, orders from Court in execution would be more appropriate - Police intervention where parties belong to educated respectable families should be avoided.	(Para 8)

heading: Custody of children
HeadNote.description:
Custody of children - Husband's right to custody of children - Controlling consideration governing custody of children is welfare of children and not rights of parents - Custody of daughter age over 13 years and of elder and younger son - Custody of elder son allowed to continue with father but custody of daughter and youngest son given to the mother who was well placed to look after them.

The dominant consideration in making orders under S.25 is the welfare of the minor children and in considering this question due regard has of course to be paid to the right of the father to be the guardian and also to all other relevant factors having a bearing on the minor's welfare. There is a presumption that a minor's parents would do their very best to promote their children's welfare and, if necessary, would not grudge any sacrifice of their own personal interest and pleasure. This presumption arises because of the natural, selfless affection normally expected from the parents for their children. From this point of view, in case of conflict or dispute between the mother and the father about the custody of their children, the approach has to be somewhat different from that adopted by the Letters Patent Bench of the High Court in this case. There is no dichotomy between the fitness of the father to be entrusted with the custody of his minor children and considerations of their welfare. The father's fitness has to be considered, determined and weighed predominantly in terms of the welfare of his minor children in the context of all the relevant circumstances. If the custody of the father cannot promote their welfare equally or better than the custody of the mother, then, he cannot claim indefeasible right to their custody under S. 25 merely because there is no defect in his personal character and he has attachment for his children -which every normal parent has. No doubt, the father has been presumed by the statute generally to be better fitted to look after the children - being normally the earning member and head of the family but the Court has in each case to see primarily to the welfare of' the children in determining the question of their custody, in the background of all the relevant facts having bearing on their health, maintenance and education. The family is normal1y the heart of our society and for a balanced and healthy growth of children it is highly desirable that they get their due share of affection and care from both the parents in their normal parental home. Where, however family dissolution due to some unavoidable circumstances becomes necessary the Court has to come to a judicial decision on the question of the welfare of the children on a full consideration of all the relevant circumstances.	  [Para 14]

heading: Family Courts Act (1984), S.9(1)
HeadNote.description: Family Courts Act (1984), S.9(1) - Divorce by mutual consent - Duty of court to endeavour for a settlement - Where parties living separately for a long period, extent of which is beyond period stipulated in the Act - And parties mutually agreed for divorce by verdict of court - In such cases, 'settlement' need not invariably be that of reunion of spouses - But it can be by way of facilitating an easy legal dissolution. 	(Para 4)

heading: Petition by husband for decree of nullity
HeadNote.description: Petition by husband for decree of nullity - Fact of removal of fallopian tubes by operation and consequent inability to give birth to a child not disclosed before marriage - Allowing the petition, held this was a fit case wherein marriage between the spouses be declared a nullity. (Paras 4, 6)

heading: Divorce
Claim by husband
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of desertion and cruelty - Claim by husband - Plea of husband that his wife deserted him and they were living separately two years prior to institution of divorce proceedings - Said plea was falsified by admission of husband and his witness in their cross-examination - Further allegations by husband that wife has extra-marital affairs and she beats him with iron rod and stick were baseless - No sufficient evidence on record to prove said allegations - Also, nothing on record to show that wife has treated husband with cruelty - Decree of divorce cannot be granted to husband. 	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Appeal by wife
HeadNote.description: Wife applying for nullity of marriage on ground of impotency - Husband obtaining decree of divorce from District Court on ground of adultery - Family Court refusing to grant decree of nullity - Appeal by wife - Held there was irretrievable break down of marriage and it would be desirable to grant divorce on ground of relative impotency and put an end to incompatible relationship - Decree passed by District Court set aside as being infructuous. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Decree of divorce and permanent alimony
HeadNote.description: Decree of divorce and permanent alimony - Death of husband thereafter - Application for execution of decree against legal heirs of husband, who are in possession of properties belonging to deceased - Executing Court held legal heirs liable to pay amount of permanent alimony of Rs.2000/- - Proper course for the Court should have been to direct parties to provide full particulars of all movable and immovable properties belonging to deceased - So that amount of permanent alimony which is a charge on estate of deceased is recovered from those properties - Heirs may not be personally liable to pay alimony but they are liable because they are in possession of assets of deceased. AIR 1983 SC 916 Ref. to.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Dissolution of marriage
Cruelty
Petition by wife
Followed.			 [Para 4,5,11]
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - Cruelty - Petition by wife - Wife meted out a cruel treatment over a period of four years in an unsatisfactory married life - Respondent husband not taking any care to contest the petition filed before Family Court - Wife entitled to decree of divorce.

It was the case of the Appellant in the trial Court that the Respondent distanced himself physically from her for no fault of her.  In her view there was a studied unkindness on his part which was reflected in various acts on his part.  Thus for example he did not confide in her in his financial affairs or with respect to family affairs on his parents side.  He did not take her to his parents, nor did he join her to visit her parents.  Whenever the Appellant got an opportunity to go abroad, she requested the Respondent to join her but he turned down that request not less than on three occasions when there was no additional expenditure involved.  On the other hand, he would go to Goa alone.  He did not contribute to expenditure for the matrimonial home beyond a sum of Rs.1000/- or Rs.1500/- per month and the payment of electricity bill, when his earning per month was not less than Rs.8000/-.  All these acts constituted cruelty against her.  She was constrained to leave the matrimonial home and to go to the parents home some time in October, 1998.  Thereafter she filed matrimonial petition first in this Court in September, 1999 though later the same was transferred to the Family Court, where it has came to be numbered as A-1135 of 2000 and decided against her.  After the Appellant filed the above referred petition, it was served on the Respondent but he did not care to attend in Family Court though served.  The Appellant filed an affidavit to substantiate her allegations.  The learned Judge proceeded ex-parte but unfortunately for her did not accept her version of cruelty and dismissed the Petition.  Being aggrieved by the judgment and decree, this Appeal is filed.  The Appellant had made out a case of cruelty before the trial Court and the learned Judge has erred in ignoring the material which was placed before him.  There was no reason for him to come to the conclusion that in fact the Appellant was at fault when the Respondent did not care to contest the petition, and the submissions made by the Appellant on cruelty were cogent and un-controverted.  It was for her to form her impression as to how she was treated.  She has placed it on record and we cannot say that she was unreasonable in contending that she was meted out a cruel treatment over a period of four years in an unsatisfactory married life.  For the reason stated above, she has made out a case under section 10 of the Indian Divorce Act, 1869 as interpreted in Pragati Varghese.  She is therefore, entitled to a decree of divorce.

2002 AIR SCW 162 and 1997(3) Mh.L.J. 602 - Followed.			 [Para 4,5,11]

heading: Christian husband pleading for marriage dissolution on grounds of cruelty
HeadNote.description:
Christian husband pleading for marriage dissolution on grounds of cruelty - Not allowed under S.10 which permits divorce on ground of adultery only.

There may be several reasons why the law permits dissolution of the marriage at the instance of the Christian husband only on the solitary ground of adultery. Perhaps, Christian women are never cruel to their husbands, for they are "Christian". Assuming there is any discrimination, the discrimination, if at all, would be in favour of a woman, which is perfectly, valid and permissible in view of Article 15(3) of the Constitution.

Even if there is some substance in the grievance that section 10 of the Act as it stands makes a discrimination in the matter of grounds of divorce between a Christian husband and wife, we have no power to introduce into section 10 a ground which the legislation did not contemplate. Section 10 is conveniently divided into two portions. The first, titled, "When husband may petition for dissolution", deals with the ground on which a Christian husband may petition for dissolution of marriage. From 1869, till today, the only ground for divorce available for the husband under the Act is the ground of adultery. The second portion of section 10 deals with "When wife may petition for dissolution", and contains several grounds, some of which were struck down. Even assuming that the remainder of section 10 after the exercise carried out by the Full Bench is considered to be discriminative against the Christian husband, it is not open to us to read into section 10 any ground other than the ground provided by the Legislature.  [Para 5]

heading: Cruelty
Petition by wife
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Petition by wife - Husband and wife poles apart as to their compatibility and temparament - Husband of suspicious nature and went on making enquiries as to the character of wife and telling the world that she is indulging in illicit relationships - He also used to beat her and make her life miserable - He did not care to counter allegations of the life and support his allegations against her - Held acts of respondent amount to not only physical but mental cruelty entitling her to decree of divorce. (1950)2 ALL ER 398, (1952)1 ALL ER 875 Refd.	(Para 16)

heading: Necessity
HeadNote.description:
Divorce of Christian couple - Confirmation by High Court of the decree for dissolution of marriage - Necessity - Provisions of Family Courts Act prevail over the provisions of Divorce Act, 1869, so far as procedural aspects are concerned - Judgment of Family Court is subject to appellate Jurisdiction of High Court and not subject to confirmation provided u/s.17 of the Divorce Act.  Family Courts Act (1984).

The procedure contemplated in the Divorce Act stood over-ridden on coming into force of the Family Courts Act in the State of Maharashtra.  The procedure of decree nisi and confirmation by the High Court as provided in the Divorce Act, 1869 has to give way to the procedure provided in the Family Courts Act.  The decree for dissolution of marriage passed by the Family Court needs no confirmation since the provisions of Family Courts Act shall prevail over the provisions of Divorce Act, 1869 so far as procedural aspects are concerned.  The judgment of the Family Court is subject to the appellate jurisdiction of the High Court under section 19 and is not subject to confirmation as provided in section 17 of the Divorce Act, 1869 as it stood prior to the amendment in the year 2001.  [Para 9]

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - Since 15 years husband and wife are residing separately - There are no instances of their meeting on any occasion - No willingness to stay together - Wife stating mother of husband was bed ridden and her behaviour was troublesome - Also that husband was seen under influence of liquor which was creating bad impact on children - These cannot be grounds for wife to leave house - Family Court's order of granting divorce and Rs.1000/- maintenance each to wife and 2 children - Order not liable to be interfered with. 	(Para 8)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.10 (as it stood prior to amending Act 51 of 2001)
heading: Dissolution of marriage
HeadNote.description:
Dissolution of marriage - No grounds other than adultery, including cruelty, desertion or irretrievable breakdown of marriage, available - Adultery, presumption and proof of, scope - Questionable conduct of R-1-wife though known to appellant since long prior to his filing petition for divorce on his detecting letters Exs.A-3 and A-4, appellant remained silent on that aspect till filing of petition - Said letters by themselves no unambiguous indications of any adulterous conduct on part of wife - In both letters R-2 is alleged to have addressed R-1 as "Dear Raja Kumari" and requested her to meet him in manner requested in letters - Merely because of such request by R-2 to R-1, there cannot be a straight presumption of questionable relationship between them - No proof of continuous course of conduct of adulterous life between respondents - Weakness of version of R-1 cannot be a ground to accept case of appellant - Appellant has to succeed in his case on strength of his own case - Exs.A-3 and A-4 or/and self-serving and uncorroborated claims of appellant, not sufficient to prove allegations of adultery - Exs.A-3 and A-4 may only suggest at worst occasional lapses in virtue not amounting to living in adultery.

Section 10 of the Act, as it stood before the amending Act 51 of 2001, entitled the husband to file petition for dissolution only on the ground that his wife has, since the solemnization of the marriage, been guilty of adultery. No other ground appeared available from Section 10 of the Act, as it stood at the relevant time. Therefore, it conflicting pleadings and evidence of the parties on the question of cruelty are beyond the scope of Section 10 of the Act as it stood then and such a ground was unavailable to the appellant though the petition filed also on the ground of cruelty was decided on merits on that question also by the trial Court.  AIR 2001 Ker 195 - Rel. on.  [Para 9]

The claim of the first respondent that at any time before filing of this petition for divorce, no unchastity was ever attributed to her by the appellant in any of the complaints of notices or proceedings before the Courts, is not in dispute and if such questionable conduct of the first respondent was known to the appellant since long prior to his filing the petition for divorce on his detecting the letters Exs.A-3 and A-4, it is inexplicable as to why the appellant remained silent till this petition on that aspect. The letters Exs.A-3 and A-4 by themselves are no unambiguous indications of any adulterous conduct on the part of the wife. It is true that in both the letters the second respondent was alleged to have addressed the first respondent as 'Dear Raja Kumari' and requested her to meet him in the manner requested in the letters. But merely because such a request by the second respondent to the first respondent was made to meet him on both the occasions, there cannot be a straight presumption of questionable relationship between both of them.  [Para 10]

The first respondent specifically denied any acquaintance with the second respondent or receiving any letters from him and though it is true that she attempted to state in the counter and during the cross-examination of PW-1 and in her own evidence about the second respondent being available to be influenced by the appellant for taking a stand against her, that will not suffice to prove any continuous course of conduct of adulterous life between the respondents. The weakness of the version of the first respondent cannot be a ground to accept the case of the appellant and the appellant has to succeed in his case on the strength of his own case, more so, when such a serious allegation of living in adultery was made against the wife through whom he had three children after marital life since 1981 to 1995.  [Para 12]

The self-serving and uncorroborated claims of the appellant, cannot be considered sufficient to prove the allegation of adultery, apart from the fact that even Exs.A-3 and A-4 may only suggest at the worst occasional lapses in virtue which may not amount to the wife living in adultery. Under the circumstances, the appellant cannot succeed and the absence of any purpose in continuing the marital tie in view of separation of the couple since 1991 and any consequential irretrievable break down of the marriage cannot be valid grounds under the statutory provisions under which the relief is claimed.  [Para 13]

heading: Not necessary
HeadNote.description: Divorce by mutual consent - Personal appearance of petitioner husband - Not necessary - Unless the Court smells some kind of fraud being played with it, it should normally recognize the act of the attorneys - Attorneys can act as per instructions of his principal. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 396 - Explained. AIR 1968 Cal. 48 - Rel. on.	(Paras 5, 8)

heading: Petition for divorce
HeadNote.description:
Petition for divorce - Christian wife can claim divorce on independent ground of adultery, cruelty and/or desertion - Petition only on ground of cruelty without any allegation of adultery - Is maintainable.

1997 (3) Mh. L.J. 602 (FB) Rel. on. (Para 7)

heading: Confirmation of decree
HeadNote.description:
Confirmation of decree - Is not an empty formality or routine affair - Amending Act of 2001 cannot be given retrospective effect. 

The confirmation of a decree is not an empty formality or routine affair. The Section creates right in favour of the unsuccessful party to object for confirmation of a decree. The substantive provision relating to confirmation of a decree will continue to hold the field and will continue to operate. The amendment affecting vested right would operate prospectively and there is no sufficient indication in the statute to show that the intention of the Legislature was to affect the existing rights. The amending provisions brought into existence by virtue of Amending Act of 2001 shall have prospective effect and that the decree passed by the District Court, prior to enforcement of the amendment, as in the instant case, needs confirmation in view of Section 17 of the Act of 1869 (prior to its amendment).
AIR 2004 Patna 53 Rel. on.

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Scope - Proviso will not validate act of presentation of appeal - Appeal against decree of District-Judge is available only after enforcement of Amendment Act of 2001. 	(Para 3)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description:
Validity - Denial of right to divorce - Discriminatory treatment to wives on ground of sex and religion - Is violative of Arts.14 and 15 of Constitution - Demeaning treatment to wives also constitutes violation of right to life under Art.21.
Constitution of India, Art.14,15,21.

The first part of the Section is in respect of a right of a husband to obtain divorce. All that is required of him is to prove that his wife has since the solemnisation of the marriage been guilty of adultery. Hence, adultery by itself is made a ground for divorce as far as husbands belonging to the Christian community are concerned. Now let us see how the wife is placed vis-a-vis the husband for claiming the very same relief. Provision in this regard is made in the later part of the Section. As far as the ground of adultery is concerned, the same by itself is not sufficient to grant her a divorce. Adultery has to be incestuous adultery. Adultery has to be accompanied with bigamy. Adultery has to be accompanied by marriage with another woman. Adultery has to be coupled with cruelty or with desertion without reasonable excuse and that too for a period of two years or upwards. A question which arises for consideration is, whether there are just and sufficient grounds to make the above classification which places the Christian women to a disadvantageous position as compared to their husbands. Are there any grounds at all which can justify the discrimination. Can the discrimination be justified because the wives belong to the weaker sex. Can it be justified in order to establish the superiority of husbands over the wives. Is it merely in order to ensure that the wife is not treated equally with the husband. The aforesaid discrimination which is meted out to the wife, is wholly unreasonable. Article 14 of the Constitution ensures equality before law. The same mandates that the State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or equal protection of the laws within the territory of India. Is this the equality that the State has been able to offer to Christian wives as per the mandate contained in the above Article. Is this the equal protection of law which the State has envisaged and has conferred on the Christian wives as compared to those conferred on Christian husbands. The answer to these questions can be only one, 'NO'. Hence Section 10 is violative of Arts.14,15 and 21 of the Constitution.  [Para 35]

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description:
Validity - Necessity of confirmation of decision by District Court - Is arbitrary and unreasonable - Suitable amendment in the Act recommended.
(1989) DMC 322 (Cal), AIR 1985 MP 85, AIR 1989 Cal 1 Rel.on. (Para 55)

heading: Custody of children after judicial separation
HeadNote.description: Custody of children after judicial separation - Estoppel based on consent decree - Orders passed about custody of minor children even if based on consent are liable to be varied by Court, if welfare of wards demands variation - Estoppel cannot be pleaded.	(Para 17)

heading: Petition by Christian husband for dissolution of marriage under S.10
HeadNote.description:
Petition by Christian husband for dissolution of marriage under S.10 - Wife's adultery alone can be ground for dissolution under S.10 - Dissolution of marriage on ground of desertion by wife is unknown to S.10 - Granting divorce in such case is illegal - Section 10 is not violative of Art.14.

Constitution of India, Art.14.

In case of Christian husband the provisions of divorce Act do not contemplate dissolution of marriage on the ground of desertion. The ground of desertion for the purpose of decree for dissolution of marriage is unknown to the divorce Act.  The language of S.10 makes it clear that the husband may present a petition to the District Court or to the High Court for grant of decree for dissolution of marriage on the ground of adultery. No ground other than adultery is provided in Sec. 10 of the Act. From the close scrutiny of the recitals of the marriage petition and the solitary oral testimony of the petitioner husband, it is revealed that the petitioner husband has sought dissolution of marriage on the ground of desertion. There is no ambiguity with regard to the ground for dissolution of marriage. Admittedly, the petitioner husband has filed a divorce petition under sec. 10 of the Divorce Act. The ground of desertion is not at all available to the petitioner husband for the purpose of getting a decree for dissolution of marriage. The only ground available to the petitioner husband is of wife's adultery, that too after solemnization of the marriage. The petitioner husband has not at all asked the relief of dissolution of marriage on the ground of adultery.  [Para 10,11]

Section 10 is not violative of Art.14 of the constitution as held by SC in (1994) 5 SCC 704.  In the circumstances it could be held that the lower court committed illegality and impropriety in reading ground of desertion in S.10. It was impermissible to dissolve marriage by decree of divorce on ground of desertion.  Order of divorce could not be confirmed.  [Para 16,17]

heading: Decree for divorce granted to Christian husband on ground of desertion by wife
HeadNote.description: Decree for divorce granted to Christian husband on ground of desertion by wife - Dissolution of marriage under S.10 contemplates only ground of wife's adultery - Matrimonial cases are undefended and even then judges are bound to apply their mind to legal provisions - Judge cannot make non justified haste in quest of adding monthly disposal of cases. (Para 17)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of desertion - Wife had gone to visit her brother's house at Kenya without knowledge or consent of husband - Not per say amounts to desertion or final separation - Evidence shows that she attempted to join matrimonial house but husband did not allow her - In fact he issued legal notice to her after her return from Kenya - Wife did not leave matrimonial home with intention of bringing cohabitation to an end - Decree of divorce cannot be granted. (1972) 1 SCC 1 Ref. to.  	(Paras 25, 26, 27)

heading: Divorce
HeadNote.description: Divorce - On ground of cruelty - Husband alleged that wife was frigid and psychologically impotent - Not acceptable, as couple is blessed with son within year of marriage - Erroneous inference drawn merely on basis of writing wherein wife stated that she had no objection if husband had love affair or married with any girl - Considering that marital life of couple was not smooth and constant quarrels between them over trivial issues, such writing can at most be construed as expression of frustration and mental stress - Further, allegations though agreed prior to marriage, wife did not get her work schedule changed from shifts to regular office hours, which caused inconvenience to him and his mother and that she stayed at her parental house for long time without permission of husband - These allegations are nothing but ordinary wear and tear of married life and were also settled between parties with intervention of relatives - Hence, could not be ground for divorce. 2007 ALL SCR 881 Ref. to.  	(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 21, 23)

heading: Validity
Portions are severable
HeadNote.description:
Validity - Portions of section discriminatory on ground of sex - Portions are severable - Can be struck down as unconstitutional - It will not be re-writing S.10.
AIR 1995  Kerala 252 (FB) Rel.on.

heading: Release of
HeadNote.description: Requisitioned Land (Continuance of Powers) Act (1947), Ss.3, 4 - Requisition made under R.75-A - Release of - A requisition made under R.75-A and continued under later enactments could not be released without an order in writing, specifying the person to whom possession is to be given - Held, requisition subsists for want of a release order. 1980 VJ (S.C.) 340 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Requisition of land made under R.75-A
HeadNote.description:
Requisition of land made under R.75-A - Right of landlord to create a direct tenancy, not suspended merely because an order of requisition is made - Right of landlord flows from his right of ownership.

Right of a landlord to let out his premises is a right which flows from his right of ownership. This right is not extinguished merely because his property is requisitioned.

Requisitioning of a property released leads to a temporary deprivation of the landlord from using and possessing his property but otherwise does not distract from his title. It is still open for him to accept a direct tenant whose right to use and possess the property may remain suspended during the period of requisition if he is a person other than a Government allottee. That is however, different than saying that the right of the landlord, to create a direct tenancy is curtailed or suspended. A situation can be countenanced where an owner may voluntary choose to confer a direct tenancy right upon a Government allottee and if this happens without compulsion, the State Govt. allottee who is already in use and occupation may be vested with the rights and protections available to a tenant.  AIR 1984 SC 866 - Ref to.	 [Para 10,11]

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens (Amendment) Rules (2017)
heading: Suit for eviction of daughter-in-law
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction of daughter-in-law - Property devolved on plaintiff-father in law by way of Will executed by his mother - Plaintiff's son or daughter in law cannot claim any right in same - As per Delhi Maintenance Rules (2017) a senior citizen can seek eviction of his son, daughter or legal heir from an ancestral or self acquired property - Vires of said Rule, not challenged - Therefore, order of eviction cannot be faulted with - Contention that R.22(3)(1)(i) does not apply to daughter in law, also rejected as Rule cannot be interpreted in a restrictive manner.			(Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Delhi Municipal Corporation (Determination of Rateable Value) Bye-Laws (1994)
heading: Property tax
HeadNote.description:
Property tax - Determination of annual value - Where Municipal Corporation itself lays down method of determining annual value under its bye-laws, provisions of Rent Control Act would be no more relevant for said determination.
100 DLT 679 (2002) Overruled.(Para 14)

heading: Dowry
Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Dowry - Meaning of - Demand of some money for meeting domestic expenses and for purchasing manure - Not a demand for dowry - Conviction under S.304-B cannot be sustained.

In the present case, what was allegedly asked for by the accused-husband and mother-in-law of deceased was some money for meeting domestic expenses and for purchasing manure.  Since an essential ingredient of Section 304-B, I.P.C. viz., demand for dowry is not established, the conviction of the appellants cannot be sustained.

The giving or taking of property or valuable security must have some connection with the marriage of the parties and a correlation between the giving or taking of property or valuable security with the marriage of the parties is essential.  Being a penal provision it has to be strictly construed. Dowry is a fairly well known social custom or practice in India. It is well settled principle of interpretation of Statute that if the Act is passed with reference to a particular trade, business or transaction and words are used which everybody conversant with that trade, business or transaction knows or understands to have a particular meaning in it, then the words are to be construed as having that particular meaning.  A demand for money on account of some financial stringency or for meeting some urgent domestic expenses or for purchasing manure cannot be termed as a demand for dowry as the said word is normally understood. The evidence adduced by the prosecution does not, therefore, show that any demand for "dowry" as defined in Section 2 of the Dowry Prohibition Act was made by the appellants as what was allegedly asked for was some money for meeting domestic expenses and for purchasing manure. Since an essential ingredient of Section 304-B, IPC viz. demand for dowry is not established, the conviction of the appellants cannot be sustained.  [Para 9]

heading: Dowry death
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.113B - Dowry death - Basic ingredients of offence - Marriage took place on 6-3-1992 - Wife committed suicide on 27-7-1997 by consuming poison - However, there was no evidence to show that there was any cruelty or harassment for or in connection with the demand of dowry - Since prosecution failed to prove cruelty or harassment - Conviction cannot be maintained.

The basic ingredients to attract the provisions of Section 304-B are as follows :- (1)  The death of a woman should be caused by burns or fatal injury or otherwise than under normal circumstances; (2)  Such death should have occurred within seven years of her marriage; (3)  She must have been subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband; and (4)  Such cruelty or harassment should be for or in connection with demand for dowry.   [Para 11]

If Section 304-B, IPC is read together with Section 113-B of the Evidence Act, a comprehensive picture emerges that if a married woman dies in an unnatural circumstances at her matrimonial home within 7 years from her marriage and there are allegations of cruelty or harassment upon such married woman for or in connection with demand of dowry by the husband or relatives of the husband, the case would squarely come under "dowry death" and there shall be a presumption against the husband and the relatives. In this case there is practically no evidence to show that there was any cruelty or harassment for or in connection with the demand of dowry. There is also no finding in that regard. This deficiency in evidence proves fatal for the prosecution case. Even otherwise mere evidence of cruelty and harassment is not sufficient to bring in application of Section 304-B, IPC. It has to be shown in addition that such cruelty or harassment was for or in connection with the demand for dowry. Since the prosecution failed to prove that aspect the conviction as recorded cannot be maintained. 1996 SCC (Cri) 31 - Rel. on.   [Para 14,15]

heading: Murder and cruelty
Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Murder and cruelty - Appeal against conviction - Prosecution case that appellants harassed deceased for bringing less dowry and were responsible for causing burn injuries that eventually led to her death - Deceased in earlier version given to doctor about incident accuses only mother-in-law and brother-in-law of having poured kerosene upon her and set her to fire - Said version does not suggesting presence of appellants husband and father-in-law of deceased at time of incident - Order of High Court ignoring it and convicting appellants on basis of subsequent dying declaration recorded before Executive Magistrate is not proper - Hence, conviction of appellants for offence of murder is set aside - However, conviction of appellants for offence of dowry harassment u/S.498A and Ss.3, 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act is proper. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Arrest of in-laws
Powers of police
Conviction of husband
Legality
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and dowry death - Conviction of husband - Legality - Deceased died of drowning in a well within 6 months of her marriage - No post mortem done - Dead body was cremated though custom of community was of burying - Despite that, FIR was not lodged immediately - Parents of deceased attended cremation without insisting for post mortem - FIR lodged only after 4 days - No explanation for keeping quiet - No specific allegation that dowry was demanded by husband - Evidence in fact show that accused bore expenses of marriage and his relation with deceased was cordial - Dowry demand and harassment, not proved - No question of presuming dowry death - Prosecution story is doubtful - Conviction set aside. 			(Paras 19, 20, 21, 24, 26, 28)

heading: Conviction and sentence
Leniency
HeadNote.description: Conviction and sentence - Leniency - Appellant punished with imprisonment for 8 months and imposed a fine of Rs.1000/- - Appellant works as a sweeper - He is a daily wage labourer and has already suffered a month's imprisonment - He is about 58 years old, not keeping good health - To meet the ends of justice, sentence of appellant reduced to period already undergone. 	(Paras 6, 8)

heading: Dowry death
Legality
Conviction is proper
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.113-B - Dowry death - Conviction of husband and in-laws - Legality - Evidence of witnesses on record to show that deceased was ill-treated by accused on account of non satisfaction of demand of dowry - Same cannot be discarded on ground that they are close relatives of deceased - Non filing of complaint by these witnesses also cannot be a reason to disbelieve them - Medical evidence reveal that death of deceased is asphyxial due to smothering and not of dry drowning and immersion syndrome as tried to be submitted by accused - Prosecution has established ill-treatment, death of deceased being unnatural death and same being caused within 7 years of marriage - Thus, statutory presumption is available u/s.113B of Evidence Act which accused failed to rebut on preponderance of probability - Conviction is proper - No interference.
2009 ALL MR (Cri) 2118 (S.C.) Disting.			(Paras 14, 18, 22)

heading: Dowry death
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.313 - Dowry death - Circumstantial evidence shows deceased not met with natural death - Ligature mark found on the neck of deceased - Presence of accused formally established at the time of incident - Immediate steps to shift deceased to hospital, not taken by accused - Death of deceased is explained as homicidal death - Conviction, for murder would be proper - In absence of satisfactory evidence against other accused they would be entitled to be given benefit of doubt. (Paras 14, 24, 25, 26, 27)

heading: Dowry death
Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Appeal against conviction - No evidence to show that appellants, in-laws of deceased played any active role in causing death of deceased - Only allegation weighed against appellants is that there was cruelty in form of demand for some dowry - Therefore, conviction for alleged offences held, not sustainable. (Para 6)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.178(c) - Jurisdiction - Wife filing FIR at Gaya - Continuing offence committed in more local areas than one - Wife was tortured for more dowry and transferring her father's house at Gaya in husband's name - When she refused he brought her from Ranchi to Gaya and left her at her parental house warning that till his demands are met she shall stay at Gaya and if she returns without meeting those demands she would be killed - Held offence was continuing one and episode at Gaya was only a consequence of continuing offence of harassment and ill-treatment meted out to complainant, clause (c) of S.178 was attracted and impugned order of High Court that proceedings at Gaya are not maintainable could not be sustained.			(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Cruelty
Conviction for
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Conviction for - Challenge - Prosecution case that due to non-fulfillment of illegal demand, accused persons subjected deceased to cruelty due to which she committed suicide - Failure of prosecution to prove amount which was actually paid to accused towards dowry - Though statement of prosecution witnesses would reveal that attempt was made to kill deceased by accused at Surat, no report lodged by these witnesses immediately after occurrence of said incident - Occurrence of said incident not believable - Evidence of prosecution witnesses is full of omissions and improvements regarding ill treatment meted out to deceased - Therefore, unsafe to record findings of guilt against accused - Accused entitled to benefit of doubt - Conviction of accused u/S.498A, set aside. 		(Para 17)

heading: Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and dowry death - Evidence and proof - Prosecution case that deceased unable to bear torture of accused on account of dowry demand committed suicide by setting herself on fire in their house within a year of marriage - Evidence of witnesses showing that accused was in habit of consuming liquor and further deceased had been subjected to physical and mental cruelty over certain issues including demand of balance dowry - Judgment of acquittal by trial court is wholly perverse and based on conjecture and surmises - Conviction of accused is proper. 	(Paras 19, 20, 21)

heading: Conviction
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Cruelty and dowry death - Conviction - Validity - Deceased staying at maternal home committed suicide by hanging herself - No evidence to show that accused persons caused cruelty to deceased or harassed her for dowry during her period of long stay at maternal home - But it is proved that accused demanded Rs.10,000/-, a gold chain and a gold ring from family of deceased prior to marriage - Even though prosecution failed to prove major offences punishable u/Ss.498A, 304B - Accused persons could still be convicted for offences punishable u/Ss.3, 4 of DP Act. 
2000 ALL MR (Cri) 552 (S.C.) Disting. (Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and dowry death - Appeal against conviction - Death of married woman in her matrimonial house within 7 years of marriage due to burns - Accused husband was not present at home at time of incident - Evidence of witnesses that there was demand of dowry for peaceful continuance of marriage by accused persons - Not a case of accidental death as she was succumbed to burn injuries on spot - Conviction of accused u/S.498A and for offence punishable u/Ss.3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act is proper - However, in absence of evidence showing that she was harassed and ill-treated on account of demand of dowry soon before her death - Conviction of accused u/S.304B is set aside. 	(Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Jurisdiction of Court
HeadNote.description:
Criminal P.C. (1973), S.179 - Jurisdiction of Court - To entertain complaint u/S.498A IPC - Courts at place where wife takes shelter after leaving or driven away from matrimonial home on account of alleged acts of cruelty, would dependent on factual scenario, also have jurisdiction to entertain complaint u/S.498A. 
2019 ALL SCR (Cri) 1451 Rel. on. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Dowry
HeadNote.description: Dowry - Expression in connection with marriage used in S.2 of Act of 1961 cannot be given restricted or a narrower meaning - Alleged demand of Rs. 1,00,000/- for business purpose and one motorcycle from deceased by applicants - Comes under purview of definition of dowry and amendment thereto. (Para 18)

heading: Cruelty and dowry demand
HeadNote.description: Cruelty and dowry demand - Allegations against husband and sister-in-law - Married sister-in-law stayed with parents for some days - During these days she allegedly directed complainant to wash W.C. and insulted her and made derogatory remarks against her - But these remarks did not amount to harassment with a view to coerce informant or her relations to meet unlawful demand for dowry or property - Bald allegations made against her seemed only to have been made with a view to rope her in the case - Held, proceedings against her were liable to be quashed. Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482.			(Para 6)

heading: Dowry death
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Evidence and proof - Amount of Rs.10,000/- was demanded by appellant through deceased was for repayment - It had no connection with marriage of appellant and deceased - Hence, it was not a demand in connection with dowry and offence under S.304 was not attracted. 	(Para 7)

heading: Cruelty
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Evidence and proof - Demand of Rs.10,000/- towards society loan made by appellant - Though may not be a demand in connection with dowry - But is certainly an unlawful demand for a property or valuable security - Also there is evidence showing that deceased was subjected to harassment by appellant on account of her failure to meet said demand of Rs.10,000 - Conviction of accused for offence under S.498A and under Ss.3, 4 and 6 of Dowry Prohibition Act is proper. 			(Paras 8, 10, 11)

heading: Dowry demand
HeadNote.description: Dowry demand - Evidence of brothers of deceased that Rs.60,000/- were demanded for appellant's business and for that amount deceased was harassed with cruelty - Such demand is in connection with dowry demand and therefore, dowry demand. (Para 16)

heading: Dowry death
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Term "dowry" includes demands made even subsequent to marriage.			(Para 7)

heading: Demand for dowry
HeadNote.description:
Demand for dowry - Is by itself punishable - Agreement for payment of dowry is not required to be proved.

The offence alleged against the respondents is under Section 304-B, I.P.C. which makes "demand of dowry" itself punishable. Demand neither conceives nor would conceive of any agreement. If for convicting any offender, agreement for dowry is to be proved, hardly any offenders would come under the clutches of law. When Section 304-B refers to "demand of dowry", it refers to the demand of property or valuable security as referred to in the definition of "dowry" under the Act. The argument that there is no demand of dowry, in the present case, has no force. In cases of dowry deaths  and suicides, circumstantial evidence plays an important role and inferences can be drawn on the basis of such evidence. That could be either direct or indirect. It is significant that Section 4 of the Act, was also amended by means of Act 63 of 1984, under which it is an offence to demand dowry directly or indirectly from the parents or other relatives or guardian of a bride. The word "agreement" referred to in Section 2 has to be inferred on  the facts and circumstances of each case. The interpretation that the respondents seek, that conviction can only be if there is agreement for dowry, is misconceived. This would be contrary to the mandate and object of the Act. "Dowry" definition is to be interpreted with the other provisions of the Act including Section 3, which refers to giving or taking dowry and Section 4 which deals with a penalty for demanding dowry, under the Act and the I. P. This makes it clear that even demand of dowry on other ingredients being  satisfied is punishable. It is not always necessary that there be any agreement for dowry.   [Para 8]

heading: Evidence Act (1872), S.113-A
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.113-A - Cruelty, abetment to suicide - Two months prior to the date of F.I.R. deceased had developed eye problem - Instead of taking deceased to a doctor the accused-husband took her to one Swamiji - Accused-husband and sister-in-law used to torture and assault her - Evidence and circumstances show deceased received the eye injury in the matrimonial home and the appellant was responsible for it - Evidence show that prior to taking cyanide poison in the matrimonial home, deceased was beaten - Accused did not rebut the presumption under Section 113A of Evidence Act - Evidence on record establishes that deceased was subjected to mental and physical cruelty which drove her to commit suicide - Held, accused is guilty of abetment - Conviction upheld. 

When a woman is subjected to ill-treatment within the four walls of her matrimonial house, ill-treatment is witnessed only by the perpetrators of the crime. They would certainly not depose about it. It is common knowledge that independent witnesses like servants or neighbours do not want to get involved. [Para 3,7,9,11,15]

heading: Dowry death
Evidence and proof
False plea taken
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Evidence and proof - Deceased died of burn injuries within 7 yrs. of her marriage - Plea of accused husband and mother in law that they had no idea about incident and were sleeping when police picked them up - Said plea is inconsistent with dying declaration produced by themselves which stated that deceased was shifted to hospital by her mother in law - False plea taken - Further, had it been a case of accident, deceased would have tried to run away and could not suffer extensive burns of 95% - Circumstances support the version of unnatural death - There is overwhelming evidence to prove dowry demand which would not be rejected for minor discrepancies as to place of demand or witnesses to such demand - Accused persons liable to be convicted. 			(Paras 15, 17, 18, 20, 23)

heading: Dowry death
Proof
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Cruelty in connection of dowry - Proof - Categorical statement in immediately lodged FIR that deceased was tortured by her in-laws - Though there was no assertion that such torture related to dowry demand - Held, FIR is not expected to contain all the details - It is sufficient if broad facts are mentioned - Money was given to in-laws both prior to marriage and after marriage - Alleged cruelty could only be in connection of dowry.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Dowry death
Appeal against conviction
Not reliable
HeadNote.description:
Dowry death - Appeal against conviction - Father of deceased immediately lodged FIR and clearly stated about torture by in-laws - His version cannot be disbelieved merely because details of money paid was not given in FIR - Evidence given in court as to payment of money is supported by bank statement of father of deceased - Brother of deceased also stated about dowry demand - His statement cannot be disbelieved merely because it was recorded with delay - Particularly when investigating officer was not questioned about such delay in recording statement - Defence relied on suicide note and letter showing previous affair of deceased with a boy - However, same were not recovered during investigation but produced by accused with their bail application - Not reliable - Conviction proper.

2005 ALL MR (Cri) 786 (S.C.), 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 2817 (S.C.), 2015 ALL MR (Cri) 1651 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 12, 20, 24, 25, 35, 39)

heading: Dowry death
Reduction in sentence
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Reduction in sentence - Appellant husband is in custody for more than 5 yrs - Occurrence was of year 1997 - Sentence of husband reduced from life imprisonment to 10 yrs - Parents in law are aged about 70 yrs and 64 yrs and also suffering from various ailments - Their sentence reduced to imprisonment of 7 yrs each. 	(Para 41)

heading: Dowry death
Circumstantial evidence
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.113B - Dowry death - Circumstantial evidence - Death occurred within seven years of marriage - Her body found in the well - Ante-mortem injuries suffered by her established that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty - Demand for Rs.40,000/- for purchasing Hero Honda could not be fulfilled by father of deceased - This demand could not be termed as a demand for any urgent domestic cause - Deceased often went to parent's house to complain about ill-treatment, she left her child behind and returned to matrimonial home - Hence demand of Rs.40,000/- was a dowry demand - Held presumption was it was a dowry death and all the circumstances unerringly pointed to guilt of accused. 2007 ALL MR (Cri) 859 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 1796, 2007 ALL SCR 2347, AIR 2007 SC 3146, 2003 ALL MR (Cri) 1784 (S.C.), 2003 ALL MR (Cri) 2398 (S.C.) - Distinguished.	(Para 29)

heading: Dowry death
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Essential ingredients of the offence - For the purpose of this Section, "dowry" shall have same meaning as provided in S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Demand of dowry has to be for or in connection with marriage - From mere demand one cannot come to conclusion that demand was for marriage. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Quashing of process
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C.
