(1973), S.482 - Cruelty, dowry demand and criminal breach of trust - Quashing of process - Allegations made in complaint and also depositions of witnesses would prima facie indicate meeting out of cruelty by accused to complainant due to her failure to meet alleged demand of dowry - Money was not demanded only for meeting expenses of marriage but also in connection with purposes of marriage -Thus, the offence prima facie fall within concept of cruelty and dowry u/S.498A - That apart, allegation as to criminal breach of trust, made only against mother-in-law i.e. accused no.3 - Thus, essential ingredients of offence u/S.406 i.e. entrustment of ornaments and refusal to part with property, not prima facie made out against remaining accused - As such, order of issuance of process against both remaining accused for offence u/S.406 deserved to be quashed - Whereas, impugned order for offence u/S.498A, maintained. (Paras 9, 12, 18, 20)

heading: Dowry death
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description:
Dowry death - Evidence and proof - Deceased was allegedly ill-treated on account of fact that gold ornaments were not given at time of "ojhe" festival - Demand of gold ornaments in relation to some custom/ceremonies/festivals prevalent in particular society - Cannot constitute dowry within meaning of S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Aspect of ill treatment being on account of non satisfaction of demand of "dowry" not proved - Accused cannot be convicted for offence of dowry.

	A demand for property or valuable security, can come within the ambit of dowry, provided the same is made in "connection with the marriage" of the parties. If such a demand is not made in connection with marriage, the same would not amount to dowry. For example, some customary payments/gifts made in connection with birth of a child or other ceremonies or local festivals, would not come within the ambit of dowry. In the present case, prosecution evidence clearly brings out that, it was mother-in-law who was not satisfied with the articles brought by deceased at the time of "ojhe" as she was expecting gold ornaments along with other articles and it was the mother-in-law who was harassing deceased . Only allegation against accused husband of deceased is that he was a "mute spectator" to the ill treatment meted out to deceased by his mother. Thus, it is clear that the demand of gold ornaments/valuables cannot be said to be a demand for "dowry" as it was not made in connection with marriage. Although the fact that the deceased met with unnatural death, within seven years of marriage is established, the aspect of ill treatment being on account of non-satisfaction of demand of "dowry" considered cannot be said to be proved. Thus, the conviction of accused under S. 304-B cannot be sustained. 				 [Para 22,31,32]

heading: Dowry death
Quashing of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Dowry death - Quashing of proceedings - Appellants in-laws of deceased facing prosecution for offence u/Ss.6, 3, 4, of DP Act and also for Ss.498A, 304B IPC - Offence u/S.6 not made out - Even though proceeding u/S.6 is independent of prosecution u/Ss.3, 4 of DP Act, in absence of specific allegations of entrustment of dowry amount and articles to appellants - Continuation of proceedings against them, not just and proper - Same liable to be quashed. (Para 13)

heading: Dowry death
Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.378 - Dowry death - Appeal against acquittal - Death of deceased occurring under unnatural circumstances and within seven years of her marriage - But no evidence showing that deceased was being ill-treated on account of demand of dowry - Further, demand also cannot be said to be in consideration of marriage, within meaning of S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Acquittal of accused persons, not perverse - No interference.  (Paras 15, 16)

heading: Dowry death
Presumption as to
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.113B - Dowry death - Presumption as to - No evidence showing that on account of demand of dowry deceased was ever ill-treated by accused persons - Prosecution on basis of vague and inconsistent statements of parental relatives of deceased failed to establish that soon before death deceased was subjected to ill treatment for demand of "dowry" - Presumption u/S.113B of Evidence Act therefore, cannot be drawn against accused persons. 	(Paras 36, 39)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Quashing of proceedings - Offence u/Ss.498-A, 506(ii) of IPC - Material on record showing that accused persons who were relatives of complainant and her husband were living at different address when alleged demand of dowry was made - Further, specific allegations were against husband and his immediate family members - No specific allegations made against accused-relatives - Proceedings against them liable to be quashed. 	(Para 7)

heading: Quashing of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Quashing of proceedings - Allegations of dowry demand against distant relatives of husband - No specific role attributed and no material produced to establish role of such distant relatives - Held, mere naming of distant relations, is not enough - Criminal proceedings against them is abuse of courts process - Liable to be quashed.(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Cruelty
Dowry death
HeadNote.description: Cruelty - Dowry death - In both dying declarations victim stated that she had caught fire accidentally - Till the previous day of incident there is not even a whisper of any demand being made - "Dowry", as defined in section 2 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, requires it to be a property of valuable security given in connection with the marriage of the parties - Conviction based on stray demands having nothing to do with the marriage, cannot be sustained.(Para 8, 10)

heading: Accused charged, for the demand of dowry coupled with harassment
HeadNote.description: Accused charged, for the demand of dowry coupled with harassment - Offence under Section 304-B not proved - Conviction under Sections 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act cannot be sustained. (Para 6)

heading: Penalty for demanding dowry
HeadNote.description: Penalty for demanding dowry - Demand of Rs.5,000/- made by accused to meet agricultural expenses - Would not be treated as demand of "dowry" within meaning of S.2 - Basic ingredients of S.304B of IPC, not proved - Conviction u/S.4 is not sustainable. 	(Paras 14, 18, 19, 20)

heading: Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.73, 45 - Dowry death and cruelty - Evidence and proof - Demand if any, made by appellant on deceased for purchasing a computer to start business six months after marriage - Not in connection with marriage and not really a 'dowry demand' within meaning of S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Only general allegations of harassment were made and there were no specific act of cruelty or harassment by appellant on deceased - Trial Court and High Court without resorting to provisions of Ss.45 and 73 of Evidence Act disbelieved defence of appellant that suicide note could not have written by deceased - Prosecution failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt ingredient of harassment or cruelty - Neither of the offences under Ss.498 A and 304 B has been made out by prosecution.		 (Paras 6, 8, 9, 10)

heading: Enforcement of Act
HeadNote.description: Enforcement of Act - Apathy resulting into thoroughly unsatisfactory enforcement of the provisions of the Act - Supreme Court, hence, directed more rigorous and effective implementation of the Act by issuing certain directions.	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Demand of dowry
Benefit of doubt
HeadNote.description: Demand of dowry - Benefit of doubt - Allegation that accused demanded cash amount of Rs. 5 lakhs and gold weighing 15 tolas - Complainant did not mention fact of demand of dowry in his police statement - However, in cross-examination complainant stating about demand of dowry by accused - It was an improvement made by complainant in his evidence - Accused entitled to acquittal by giving benefit of doubt. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Dowry death
Conviction for
HeadNote.description: Dowry death - Conviction for - Husband or relatives of husband subjecting victim to cruelty - Alleged demand and payment of part of dowry - No clinching evidence about any prior communication by victim about ill-treatment - Harassment for non-payment of balance of dowry of Rs.10,000/-, doubtful as ornament allegedly given as security - Entire evidence of harassment surfaced only after incident and comes in form of improvement - Person at whose instance report made seven days after incident not examined - Only harassment that was reported by victim was taunting or abuses and harassment reported by witnesses does not qualify to be cruelty as per S.498A - Sentence imposed upon accused cannot be sustained. 	(Paras 16 to 20)

heading: Demand of dowry
Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Demand of dowry - Appeal against conviction - Deceased committed suicide due to cancellation of marriage with accused no.1 - When mother of deceased had gone to house of accused for fixing date of marriage accused no.1 allegedly demanded Rs.50,000/- in cash, gold chain and ring - As per mother of deceased when alleged demand was made, all accused were present at house of accused no.1 - If mother of deceased had gone to house of accused no.1 without pre-intimation, presence of all accused at same time including sister and brother-in-law of accused is highly improbable - No evidence on record to show any premeditated concert between accused persons - Family of accused no.1 was aware of poor economic condition of family of deceased, and that no demand was made before or at the time of engagement - Nor they conveyed any demand through relatives of deceased - In dying declaration deceased stated that her father did not look after accused no.1 and his family - Possibility that engagement was cancelled by accused persons for reason unconnected with dowry demand - Prosecution failed to prove case beyond reasonable doubt - Accused persons entitled to be acquitted. AIR 1955 S.C.216 Ref. to. 			(Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Dowry death
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.113B - Dowry death - Evidence and proof - Unnatural death of wife within one year of marriage while she was in custody of her husband - Explanation by husband that deceased wife was getting epileptic fits and suffered injury while she was being carried in bullock cart to hospital, was false - Evidence on record that there was demand of dowry from husband and in-laws and on non-fulfillment she was ill treated - Presumption under S.113B of Evidence Act attracted - Accused persons liable to be convicted under Ss.304B and 498A and S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act. 			(Paras 24, 25, 28, 32, 34 to 37)

heading: Demand of dowry
Quashing of proceedings
Returned said amount
HeadNote.description:
Demand of dowry - Quashing of proceedings - Applicants groom and other persons during the time of engagement ceremony specifically demanded and received Rs.1,50,000/- towards motor vehicle, band and video recording etc. - Returned said amount - But subsequently made further demand of Rs.2,50,000/- and dictated that if said further demand was not met by complainant, they would return earlier amount received by them and call off marriage ceremony - Said allegations are covered by definition of "dowry" u/S.2 of Dowry Prohibition Act - Thus, continuation of proceedings against applicants u/S.4 of said Act, would not amount to abuse of process of law - Proceedings not liable to be quashed. 
2010 ALL MR (Cri) 2947 (S.C.) Disting.			(Paras 8, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Expression "agreed to be given"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "agreed to be given" - Must be construed in the light of Ss.3 and 4 - Contention that conviction can only be if there is agreement for dowry is misconceived.

The interpretation that conviction can only be if there is agreement for dowry, is misconceived. This would be contrary to the mandate and object of the Act. "Dowry" definition is to be interpreted with the other provisions of the Act including Section 3, which refers to giving or taking dowry and Section 4 which deals with a penalty for demanding dowry, under the Act and the IPC. This makes it clear that even demand of dowry on other ingredients being satisfied is punishable. It is not always necessary that there be any agreement for dowry.   [Para 9]

heading: "Expressions" in connection with the marriage
HeadNote.description:
"Expressions" in connection with the marriage - Cannot be given restricted or a narrower meaning.

All the expressions used in S.2 are of a very wide magnitude. The expressions 'or any time after marriage' and 'in connection with the marriage of the said parties' were introduced by amending Act 63 of 1984 and Act 43 of 1986 with effect from 02.10.1985 and 19.11.1986 respectively. These amendments appear to have been made with the intention to cover all demands at the time, before and even after the marriage so far they were in connection with the marriage of the said parties. This clearly shows the intent of the legislature that these expressions are of wide meaning and scope. The expression 'in connection with the marriage' cannot be given a restricted or a narrower meaning. The expression 'in connection with the marriage' even in common parlance and on its plain language has to be understood generally. The object being that everything, which is offending at any time i.e. at, before or after the marriage, would be covered under this definition, but the demand of dowry has to be 'in connection with the marriage' and not so customary that it would not attract, on the face of it, the provisions of this section.   [Para 11]

heading: "Dowry"
HeadNote.description:
"Dowry" - Meaning of.

The definition of 'dowry' is not restricted to agreement or demand for payment of dowry before and at the time of marriage but even include subsequent demands, where the husband had demanded a specific sum from his father-in-law and upon not being given, harassed and tortured the wife and after some days she died, such cases would clearly fall within the definition of 'dowry' under the Act. Section 4 of the Act is the penal Section and demanding a 'dowry', as defined under Section 2 of the Act, is punishable under this section.   [Para 12,13]

heading: Expressions "demand for dowry" and "in connection with the marriage"
HeadNote.description:
Expressions "demand for dowry" and "in connection with the marriage" - Must be given appropriate meaning to avoid undue harassment or advantage to either of the parties.

The cruelty and harassment by the husband or any relative could be directly relatable to or in connection with, any demand for dowry. The expression 'demand for dowry' will have to be construed ejusdem generis to the word immediately preceding this expression. Similarly, 'in connection with the marriage' is an expression which has to be given a wider connotation. It is of some significance that these expressions should be given appropriate meaning to avoid undue harassment or advantage to either of the parties. These are penal provisions but ultimately these are the social legislations, intended to control offences relating to the society as a whole. Dowry is something which existed in our country for a considerable time and the legislature in its wisdom considered it appropriate to enact the law relating to dowry prohibition so as to ensure that any party to the marriage is not harassed or treated with cruelty for satisfaction of demands in consideration and for subsistence of the marriage.   [Para 16]

heading: Object and implementation of Act
HeadNote.description:
Object and implementation of Act - Role of society in controlling and combating the evil.

Daily, demon of dowry is devouring lives of young girls, who marry with high hopes of having heavenly abode in their husband's house. In few cases, guilty are punished but it has no deterrent effect on mothers-in-law or sisters-in-law who might have suffered similar cruelty/tyranny. This deep rooted social evil requires to be controlled not only by effective implementation of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961, but also by the Society. The Society has to find out ways and means of controlling and combating this menace of receipt and payment of dowry. It appears that instead of controlling payment and receipt of dowry in one or other form, it is increasing even in educated class. May be that it is increasing because of accumulation of unaccounted wealth with few and others having less means follow the same out of compulsion. [Para 1]

heading: Definition of dowry
HeadNote.description:
Definition of dowry - Object of the Act - Denial of benefit of doubt to accused - Necessity of the provision.

The Act was enacted to provide an effective check to dowry deaths which were continuing despite the then prevailing laws. The object of the Bill was to prohibit the evil practice of giving and taking of dowry. This objective was not achieved hence drastic amendments were brought in by amending various provisions of the said Act and the related provisions under the Indian Penal Code and the Evidence Act. Earlier, the definition of 'dowry' which was limited to the time at or before the marriage was extended to the period even after the marriage by means of Act 43 of 1986 w.e.f.  November 19, 1986. Similarly, Section 304-B was introduced by means of the same amending Act and Section 498-A was introduced by Criminal Law (Second Amendment) Act, 1983 (Act 46 of 1983). Various other amendments were brought in bringing more stringent provisions in the aforesaid 1961 Act in order to stem the onslaught on the life of a married woman.  [Para 10]

It is true that in criminal jurisprudence benefit of doubt is extendable to the accused. But that benefit of doubt would arise in the context of the application of penal law, and in the facts and circumstances of a case. The concept of benefit of doubt has an important role to play but within the confines of the stringency of laws. Since the cause of death to a married woman was to occur not in normal circumstances but as a 'dowry death', for which the evidence was not to (too) easily available, as it is mostly confined to within four walls of a house, namely husband's house where all likely accused reside. Hence the aforesaid amendments brought in the concept of deemed 'dowry death' by the husband or the relatives, as the case may be. This deeming clause has a role to play and cannot be taken lightly and ignored to shield an accused otherwise the very purpose of the amendment will be lost. Of course, the prosecution has to prove the ultimate essential ingredients beyond all reasonable doubt after raising the initial presumption of 'deemed dowry death'.  [Para 11]

heading: Dowry
Periphery of dowry
Connotation of
HeadNote.description:
Dowry - Periphery of dowry - Words "agreed to be given" - Connotation of - Penal Code (1860), S.304B.

The word 'agreement' referred to in Section 2 has to be inferred on the facts and circumstances of each case. The interpretation that the appellant seeks, that conviction can only be if there is agreement for dowry, is misconceived. This would be contrary to the mandate and object of the Act. "Dowry" definition is to be interpreted with the other provisions of the Act including Section 3, which refers to giving or taking dowry and Section 4 - Penalty for demanding dowry, under the 1961 Act and the Indian Penal Code. This makes it clear that even demand of dowry on other ingredients being satisfied is punishable. This leads to the inference, when persistent demands for TV and scooter are made from the bride after marriage or from her parents, it would constitute to be in connection with the marriage and it would be a case of demand of dowry within the meaning of Section 304-B, IPC. It is not always necessary that there be any agreement for dowry.  [Para 16]

In the present case after few days of the marriage there was demand of scooter and fridge, which when not being met lead to repetitive taunts and maltreatment. Such demands cannot be said to be not in connection with the marriage. Hence the evidence qualifies to be demand for dowry in connection with the marriage and in the circumstances of the case constitutes to be a case falling within the definition of 'dowry' under Section 2 of 1961 Act and Section 304-B, IPC.  [Para 17]

heading: Penal Code (1860), S.304B
HeadNote.description: Penal Code (1860), S.304B - Death of wife within seven years of marriage - Arranged marriage did not materialise as the bride groom did not turn up - Accused agreeing to marry on payment of Rs.10,000/- and three gold sovereigns - Marriage taking place on payment of Rs.8000/- and promise to pay remaining amount after harvesting the crops - Harassment started on failure to pay remaining amount - Body of deceased recovered from the well and doctor opining that death was homicidal and not suicidal - But links in the chain of circumstances not conclusively established to hold accused guilty - Acquittal under S.302 confirmed but accused held guilty under S.304 B and sentenced to 10 years R. I.	(Paras 14,22,23)

heading: Dowry demand

HeadNote.description: Dowry demand - Proof - Evidence to the effect that accused received money from mother and sister-in-laws of deceased - Parents of deceased deposing demand of dowry - Merely because there was omission on part of sister-in-law to state that she too accompanied mother of deceased to handover money to accused would not justify conclusion that prosecution failed to justify its case - Such a finding ignoring relevant evidence about demand of dowry cannot be sustained even in an appeal against acquittal - Conviction under Dowry Prohibition Act was justified.	(Paras 9, 10)

HeadNote.description: Penalty for giving and taking dowry - Ambit and scope of sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Act is different from the ambit and scope of section 498-A of Penal Code. Penal Code (1860), S.188A.	(Para 41)

HeadNote.description: Sentence - Minimum sentence of 5 years imprisonment and fine of Rs.15,000/- - Is mandatory - No discretion is left to the Courts in the matter of the imposing fine - For imposing sentence of less than five years imprisonment adequate and special reasons are required to be recorded. 2000(40) ACC 136 - Rel. on. Scope of definition
HeadNote.description:

2007 ALL MR (Cri) 859 (S.C.) Held Not Good Law.	()

Word "marriage
HeadNote.description: Dowry - Definition of - Word "marriage - Definition of - Word "marriage" in the definition - Would include a proposed marriage also more particularly where non-fulfilment of "demand of dowry" leads to ugly consequence of marriage not taking place at all.	(Para 15)

heading: Dowry
HeadNote.description: Dowry - Mere demand of dowry is sufficient to bring home offence to an accused.			(Para 15)

HeadNote.description: Demand for dowry - Could be direct or indirect - There may be no direct evidence of agreement - Yet circumstances may be so eloquent that demand for dowry could be easily spelt out. 2009 ALL MR (Cri) 588 (S.C.) Rel. on.			(Para 21)

heading: "Dowry"
HeadNote.description: "Dowry" - Amount spent by parents of bride towards clothes and marriage expenses - Do not fall within term "dowry" in view of S.3(2) - Thus, customary presents, value of which is not excessive do not fall within definition of term "dowry". (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Dowry
HeadNote.description:
Dowry - Parties governed by Muslim Sheriath law - Giving of household articles, new clothes and wrist watch to bridegroom accepted a customary - But payment of cash of Rs.25,000/- cannot be said to be customary - It is nothing but dowry.

There are no circumstance to indicate that the payment of cash of Rs.25.000/- was as per the custom. On the other hand the positive evidence clearly establishes that payment of money in cash was only as dowry and nothing else. In our considered opinion, even if there is a custom in any community to pay substantial money to the bridegroom either before or at or after the marriage, it would be contrary to the very object for which D.P. Act has been enacted and it defeats the very object which the Act sought to be achieved, such payments are kept outside the definition of 'Dowry' on the premise that it is customary, it would defeat the purpose of the Act, and in all cases the accused could relieve themselves from the rigor of law by describing it as customary. Therefore. such payments can never be construed as customary and it has to be accepted as dowry only.   [Para 24]

heading: Proof
HeadNote.description: Offence of giving or taking dowry - Proof - Accused alleged to have been paid Rs.7,000/- against his demand of Rs.15,000/- from father of girl for securing admission to B.Ed. Course - Said demand has no nexus with demand made in consideration of marriage - As it was stated by complainant that they have mutually agreed to give Rs. 33,000/- in cash and gold ring of 10 gms. to accused in his marriage - Complainant nowhere stated that amount demanded as dowry or amount demanded as part of amount agreed to be given as dowry in marriage - Alleged demand and payment is not covered by definition of 'dowry' u/S. 2 of Act which is necessary to attract offence u/S.3 of Act - Also there was material discrepancies in complaint of complainant and facts deposed by him before Court relating to payment of amount to accused - Except testimony of complainant there was no other evidence to prove alleged demand and payment of amount - There was no evidence to prove alleged demand made towards dowry - Conviction of accused for offence u/S.3 liable to be set aside. (Paras 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Necessary ingredients
HeadNote.description: Offence of giving or taking dowry - Necessary ingredients - To constitute an offence u/S. 3 of Act, it is necessary that an act attributed against accused must necessarily amount to an act of giving or taking dowry - It necessarily means that such giving or taking property or valuable security must be in consideration of marriage. 	(Para 10)

heading: Entrustment of dowry
Explanation
HeadNote.description: Entrustment of dowry - Explanation - Giving of dowry and traditional presents at or about time of wedding - Does not, in any way raise a presumption that such a property was thereby entrusted and put under the dominion of the parents-in-law of the bride or other close relations so as to attract ingredients of S.6 of Dowry Prohibition Act. (Para 13)

heading: Refusal to accept
HeadNote.description:
Allotment of agricultural land - Refusal to accept - Provisions of R.61 operate only when there is express refusal to accept the allotment of any agricultural land - The consequence prescribed is that the claim of such allottee for compensation to that extent is deemed to have been satisfied - Such land then becomes available for allotment to any other claimant - Therefore, held, even if allotment is refused, the claim towards compensation is deemed to have been satisfied and thus in statement of accounts his entitlement to compensation gets reduced to that extent.

(1995) 5 SCC 302 - Ref. to. (Para 19)

heading: Time limit
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land to displaced persons - To make good verified claim - Time limit - Predecessor-in-interest of appellant had not raised any grievance during his lifetime and for more than 13 years of his death - Appellant cannot agitate issue which have attained finality - Successor in interest is also required to file claim before date fixed by S.4.			(Para 32)

heading: Transfer of title
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of title - Property forming part of compensation pool put to public auction - Transfer becomes effective when full purchase price is paid by auction purchaser.

The legal position with regard to transfer of title in respect of the property forming part of the compensation pool put to public auction under Rule 90 of the 1955 Rules may be summarized thus : on approval of the highest bid by the Competent Authority, a binding contract for the sale of the property to the auction-purchaser comes into existence. Once the payment of the full purchase price is made, title in the property would pass to an auction-purchaser. In other words, on the payment of the full purchase price, the ownership in the property sold in public auction would stand transferred but the transfer formally becomes complete on issuance of the certificate of sale. If in the sale certificate, any particular date is mentioned as provided in the proforma appended to Rule 90, such date mentioned in the sale certificate may be presumed to be the date on which the purchase has become effective but crucial date for transfer of ownership in the property in favour of auction-purchaser is the date when full purchase price has been paid by the auction-purchaser.  [Para 32]

heading: Hoardings on
Lawfulness
Heritage Conservation Committee
HeadNote.description:
Heritage buildings and heritage precincts - Hoardings on - Lawfulness - Heritage Conservation Committee - Powers and duty of - Municipal Commissioner's power to override - Limited to exceptional cases.

Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act (1888), Ss.328, 328A.

In the instant writ petition by way of public interest litigation, the lawfulness of hoardings on heritage buildings and heritage precincts in Mumbai was challenged.  During pendency of the petition, a batch of writ petitions were filed by hoarding owners and by persons claiming an entitlement to display advertisements and hoardings situated on heritage buildings.  The Court appointed an Expert Committee and after considering its report came to the conclusion that there was no merit in the legal challenges preferred before the Court on behalf of the hoarding owners and advertisers, yet, it was inappropriate for the Court to deal with the facts of each individual case under Article 226 bereft of a decision by the Heritage Conservation Committee.  The Expert Committee appointed by the Court carried out a mammoth exercise.  Nevertheless, having regard to the role and position of the Heritage Conservation Committee, the Court left it to that Committee to consider individual cases after furnishing an opportunity to the advertisers and hoarding owners to submit their representation.  The Heritage Conservation Committee observed in its Report that "the vast majority of the hoardings have been erected to the detriment and prejudice of the heritage value of such structures, public open spaces and precincts".  The Committee was of the view that while by and large hoardings should not be permitted at listed heritage buildings and structures and in their compounds or in and around listed public open spaces or within heritage precincts, it should be open to the Committee to permit a display in exceptional cases if certain conditions are satisfied.  The Report of the Committee recommending removal of hoardings from various heritage buildings and precincts was not accepted by the Municipal Commissioner.

Held, that the action of the Municipal Commissioner in overriding the Report of the Heritage Conservation Committee suffered from the following illegalities -

i)	Though certain precincts were listed under Regn.67(2) the Development Control Regulations as Heritage precincts, the Municipal Commissioner treated them as not listed. 

ii)	Regulation 67(2) mandates that the Commissioner "shall act on the advice of/in consultation with" the Heritage Conservation Committee.  The power of the Municipal Commissioner to overrule the decision of the Committee is confined to exceptional cases and for reasons to be recorded in writing.  The power is to be exercised by the Commissioner himself and is not to be delegated to any other officer.  However, in the instant case the Municipal Commissioner had overridden the Heritage Committee without there being any exceptional reasons.  The personal view of the Municipal Commissioner regarding urban aesthetics could not be allowed to transgress the restraints on the exercise of his own administrative powers.  [Para 14]

iii)	The Heritage Conservation Committee acted intra vires its powers in framing Guidelines for regulation of hoardings and billboards.  In view of the broad sweep of the expression "development" under the Act, the regulation of hoardings and billboards does fall within the ambit of Regulation 67.  The provisions of Regulation 67 will be defeated - and with it the salutary public interest in conserving and protecting heritage structures and precincts - if the regulation of hoardings and billboards is to be carved out of Regulation 67.  That cannot be done.  The power to frame guidelines is also expressly conferred upon the Committee by clause 4.9 of its terms of reference.  The decision which has been arrived at by the Municipal Commissioner is patently perverse.  The decision is based on a wrong and incorrect perception of the nature of his powers under Regulation 67(2).  The decision is based on a demonstrably incorrect appreciation of the applicable principles of law embodied in the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966.  [Para 21,24]

iv)	Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus is listed as a grade one heritage structure.  13 hoardings which are on or in the compound of the Terminus are admittedly not of exempted category since they are plainly of commercial nature.  However, the Municipal Commissioner did not give any finding thereon on the ground that they are situated within Railway premises.  Thus the Municipal Commissioner failed to notice the governing statutory provisions and thus failed to discharge statutory obligation imposed upon him.					      [Para 24]

v)	The Municipal Commissioner was also not justified in wholly rejecting the recommendations of the Heritage Conservation Committee in relation to hoardings situated in Heritage precincts, hoardings situated in the compound of Grade-II structures and hoardings on all Grade-III structures.  Grade-III structures have been excluded in one fell stroke without an application of mind to the relevant provisions.  The Municipal Commissioner evidently ignores that for Grade-I buildings and precincts "absolutely essential and minimal changes would be allowed and they must be in accord with the original".  For Grade-II(A), adaptive reuse or external changes are "subject to strict scrutiny".  For Grade-II(B), the need to preserve harmony and the need not to detract from existing heritage buildings and precincts, especially in terms of height and facade is emphasised.  Yet the Commissioner permits all hoardings in the compounds of Grade-II structures, irrespective of height and facade.  Even in the case of Grade-III buildings, the regulation requires that "unless absolutely essential nothing should spoil or destroy any special features or attributes for which it is placed in the Heritage List".  None of these vital principles finds mention in the approach of the Municipal Commissioner as elucidated before this Court.  The view taken by the Municipal Commissioner in so far as he differed with the Heritage Conservation Committee is manifestly unsustainable and must, therefore, be quashed and set aside. 					         [Para 25,26]

HeadNote.act_name: Dadra and Nagar Haveli Land Reforms Regulations (1971)
heading: Transfer of occupancy rights
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of occupancy rights - Expression "otherwise" occurring in S.4(6) - It is not a word of limitation but extension so as to cover all possible ways in which transfer of occupancy rights may occur - Law maker has been cautious and by use of expression "otherwise" sought to plug all avenues of escape.

Merely because the document has been entitled "agreement" it would not cease to be document of sale if vendor divested himself of his right, title and interest in the said land by such document, received full consideration and handed over possession to the purchaser.  Assuming that the document dated 16-6-1975 is not sale by itself, the question that arises is:  whether by the said document there was transfer of the occupancy rights and such transfer is hit by sub-section (6) of section 4.

The expression "otherwise" occurring in sub-section (6) of section 4 cannot be read to mean transaction as narrated proceeding thereto alone like transfer by way of sale, lease, mortgage or exchange.  The instances of transfer by way of sale, lease, mortgage and exchange in section 4(6) are only illustrative and not exhaustive.  There may be some other transfers besides instances of transfer stated in sub-section (6) of section 4 and word "otherwise" has been used keeping that in mind.  By use of the expression "otherwise", the law makers have given an extended meaning to include the transactions of transfer which are otherwise not covered by way of sale, lease, mortgage and exchange but whereby the occupancy rights have been transferred.  By use of the word "otherwise", apparently, the law makers intended to cover other cases of transfer of occupancy rights which may not come within the meaning of preceding instances.  What seems to us is that law makers intended to cover all possible cases of transfer in relation to the occupancy rights for whatever reasons and by whatever modes.  The word "otherwise" has been used in all inclusive sense.  The law maker has been cautious and by use of expression "otherwise" sought to plug all avenues of escape.  The word "otherwise" is not a word of limitation but extension so as to cover all possible ways in which transfer of occupancy rights may occur.

1975 Mh.L.J. 566 - Rel on.  2001(4) ALL MR 116 - Distinguished.  [Para 7,10]

heading: Property tax
HeadNote.description:
Delhi Electricity Reforms (Transfer Scheme) Rules (2001), Rr.3, 4, Sch.F Items I, II, III - Property tax - Liability of power distribution company (NDPL) to pay - NDPL was a licensee of Govt. - S.120(1)(c) contemplates that a person who has right to let out un-let land is liable to pay tax - His status as a lessor or licensee is irrelevant - If distribution license empowers Distribution company to let out the land, notwithstanding the fact that distribution company is a licensee as per sch. F of Transfer Scheme Rules, it would still have to pay the tax.

The scheme contemplated by the Delhi Electricity Reforms Act and the Rules framed therein is that the assets of the erstwhile Delhi Vidyut Board initially stood transferred and vested absolutely in the Government. The undertakings were transferred to generation, transmission and distribution companies. The shares of these companies were allotted to the Holding Company which is Delhi Power Company Ltd. which is a wholly owned Government company. Land and land rights also were transferred to the Holding Company. Thereafter the process of privatization takes place by divesting shares in the distribution companies. It is clear that the transfer of all the assets including land to the Government is a transitory step as the Holding Company is to be in total control. In the above background, the question is whether the land belongs to the Government and exempt from tax. No doubt, all the assets of Delhi Vidyut Board stood transferred and vested in the Government. It is also clear that the distribution undertaking with assets mentioned in Items I, II & III of Part I of Schedule F were transferred to the Distribution Company. The proviso to Items I, II & III of Part I of Schedule F to the Transfer Scheme Rules contemplates that land which was exclusively and primarily being used for business purpose by the transferee before the transfer does not form part of the assets transferred and the transferee would be a licnesee of the Government for the said land on payment of a nominal amount. Schedule 'G' deals with transfer in favour of the Holding Company and land and land rights is one of the entities therein. Transfer of assets and liabilities are dealt with in Schedule F and it is clear from the said Schedule that the Distribution Company is a licensee of the Government.further Government continues to be the owner of land and the entry land and land rights is vague and has to be ignored as it is not applicable to the land already covered by Schedule F. Whereas, the case of the Corporation is that there is no ambiguity in Schedule G. Land was transferred to the Holding Company and Section 119 of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act is not applicable. The High Court held that the initial transfer and vesting of land is in the Government, then Distribution Company becomes licensee of the Government qua land and finally there is a transfer of land to the Holding Company. In view of the fact that Government was not to hold any asset and the vesting of land in the Government was only transitory in nature, the findings of the High Court that Holding Company is the owner of land is upheld.

	According to Section 120 (1) (c), the person who has a right to let would be liable to pay tax for un-let land. Admittedly, this land is un-let. Incidence of tax has to be decided by the Authority after taking into consideration the provisions of the Act, rules and the licences, including the distribution licence.

	Section 120 (1) (c) contemplates that a person who has the right to let out un-let land is liable to pay tax. His status as a lessor or licensee is irrelevant. If the distribution licence empowers the Distribution Company to let out the land, notwithstanding the fact that the Distribution Company is a licensee as per Schedule 'F' of the Transfer Scheme Rules, it would still have to pay the tax.	 [Para 12,19]

heading: Consideration of
HeadNote.description:
Application for grant of approval - Consideration of - Application received first is to be processed first independently - If it fails to get 70% support, Second Application can be examined - It is not desirable that an application which is earlier made and the one which is subsequently filed should be considered together.

If the entire scheme under Regulation 33(10) is perused it is obvious that if 70% of the slum dwellers on a particular area come together and apply after formation of proposed co-operative housing society, the said application has to be independently considered in accordance with law. The scheme does not contemplate simultaneous consideration of such an application made by a proposed society with an Application subsequently made by another proposed society relating to same land. The Applicant-society has to have 70% support which obviously two societies cannot have. The Application received first is to be processed first independently. If it fails to get 70% support, Second Application can be examined. The obvious intention is to avoid unhealthy competition between the different builders who are interested in supporting such societies. If such a course of simultaneous consideration is permitted to be adopted, unscrupulous persons and builders will try to win over the hutment dwellers who have supported the application made earlier by another society. Therefore, it is not desirable that an application which is earlier made and the one which is subsequently filed should be considered together. That is not the scheme provided under D.C. Regulation 33(10). It is necessary that the application which is first received in respect of a particular property by the SRA should be processed and decided first. After decision of the first Application, the second Application made by another society can be considered depending on the result of the first Application. The reason is that none of the societies have any right, title and interest in respect of the property. Such a course will prevent the unhealthy competition between the builders or between the leaders of two groups in a slum area.  [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Restriction on work
HeadNote.description:
Restriction on work - Plans sanctioned, IOD, Environmental Clearance, NOC issued - Commencement certificate was issued up to 14th floor for Wing C - Show cause notice issued for revocation of commencement certificate - Stop work notice issued and directions given to restrict work of public parking lot up to 4th floor instead of 13th floor - Work of construction had substantially progressed - Order is in deviation to permission granted - Order liable to be set aside. 
AIR 1954 Calcutta 20 Ref. to. 	(Para 18)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Play ground
Change of user
Sports complex
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Play ground - Change of user - Sports complex - Plot of land reserved as 'playground' in final development plan published by State Government - Municipal Corporation deciding to develop it as park, swimming pool and sports complex - Change of user not accorded by State Government - Land entrusted on caretaker basis for construction, management and maintenance of sports complex - Entrustment of land challenged - Single judge dismissed challenge - Appeal - Held, change of user from play ground to sports complex is illegal and against the interest of public - Entrustment for such development is in blatant misuse of powers vested in Corporation and its Commissioner and intended to benefit an individual who was ex-Mayor and sitting M.L.A. at the relevant time - Provisions in D.C. Regulations relating to open spaces in residential and commercial layouts are not applicable to open spaces reserved as play ground - It may not be in the interest of any one to direct demolition of complex - Corporation directed to take possession of plot and structure and make available the facilities to public at large without discrimination.			(Paras 2, 3, 4 and 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Administrative Guidelines for redevelopment of old Municipal properties by Municipal Tenants Co-operative Housing Societies on land owned by Corporation
HeadNote.description:
Administrative Guidelines for redevelopment of old Municipal properties by Municipal Tenants Co-operative Housing Societies on land owned by Corporation - Under the guidelines, no choice is given to tenants/occupants, who are in minority, i.e. 30% or less to take different stand/decision, though it may be possible for such tenant/occupant or a group of tenants/occupants to give up their right and quit from the scheme - Held, if tenants in minority or non-co-operative tenants are given choice to become members of any other society, as of right, perhaps that will create chaos and no redevelopment would ever progress smoothly.

As per the Administrative Guidelines for the re-development of old Municipal properties by Municipal Tenants Co-operative Housing Societies on the land owned by the Corporation under Regulation No.33(7) of the Development Central Regulations for Greater Bombay, 1991, it is necessary that more than 70% of the eligible existing Municipal tenants should give written consent to redevelop the property under the scheme and form an association/co-operative society and initiate proposal of development. There is no dispute that more than 80% tenants/occupants of the Parsi Chawl have formed a society (Pavanputra) and their proposal for redevelopment has been sanctioned by the Improvement Committee of the Corporation on 8.8.2006. Under the guidelines, no choice is given to the tenants/occupants, who are in minority, i.e. 30% or less, to take different stand/decision, though it may be possible for such tenant/occupant or a group of tenants/occupants to give up their right and quit from the scheme. However, once 70% or more tenants/occupants give written consent to redevelop the property under the scheme and form an association/co-operative society and initiate proposal of redevelopment and if the scheme/proposal is approved by the Corporation, it is binding on all the tenants of the chawl/building whether they like it or not. If tenants in minority or non-co-operative tenants are given choice to become members of any other society, as of right, perhaps that will create chaos and no redevelopment would ever progress smoothly. 		 [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Occupancy certificate
HeadNote.description:
Occupancy certificate - Building wherein disputed shop situate, demolished for redevelopment purpose - After redevelopment, since respondent was last occupant of said shop, possession is given to him and also certified him as occupant of said shop - Challenged by petitioners- tenants of said shop - On ground that their name was initially shown in list of occupants certified by MBR and R (Mumbai Building Repairs and Reconstruction) Board - Held, mere certification by MBR and R Board of list of occupants, does not confer any right on petitioners - No interference. 
2003(3) ALL MR 665, AIR 1992 Bombay 53 Ref.to.     (Paras 11, 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Public Interest Litigation
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Public Interest Litigation - Petition for demolition of building Constructed in 2002 on exempted land in violation of CRZ and also in violation of Environmental rules etc. - Similar petition in regard to same building filed earlier dismissed by court - Also, SLP filed against dismissal of write petition dismissed by supreme court - Held, it would not be just and proper to entertain one after another petition regarding the same building - It is for the concerned Authorities to consider whether there is any violations of laws or not - Court cannot monitor each and every building of the city to find out as to whether any law has been violated or not. 	(Para 10)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Housing Area Development Act (1976), S.95A - Summary eviction of tenant - Re-development of dilapidated building along with large number of properties in area - Letters of Intent (LOI) issued under Cluster Re-development scheme sanctioned by State Govt. under Regn.33(9) of DCR - Developer, Landlord Trust already entered into agreement for providing alternate temporary accommodation with petitioner, tenant in said building - None of other occupants impugned notices u/S.95A - Since all conditions u/S.95A satisfied by developer, petitioner could not have refused to vacate two rooms in his possession in spite of several notices issued to him u/S.95A - Plea that till such time developer execute agreement for permanent alternate accommodation or identify new tenement first, no order of eviction would be passed u/S.95A - Not tenable - Further, plea that provisions of S.95A could not have been involved and suit was required to be filed u/S.16 and 33 of MRC Act 1999 for eviction and demolition of building - Not tenable, as State Govt. already approved Cluster Development Scheme in favour of developer for larger land and structures thereon including building in question.			(Paras 57, 60, 63, 65, 68, 69, 70)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Slum area
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Slum Areas (Improvement, Clearance and Re-development) Act (1971)), Ss.33, 38, 4 - Slum area - Issuance of notification u/s.4 of Slum Act - Not a pre requisite for an area to be considered a slum Area rehabilitation area.

In the present case, the submission made on behalf of the Petitioners that the provisions of the Slum Act cannot be invoked unless there is a declaration made under section 4 that the area is a slum area, is without merits.  The provisions of sections 33 and 38 of the Slum Act have been invoked by the Respondents in order to evict the slum dwellers from the area which is a censused slum.  It is only the machinery which is available under the Slum Act that is being utilised for the purposes of removing the occupants from a land which is declared a slum area.  In fact under the D. C. Regulations steps can be taken to evict those hutment dwellers who do not join a rehabilitation project willingly.  The provisions clearly stipulate that if the hutment dwellers do not join the scheme within 15 days after a slum rehabilitation project has been approved, then action under the provisions of the Slum Act including sections 33 and 38 as amended from time to time can be taken against the hutments.  All those who do not join the project lose the right to any built up tenament and their tenament can be taken over by the slum rehabilitation authority and can be used for accommodating those slum dwellers from other slums who cannot be accommodated in situ.  The Corporation on 24-05-1996 issued a letter of "no objection" after verifying the proposal of Respondent No.3 for rehabilitation of the slum area.  After completion of various other formalities the Slum Rehabilitation Authority approved the project on certain terms and conditions.  The impugned orders have been passed after the slum rehabilitation project was approved by the Slum Rehabilitation Authority (SRA).  Factually what has been done is recourse taken to the provisions of sections 33 and 38 of the Slum Act for the purposes of implementing the development plan or project undertaken under D. C. Regulations in relation to a censused area.  That being permissible in law, mere use of machinery provided under the Slum Act cannot be faulted.  Therefore, there is no substance in the contentions of the petitioners that without a notification under section 4 of the Slum Act the provisions of the Act cannot be used at all.  2004(2) ALL MR 320 and 2003(4) ALL MR 584 - Referred to.					  [Para 8]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Transferable Development Rights (TDR) - Grant of - Land already vested in Planning Authority - Permission for development could not be granted to original owners - Grant of TDR to the original owners, held, was beyond the scope of appeal under S.47 of the Act of 1966. 2006(4) ALL MR 326 - Ref. to. 	(Para 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Reg.33(15), is not applicable with retrospective effect.	(Para 49)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Reduction
HeadNote.description: Segregating distance i.e. liner distance on ground between plot boundaries - Reduction - Not shown to have adverse impact - Interference with such decision on merits - Not permissible for not being shown to be utterly perverse.		(Para 79)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Modification in development plan
HeadNote.description:
Modification in development plan - Reservation "housing for dishoused" deleted - Obligation upon owner is only restricted to handing over 10% of permissible built up area.

Where the land with the reservation "housing the dishoused" is allotted by the Government, for dereservation the allottee would have to give away 10% built up area (100 sq,mts.) to the Municipal Corporation for housing the dishoused and then use the balance 90% (900 sq.mts.) area for himself and in addition get additional FSI of 10% (100 sq.mts.) to compensate for the 10% built up area given to the Municipal Corporation for housing the dishoused. It is, therefore, clear that there is no obligation that the entire plot area has to be used for the purpose of housing the dishoused. The reservation itself makes it clear that the obligation upon owner is only restricted to handing over 10% of the permissible built up area. In other words, for a plot admeasuring 10,000 sq.mtrs. with FSI of 1, the owner is free to use the entire FSI of the plot and construct 10,000 sq.mts. of built up area, subject to handing 10% built up area (1000 sq.mtrs.) over to the Municipal Corporation. 				 [Para 15,18,33]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Sanction of Slum Re-development Scheme
HeadNote.description:
Sanction of Slum Re-development Scheme - Issuance of notification u/s.3-C(1) of the Slum Act, not a condition precedent for sanction of slum re-development scheme governed by Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991), Regn.33(10).

For sanction of a scheme governed by the said Regulation in respect of a parcel of land, it is not necessary to have a declaration of the particular parcel of land as a slum rehabilitation area in exercise of power under section 3-C(1) of the Slum Act. The Slum Rehabilitation Scheme can be sanctioned in respect of a slum as defined in clause II of Annexure to Regulation 33(10). Under the said Annexure there can be a scheme for a viable stretch of pavement also. 2004(3) Bom.C.R. 14 - Referred to.  [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Compensation against land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Compensation against land acquisition - Whenever a set back land is acquired by the Corporation, the owner of the land is entitled to the compensation or FSI in lieu of compensation.  (Para 1)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Claim for compensation or FSI in lieu thereof
HeadNote.description: Claim for compensation or FSI in lieu thereof - Limitation of 12 years - Petitioner's land acquired by the Corporation - Correspondence was exchanged with regard to fixation and payment of compensation - During limitation period no decision was taken by the Corporation - Petitioner's claim for compensation or FSI is maintainable even after expiry of limitation period. (Paras 1, 2, 5)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Amenities
HeadNote.description: Circular dt.9th April, 1996 - Amenities - Circular providing 100% FSI to public utilities which do not find place under S.2(2) - It is highly debatable if those public utilities can be introduced through the circular as 'amenities' within the meaning of the Act or the Regulations.	(Para 45)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Agreement to surrender land in terms of S.126(1)(b)
HeadNote.description: Agreement to surrender land in terms of S.126(1)(b) - Cannot be subjected to any further conditions than those already provided for in statutory provisions - Fact that representative of appellant was present in the meeting where graded scheme for grant of additional TDR was introduced would not authorise municipal authorities to override or supersede statutory provisions.	(Para 48)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Lease hold property
HeadNote.description: Lease hold property - Permission for development in lease premises - Prerequisite of NOC from defence department - Admittedly naval base is adjacent to leased property having a common compound wall - Risk of danger is on higher side of area of leased premise as compared to other high rise buildings and slum areas that are at some distance from naval base - Planning should examine other aspect than provided u/s.46 of Act, 1996 while granting development permission - Planning authority may refuse to grant permission of using land if proposed development is likely to involve damage or is not in public interest - Insistence of planning authority of NOC from Navy Department being in public interest - Cannot be said to be dehors provisions of Act and Regulations. (Paras 17, 18, 19)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Redevelopment scheme
HeadNote.description:
Redevelopment scheme - Minor corrections in description of plots - Not to affect the project as also the timely and/or phase wise development on permissible area.

The clear description of area and boundaries is a must for any project or any redevelopment scheme. The announced scheme is always based on the major land and/or plot and for any calculation for redevelopment, respective tenants' share/ area of the occupants, commercial area/saleable area of the builder, and for FSI purpose and/or such other similar purposes. The exact area/measurement is a must. Some minor corrections here or there, should not affect the project and so also the timely and/or phase-wise development on the available area and/or permissible area. The correction, even if any, can always be corrected and/or subject to correction and/or amendment of the plans. But the area and/or plot must be clearly demarcated with clear boundaries. It is necessary to avoid further complications and/or problems in the construction, as well as, the completion of the project.
2011(4) ALL MR 120 - Ref. to.  [Para 101,102]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Slum redevelopment scheme
HeadNote.description: Slum redevelopment scheme - Requirement as to consent of 70% slum dwellers - Is mandatory. (Paras 61, 62)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Slum redevelopment scheme
HeadNote.description: Slum redevelopment scheme - Migration from 1991 scheme to 1997 scheme - Applicability of conditions of new scheme - Appellant appointed as developer while DCR of 1991 was in force - Later on migrated to amended scheme of 1997 which required it to enter individual agreements with minimum 70% slum dwellers - Facts and evidence show that after migration, SRA insisted and appellant clearly understood that it had to submit relevant agreements - In fact, it had submitted some of agreements - Appellant now cannot take U-turn to say that it is not governed by amended regulations of 1997 - Relevant agreements to be submitted within reasonable time.  (Para 70)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Development plan
HeadNote.description:
Development plan - Suit plot reserved for municipal school in Development plan 1991 - Could be renewed once again for same purpose in Development Plan 2034 - No case by petitioner that reservation of said plot was sought to be deleted in Development Plan 2034 - Modification of Development Plan is ongoing process, warranted from time to time - There is no automatic lapses of reservations - Therefore, suit plot could not have been allotted to any of the petitioners.	
	(Paras 125, 126, 128, 131, 132)

headline:
(A) Allotment of Govt. land – Review/revision by Revenue Minister/Chief Secretary – Limitation – Application filed much after expiry of 90 days from date of allotment – Barred by limitation.	
	

(B) Locus standi – Petitioner, lessee permitted to use structure on Govt. land – Lease expired and not renewed – Land in question allotted to other allottee – Thus, lessee had no locus to challenge said allotment of land – Merely because few letters were addressed by petitioner to Collector for renewal of lease – Would not create any right in favour of petitioner in said suit structure.			


(C)  Allotment of Govt. land – Petitioner did not pay market value in respect of said land – Nor entered into any agreement with State Govt. – Thus, on basis of mere allotment letter, petitioner cannot claim any right, title or interest of any nature whatsoever in respect of suit land. 	(Para 118)


(D) Development plan – Suit plot reserved for municipal school in Development plan 1991 – Could be renewed once again for same purpose in Development Plan 2034 – No case by petitioner that reservation of said plot was sought to be deleted in Development Plan 2034 – Modification of Development Plan is ongoing process, warranted from time to time – There is no automatic lapses of reservations – Therefore, suit plot could not have been allotted to any of the petitioners.	
	

(E) Reservation of land – Lapsing of – Petitioner has not established any right, title or interest of any nature whatsoever in suit plot – Not entitled to invoke such provision u/S.127 of MRTP Act.

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Slums
Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Slums - Meaning of - The slums mean either censused slums or slums declared and notified as such under Slums Act.

A General Scheme under Section 3-B of the Slum Act can be framed either by the State Government or by SRA with the prior approval of the State Government. However, the scheme under clause 33(10) is to be approved in individual cases by the SRA. Clause (II) of Annexure to the said Regulation provides that for the purpose of Regulation 33(10), a slum means that area which is either censused or one which is declared and notified under the Slum Act. It provides that the slum shall also mean areas pavement stretches hereafter notified as slum rehabilitation areas. The clause provides that if any area fulfills conditions laid down in section 4 of the Slum Act to qualify as a slum area and has been either censused or declared and notified as slum, it shall be deemed to be and treated as Slum Rehabilitation Areas. The said clause also provides that censused means those slums located on lands belonging to Government, any undertaking of Government, or to Brihan Mumbai Municipal Corporation and incorporated in the records of the land owning authority as having been censused in 1976, 1980, or 1985 or prior to 1st January, 1995. Thus for the purpose of scheme under Regulation 33(10), the following areas are Slum Rehabilitation Areas; (a) any area which fulfills the conditions laid down in section 4 of the Slum Act which is declared and notified as such and (b) slum rehabilitation area declared as such by the Slum Rehabilitation Authority fulfilling the conditions laid down in section 4 of the Slum Act to qualify as slum area and/or required for implementation of any slum rehabilitation project. Regulation 33(10) contemplates that there can be redevelopment of slums including pavements. The slums are defined by clause II. The slums mean either censused slums or slums declared and notified as such under the Slum Act. Clause II also defines the word censused which means slums located on lands belonging to Government, any undertaking of the Government or Mumbai Municipal Corporation and incorporated in records of the land owning authority as having been censused in 1976, 1980 or 1985 or prior to 1st January, 1985.  [Para 19]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Re-development of area under Urban Development Scheme
HeadNote.description: Re-development of area under Urban Development Scheme - Challenge to letter of Intent (LOI) issued to developer - On ground that requisite consent of tenants were not obtained - GO dated 10th December, 2009 provides for two options to obtain LOI under Reg.33(9) - Under option II of said GO, consent of 70% land owners is required - Developer proceeded to obtain consent of 77.67% of total number of tenants/occupants - No land owner contending that consent to re-development was not given or that the consent was obtained either by coercion, undue influence or misrepresentation - Hence, LOI is not liable to be quashed. 			(Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Grant of permission
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Bombay Public Trust Act (1950) - Sale of trust property - Grant of permission - Challenge - Property being sold for reason of it being largely tenanted and very meager rents were being obtained - Offer of 6 crores made by developer - Reasonableness of offer tested by issuing fresh advertisement as per court's direction - Same was found reasonable and even offer raised up to 8.25 crores - Sale-cum-development agreement also entered into between parties - Moreover, 74% occupiers have consented for redevelopment - In such circumstances, acceptance of offer would be for the benefit of the trust - Permission granted. (Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Propriety
HeadNote.description:
Redevelopment cum sale of trust property - Agreement with a particular developer without any public advertisement - Propriety - Depends on facts and circumstances of each case.

The decision of the Charity Commissioner regarding need to issue public advertisement will depend on the facts and circumstances of each case. The Charity Commissioner must however take into consideration the object of the Act stressing the need for supervision and must rest his decision on cogent grounds. The decision cannot be arbitrary, should be guided by prudence and realities of the situation and should be reasoned one so that it is correctable by higher forums. 			    [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Propriety
HeadNote.description:
Redevelopment cum sale of trust property - Agreement with a particular developer without any public advertisement - Action sought to be justified on ground that tenants wanted only a 'Maharashtrian' developer - Propriety - Building in instant case is of immense value situated in heart of commercial areas but tenants hardly having any idea about its worth - Unless competitive bids are invited, they would not have fair idea about true worth of building - Their decision based on regionalism cannot be said to be well informed - Consequently, decision to dispense with public advertisement is also unjustified - Matter remanded back to Charity Commissioner with direction to issue public advertisement.

In the instant case, it appears that the reason given for not giving advertisement was that the tenants wanted a 'Maharashtrian' developer to develop the property and Raunak Corporation was the best candidate. If the trustees genuinely wanted to entrust the work of development in whom they and tenants had confidence, nothing stopped them from calling for best offers and then narrowing down the choice. The selection of Raunak Corporation on the basis that it is the best developer is based on an inadequate data.

The trustees and developers are placing the tenants in the forefront and contending that it is the tenants' desire that they want a 'Maharashtrian' developer. Admittedly the tenants are staying in the dilapidated chawls for years and do not belong to a very rich class. They may or may not have any idea what is the true worth of the property when it is exploited commercially by a developer. The intricate calculation of FSI, TDR and the manner in which they can be commercially exploited are better known to developers. When properties such as the present one, i.e. old dilapidated buildings in the heart of commercial areas consisting of tenants, are put up for alienation, only when competitive bids are invited that all concerned will have a good idea of what is the true worth of the properties and how much corpus will be available. Tenants/occupiers may get tenements of fixed area but competitive bids may push up the corpus and offer several other amenities. Then they may discover that it is the builder of their chosen regionality was in fact cheating them. In the present case the tenants were not exposed to the true worth of the properties in their possession and the monies they would receive. Their decision could not be treated as a well informed one. This decision cannot certainly be advanced as a reason for the trustees and the developers to dispense with public advertisement.

Considering the totality of the circumstances such as the nature of the property, location, valuation, object of the Act, duties of the trustees, reasons for not giving advertisements, there is no error in directing the Charity Commissioner to call for advertisement from all interested developers. Such course of action cannot be said to be against the interest of the Trust. Such course of action will not only be in the interest of Trust but would dispel all doubts. 						      [Para 20,27]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Circular of Corporation, dt. 11.9.2012 - Unregistered power of attorney - Seeking sanction for development - Rejection of - Validity - S.17 provides that an irrecoverable power of attorney relating to transfer of immovable property executed on or after commencement of amended Act - On 1.4.2013, is liable to be registered - Petitioner sought permission for development after coming into force amended provision of S.17 - Petitioners power of attorney, therefore required to be registered - Rejection of unregistered power of attorney, proper. 	(Paras 5, 6)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Redevelopment of building
Residents not responsible
Accepted
HeadNote.description: Redevelopment of building - Compensation in lieu of alternate accommodation - Redevelopment agreement entered in 2008 - It stipulated completion of construction within 24 months and also provided that in the event of non-completion, residents would be entitled to increased compensation - Construction not completed, though 5 years passed - Reason for non-completion was dispute between developer and BMC regarding lease of land - Residents not responsible - They were kept out of their premises for 5 years - Though case made out for cancellation of NOC and IOD issued to developer and construction being entrusted to a third party, court not inclined to pass such order - In view of fact that respondent developer has already expended a large sum of money, his undertaking to complete the project in 24 months, irrespective of any difficulty - Accepted - However, the respondent would have to pay increased compensation - That being a condition to extension of time, cannot be said to be alteration in original agreement - Petitioners entitled to enhanced compensation w.e.f. January 2011.			(Paras 3, 13, 14, 17, 20, 21, 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Slum Rehabilitation Scheme
Proposal rejected
HeadNote.description: Slum Rehabilitation Scheme - Proposal initially accepted on the basis that required consent of minimum 70% slum dwellers was obtained - Later on Authorities found that percent of consent as shown was incorrect - Proposal rejected - No opportunity to explain was given to proposers - Breach of natural justice - Rejection order liable to be set aside.	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Environmental clearance
Application pending
HeadNote.description: IOD issued by corporation - Environmental clearance - Application pending - Environmental clearance is required only if construction is in excess of 20,000 sq. meters - Petitioner already granted IOD for construction upto 14809 sq. meters - Held, commencement certificate should be considered without requiring petitioners to produce environment clearance from State Level Impact Assessment Authority. 			(Paras 16, 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Environmental clearance
HeadNote.description: Permission to redevelop property granted by MHADA - Municipal corporation also issuing IOD under S.346 of Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act - Environmental clearance - In view of inordinate delays in granting such clearance authorities directed to consider grant of commencement certificate to put up construction of about 11,000 sq. meters in the first phase immediately because environmental clearance is required only where proposed construction exceeds 20,000 sq. meters. 			(Paras 12, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Clarificatory amendment Dt.04-04-2011 to CRI Notification of 2011
HeadNote.description:
Clarificatory amendment Dt.04-04-2011 to CRI Notification of 2011 - Applicability.

The amendment dated 4 April 2011 is clarificatory as indicated in the preamble to the Notification itself. The change in the definition of built up area from merely covered area to areas including basement and service areas will significantly increase the construction area. After all, CRZ clearance is all about construction activity in a coastal zone and, therefore, merely because the construction is open to sky would not make it any less the construction than the construction of the covered area. The Notification dated 4 April 2011 will apply to the pending projects as well, meaning thereby the projects are not already executed. [Para 16]

However, when clearances are required only for projects with built up area exceeding 20,000 sq. meters, redevelopment projects for residential buildings should not be unnecessarily delayed even to the extent of construction upto 20,000 sq. meters when the developer is ready to give undertaking not to exceed the construction beyond 20,000 sq. meters without first obtaining environmental clearance. The Authorities take considerable time for taking a decision on the application for environmental clearance or for CRZ clearance. In the meantime the redevelopment projects are being delayed. High Court has been granting relief in such cases on the basis that even if ultimately the authorities were to reject the applications for clearance, there will be no illegality in so far as the developer has made construction upto 20,000 sq. meters. [Para 17]

HeadNote.act_name: Development Control Regulations for Greater Bombay (1991)
heading: Interpretation of third paragraph
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of third paragraph - Word "of" incorporated in sentence of provision, ".... of area of plot remaining after such surrender...." - Plain reading of sentence permits utilization of FSI of 40% of balance area of plot remained after area is surrendered for road widening/ construction of new road in Mumbai - It completely takes away object to achieve as to what has been stipulated in paragraphs one and two of Reg.33(1) - Third paragraph does not confer any additional or different FSI benefit - But, only prescribes manner in which benefit of FSI already conferred under paragraphs one and two is to be utilized - Word "of" in following sentence of third paragraph creates absurdity and therefore, is required to be read as "on" - Such interpretation of provision becomes workable and satisfies its legislative intent and object. 1955 ALLMR ONLINE 159 (S.C.), 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1032 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 21, 22, 24)

Challenge to
